componenttext: That would be correct.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay. And then just lastly, on gross margin, why would fourth quarter be the lowest increase of the year?
componenttext: Okay. Okay. And then just lastly, on gross margin, why would fourth quarter be the lowest increase of the year?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Probably a good question, and we take a look at some of the detail. Yes, there's several components and a lot of them are -- I want to say, relatively small. We try to hit the highlights as we do detailed analysis and work through some of the other i
componenttext: Yes. Probably a good question, and we take a look at some of the detail. Yes, there's several components and a lot of them are -- I want to say, relatively small. We try to hit the highlights as we do detailed analysis and work through some of the other impacts throughout the quarter. There's some variances. So when we look at next year, it's really hard to match it up, but there are a lot of other impacts that are in the quarter. It could be as basic relative to new store discount that flows through. We go back and we've been working with our vendors overseas, looking at discounts and getting adjustments for foreign currency. Really, it's a lot of these minor issues that impact margin that will make it a little bit more difficult comparison as we go into Q4.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Jaime Katz with MorningStar.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Jaime Katz with MorningStar.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'm curious, you guys talked about drawing on your revolver, maybe at slightly higher levels than in the past over the next few quarters. And I'm curious if there's been any difference in working capital intensity or how that's changed for you guys?
componenttext: So I'm curious, you guys talked about drawing on your revolver, maybe at slightly higher levels than in the past over the next few quarters. And I'm curious if there's been any difference in working capital intensity or how that's changed for you guys?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: There hasn't really been a significant change. Obviously, as we worked our way through Q4 with the softer sales and higher inventory levels, there's going to be an impact there. But our general philosophy is to continue to drive improved turns, although a
componenttext: There hasn't really been a significant change. Obviously, as we worked our way through Q4 with the softer sales and higher inventory levels, there's going to be an impact there. But our general philosophy is to continue to drive improved turns, although again, it will be a challenge this year as far as improving turns as we work through some of the inventory coming out of the seasonal -- the winter season. So there's been no change there. Where we've been focused over the last couple of years is to continue purchasing under the share repurchase program. And that's really been the major drivers as far as use of cash.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, in the past, I know you guys had called out maybe the Northwest in 2017 for possible distribution center and then maybe the Northeast thereafter. But I'm wondering if the ordering or anything like that has changed and where you're finding
componenttext: Okay. And then, in the past, I know you guys had called out maybe the Northwest in 2017 for possible distribution center and then maybe the Northeast thereafter. But I'm wondering if the ordering or anything like that has changed and where you're finding the best opportunities to build out your footprint right now versus maybe where you thought they were last year, just if [indiscernible] better in one location over the other?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jaime, this is Greg. As we said, we're going through our typical 3- to 4-year study right now. And I think once we're through that, we'll have better answers. Right now, with the West DC in place, particularly in [indiscernible] Arizona, we can service a
componenttext: Jaime, this is Greg. As we said, we're going through our typical 3- to 4-year study right now. And I think once we're through that, we'll have better answers. Right now, with the West DC in place, particularly in [indiscernible] Arizona, we can service a number of stores on the western seaboard. But [indiscernible] analysis will be, we'll have probably more to talk about, about midyear. And we'll probably bring this topic up again at that time.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Chuck Cerankosky with North Coast Research.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Chuck Cerankosky with North Coast Research.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question and looking at the fourth quarter customer behavior, with the categories you mentioned being influenced by the warm weather. How does that relate to how customers put together their baskets in traffic if they're not in there for some
componenttext: Just a quick question and looking at the fourth quarter customer behavior, with the categories you mentioned being influenced by the warm weather. How does that relate to how customers put together their baskets in traffic if they're not in there for some of the cold stuff? Are there attachment rates that would accrue to a purchase of a heater or stove that we just didn't see because of the weather?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [ph] Well, yes. And when we look at the basket and look at the transactions, it's very clear that we're still getting the footsteps. And so again, our customers are coming in for their everyday needs. And the driver relative to some of the cold winter p
componenttext:
[ph] 
Well, yes. And when we look at the basket and look at the transactions, it's very clear that we're still getting the footsteps. And so again, our customers are coming in for their everyday needs. And the driver relative to some of the cold winter product really is related to the ticket, and the drive -- we talked about some of the big ticket was 70 basis points on the average ticket. So we're still driving in the footsteps, and obviously, we're very pleased with the positive transaction count increase. Obviously, the basket might not be as big as they come into the store because of the decline in some of the winter seasonal goods. But again, it's really the strong transaction count that is driving the business.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Eric Bosshard with Cleveland Research Company.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Eric Bosshard with Cleveland Research Company.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: With the online efforts and what you're doing and the growth that you're seeing there, and I recognize that it's still a small piece of the business, but curious as you've started to dig into this, what you're seeing in terms of an evolution of your custo
componenttext: With the online efforts and what you're doing and the growth that you're seeing there, and I recognize that it's still a small piece of the business, but curious as you've started to dig into this, what you're seeing in terms of an evolution of your customers' desires or interest in online and how big of an opportunity you think this is. And then, if your thinking about that has changed as you've started to become more involved within this.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric, this is Greg. I would tell you that we are very delighted as we have started to build out the content piece of the business and giving the customer more information about product that, that is kind of helping us push through into the social space, a
componenttext: Eric, this is Greg. I would tell you that we are very delighted as we have started to build out the content piece of the business and giving the customer more information about product that, that is kind of helping us push through into the social space, as well as driving some commerce. So I said, it's less than 1%. It's growing rapidly. We have to get the new platform up. Rob Mills' [ph] team did a wonderful job working with Letitia, who is our VP in that area, really getting this platform up and running. We've still got some tooling to do to it. What we're seeing is customers are going to the web to research. And then, from the web, they're starting to look at the option of buying it online, picking it up at the store or having it shipped to the store. By now, we can give them the option of ship to store. We can't give them pick up at store. And there's a difference. One is shipping it to the store from a DC or from a third-party. The other is, it's actually being held there at the store for the customer when they buy it online. So we're seeing that, and then this whole special order component that's coming online later this year I'm very excited about. It's one of the areas that our store struggle with daily, trying to leaf through books and catalogs, and that they'll talk all of that out of the way and they'll be able to go to the screen there at the service center that's in the middle of the store and pull things, pull information up, address the customer, customer can transact there. And we'll be able to even give them the ETA of when it's going to be there and so on. No one in our space is doing anything quite like this and it's pretty exciting. But how big will it be over time? Hard to say.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Joseph Feldman with Telsey Advisory Group.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Joseph Feldman with Telsey Advisory Group.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask also about e-commerce, actually. Again, early days and I understand that. But anything you can share about the type of customer that you're seeing or maybe what the customer is purchasing, if that's different in any ways than you would hav
componenttext: I wanted to ask also about e-commerce, actually. Again, early days and I understand that. But anything you can share about the type of customer that you're seeing or maybe what the customer is purchasing, if that's different in any ways than you would have expected or exactly even what it is relative to what you see purchasing in the stores?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Joe, it's Greg. A couple of things we noticed. They have no issue, no problem at all buying large ticket, big ticket items, because we have a delivery process that we can get the product to them, basically drop shipping it or taking it LTL, whether it's a
componenttext: Joe, it's Greg. A couple of things we noticed. They have no issue, no problem at all buying large ticket, big ticket items, because we have a delivery process that we can get the product to them, basically drop shipping it or taking it LTL, whether it's a safe or a riding lawn mower, what have you. They don't have that advantage necessarily when they buy at the store. That's typically bring your own truck, bring your trailer, or you we can arrange for deliveries from the store to your property. So that kind of surprised, I think, all of us. We still have a high component of footwear and apparel that's coming through. But they're buying across the store, ironically. And I think the more that we put product content out there and we're able to draw that in and expand the envelope in the files and some categories of things, whether it's Tractor parts or some of that hard to find type of items that only Tractor will probably have versus some other store, that's where the real opportunity is going to be. It's a true area for destination for us as we can evolve this. And I think it's quite exciting. We're not doing things like feed and food necessarily in a big way. We are selling some ped food, but this is really the kind of things that only Tractor Supply sells or that the customer is saying, "Boy, it's easier for me just to buy it online and have it delivered to my property."

headline: Tractor Supply Company, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just another sort of unrelated question. But you touched on rolling out a new special order system in the stores. And I just wanted to get a little more color on that, like what's involved with that rollout and how that will that work, an
componenttext: Got it. And then just another sort of unrelated question. But you touched on rolling out a new special order system in the stores. And I just wanted to get a little more color on that, like what's involved with that rollout and how that will that work, and training maybe and expense related to that, and what specific items people do need to use that system for.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, today, we have a special order business that is, I would say, not substantial but significant. But it's done in a very cumbersome way. We put the burden on the store to really do the research, to make the phone calls. And there are some work -- ther
componenttext: Well, today, we have a special order business that is, I would say, not substantial but significant. But it's done in a very cumbersome way. We put the burden on the store to really do the research, to make the phone calls. And there are some work -- there are some things we can work with them on to [indiscernible] Store Support Center to aid that process, but it's clunky. The new process will be very fast, very easy for both the team member and the customer at the store. They can transact at the store. And it's going to give us real-time data. We lock in the order, here's the price it's being sold at. Here's the ETA of delivery to your home or to store for pickup. We think it's going to be used primarily again for the kinds of things that you can't find in the store or the kinds of -- quantities of things that you're buying that you need quite a few of them. If someone comes in for a [indiscernible]  On a particular piece of equipment and we have maybe 20 in the store but they want 100, that's something you can go ahead and just place as a special order and give it to them. Or if it's a -- we carry 5 SKUs of [indiscernible] category and we now have to build it through the longer tail to have all 50 SKUs, the customer has the choice to be able to buy deeper into that category or from that vendor. So I'm excited about it. I don't -- I can't tell you how large that can be over time, but I do think that our guys in IT have done a wonderful job working with the stores to understand the need, to understand how this needs to work, take the work out of it from both them and the customer, make it easy. And I think it's going to be something we'll be talking about at greater length as we get toward the end of the year.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to David Magee with SunTrust.
componenttext: We'll go next to David Magee with SunTrust.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. One is, you mentioned deflation this year being a lesser dynamic, less throughout the year. Can you just quickly talk about just some of the puts and takes there? What's the bigger -- what's the biggest variable in determining that?
componenttext: A couple of questions. One is, you mentioned deflation this year being a lesser dynamic, less throughout the year. Can you just quickly talk about just some of the puts and takes there? What's the bigger -- what's the biggest variable in determining that?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly, the biggest variable is the impact on feed, and that's what's moderated. Obviously, oil prices have come down, so oil-related products -- there's some deflation in that category. But it tends not to be as impactful as what we had experience
componenttext: Well, clearly, the biggest variable is the impact on feed, and that's what's moderated. Obviously, oil prices have come down, so oil-related products -- there's some deflation in that category. But it tends not to be as impactful as what we had experienced with feed. So we anticipate that it will be flattening out over the course of the year. Obviously, that's going to be dependent on where oil goes. And obviously, each conference call, we'll update you as to what we expect out of deflation or inflation.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just secondly, with regard to the Neighbor's Club project that's going on now, if this turns out to be a big success over the next year or so, what metrics do you think will be moved by it at the store level? Is it primarily traffic? Or do you th
componenttext: And then just secondly, with regard to the Neighbor's Club project that's going on now, if this turns out to be a big success over the next year or so, what metrics do you think will be moved by it at the store level? Is it primarily traffic? Or do you think margins might be enhanced? How do you see that evolving?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is Steve. One of the values of having a loyalty program in a pilot is to test exactly that. Right now, we're getting our first seasonal rewards out to the customers that have adopted or signed into the program, and we're going to see what respo
componenttext: Well, this is Steve. One of the values of having a loyalty program in a pilot is to test exactly that. Right now, we're getting our first seasonal rewards out to the customers that have adopted or signed into the program, and we're going to see what response rates we get. The other thing strategically that we talk a lot about internally is the importance of personalization. And Greg has talked a lot about the digital side of our business and what we're doing on the web. Getting these e-mail addresses and being able to talk to consumers the way they want to be talked to on their purchase history, we're finding that we've got a lot better open rates on e-mails that we're sending out. And we believe, by continuing to talk to them in the way they want to be talked to, we should see better traffic on our stores and increase in sales. So again, part of the pilot and what we're trying to learn right now before we roll out to more stores is to quantify what that's going to look like.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

headline: Tractor Supply Company, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first issue I'd like to ask about is new store productivity. By our math, it looks like there was a bit of a step-down in new store productivity this quarter. Curious to know if there's any brush off of that with timing and store openings or anything
componenttext: The first issue I'd like to ask about is new store productivity. By our math, it looks like there was a bit of a step-down in new store productivity this quarter. Curious to know if there's any brush off of that with timing and store openings or anything else?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. When we look at the overall productivity of the new stores, in aggregate, our new stores are hitting our pro forma, so we feel very good about that. There are some pockets, in particular, in one of our new markets that we went into over the last 1.5
componenttext: Yes. When we look at the overall productivity of the new stores, in aggregate, our new stores are hitting our pro forma, so we feel very good about that. There are some pockets, in particular, in one of our new markets that we went into over the last 1.5 years. Utah has come out slower than we had anticipated, so that's pulled the numbers down a little bit. And so sometimes, in some markets, it's going to take a while to build and strengthen our positioning in particular markets. But the one thing that we really like is how the stores have comped, particularly in the West as well. So in some cases, the stores may come out a little bit lighter in sales than we have anticipated. But overall, they're coming out consistent with our pro forma and they are ramping at a nice clip. So as we look overall at productivity, what's important to us is, as we approve the stores that they live up to the pro forma that we've designed for each store. And generally, over the years, we open up stores somewhere between $2.8 million and $3.2 million. Each year's groups of stores are going to vary but will generally be in that range. So I would expect, as our chain continues to grow substantially, that the productivity will sort of stay in this range or at times flatten out a bit. But relative to 2014 -- 2015, there's nothing in that mix of stores that caused any sort of differentiation to how the stores have performed in the past.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got you. I would think that in the fourth quarter, with the West doing so well and a lot of your stores concentrated out West, or I should say your new stores concentrated out West, that should be a benefit to new store productivity. But it seemed t
componenttext: Okay. Got you. I would think that in the fourth quarter, with the West doing so well and a lot of your stores concentrated out West, or I should say your new stores concentrated out West, that should be a benefit to new store productivity. But it seemed to be a step-down. Does that suggest that there is any further weakness in the Utah region? Or any other spot of the new store opening fleet?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. What we experienced was nice comps. And like I had said, if the stores come out a little bit less than what have been pro forma, we generally see a nice comp ramp. So again, as long as the stores are consistent with the pro forma that we have out ther
componenttext: No. What we experienced was nice comps. And like I had said, if the stores come out a little bit less than what have been pro forma, we generally see a nice comp ramp. So again, as long as the stores are consistent with the pro forma that we have out there, we believe that we'll get a nice return. The IRR will be nice and firm and continue to grow the ROIC.

componenttext: Thank you, operator. As we look ahead to 2016, we are excited about our opportunity for growth.
