componenttext: We'll take our next question from Jessica Mace with Nomura Securities.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question is about the health of the consumer. On your last call, you made some comments about seeing some caution amongst consumers. And I just wonder if on the other side of the first quarter, you have any updates or any changes you've noticed i
componenttext: My first question is about the health of the consumer. On your last call, you made some comments about seeing some caution amongst consumers. And I just wonder if on the other side of the first quarter, you have any updates or any changes you've noticed in that behavior.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jessica, this is Tony. I'll answer that since I have such a handle on the consumer themselves. But I would tell you that really our outlook hasn't changed. We are company and people are coming to us for their everyday needs. And that is really the consist
componenttext: Jessica, this is Tony. I'll answer that since I have such a handle on the consumer themselves. But I would tell you that really our outlook hasn't changed. We are company and people are coming to us for their everyday needs. And that is really the consistency of our business model. As we talked about, big-ticket relatively consistent and again consistent with chain average for the most part in the quarter. So again, we have a resilient model because of the basic needs and supporting that of the rural lifestyle. And we did not see any significant changes in the consumer patterns throughout the quarter.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my second question is on the transportation cost. I just wondering if you could review some of the moving pieces a little bit. What you get a benefit from as a result of the Southwest distribution center and then on some of the inbound frei
componenttext: Okay. And then my second question is on the transportation cost. I just wondering if you could review some of the moving pieces a little bit. What you get a benefit from as a result of the Southwest distribution center and then on some of the inbound freight cost, what the outlook is for those for the rest of the year.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly. When it comes to the transportation cost, the key to the Arizona distribution center is that obviously, we're reducing the outbound stem miles to the store. And we're very successful there, and we saw a reduction in those transportation costs.
componenttext: Certainly. When it comes to the transportation cost, the key to the Arizona distribution center is that obviously, we're reducing the outbound stem miles to the store. And we're very successful there, and we saw a reduction in those transportation costs. But obviously, the inbound from many of our Eastern-based vendors, the inbound miles increased substantially as well. So the key to the program go forward is to make sure that we have either additional facilities of the Eastern vendor base and they open up additional facilities out West and/or we bring on Western-based vendors. So when -- but the key to the distribution center really is, as we move forward, and then the stores that we open in the West now will not have that deleveraging impact that we experienced as we had that accelerated growth out West. So as we bring on new stores out West, they'll be less impactful to our transportation cost. And that's really the key benefit to the Arizona distribution center.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Ben Bienvenu with Stephens.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Ben Bienvenu with Stephens.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just looking at the ticket, the improvement there, you spoke to the basket getting bigger. What are some of the areas where you're seeing product merchandise resonate with customers to drive this? And how sustainable do you think this trend is going forwa
componenttext: Just looking at the ticket, the improvement there, you spoke to the basket getting bigger. What are some of the areas where you're seeing product merchandise resonate with customers to drive this? And how sustainable do you think this trend is going forward?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve Barbarick here. What I would tell you is we've got a number of different levers to drive sales and one of those is drive aisle. And that's the in-caps, the power panels and the center cords. Greg referenced Chick Days earlier in his canned remarks.
componenttext: Steve Barbarick here. What I would tell you is we've got a number of different levers to drive sales and one of those is drive aisle. And that's the in-caps, the power panels and the center cords. Greg referenced Chick Days earlier in his canned remarks. And we also had a garden event that took place in the center core. And we're seeing really good movement in both of those events as well as getting behind and working with our vendors on our in-cap programs. So that's really what's helped to drive some of the increase in the basket. In terms of sustainability, this is a focus for us. And it's something we're getting better at. And I would hate to tell you that or I wouldn't want to suggest that this is sustainable in every quarter we're going to talk about the gains. But I can tell you, we're making a concerted effort to put in front of the customers those impulse buys as they shop our stores for needs-based products.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then looking at import sales continues to nicely tick up as a percentage of total sales. What are some of the categories that are driving the majority of the growth? And then when you look out to the future, where do you see a lot of opportunit
componenttext: Great. And then looking at import sales continues to nicely tick up as a percentage of total sales. What are some of the categories that are driving the majority of the growth? And then when you look out to the future, where do you see a lot of opportunities? What gets you excited about continuation of that penetration rate?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Over the last few years, we've really put a concerted effort into the -- into our exclusive brand program and product development. We've got a number of agents that we work with overseas, and the team and the merchandising team has done a very nice job bu
componenttext: Over the last few years, we've really put a concerted effort into the -- into our exclusive brand program and product development. We've got a number of agents that we work with overseas, and the team and the merchandising team has done a very nice job building our exclusive brands. If you look at some of the new things we've added, for example, we've got in the travel line a new lighting said for truck accessories. We've got GroundWork's that came in, which is our garden program. And there's a variety of things that we've been bringing in that customers seem to really respond to. So this continues to be a focus for us, and I believe that there's still a lot of runway ahead of us.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Christopher Horvers with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Christopher Horvers with JPMorgan.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I want to follow up on the spring pull forward a little bit. I mean, as you step back, weather overall sounded like it was probably neutral, considering how it played out for you on February as you look at the trend of the quarter. Is that fair? And if
componenttext: So I want to follow up on the spring pull forward a little bit. I mean, as you step back, weather overall sounded like it was probably neutral, considering how it played out for you on February as you look at the trend of the quarter. Is that fair? And if you just think about -- with what you're seeing in April and the -- what you saw in March, it was much more, okay, was warmer than last year but in the grand scheme of things, it arrived on a more on-time basis relative to the longer history of how seasonal sets up?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: When we look at the quarter, net-net, we would assess that weather was a positive because we had a relatively cold January, and then we had the early arrival of spring in March. So as much as February was a little bit warmer and sales a little bit softer.
componenttext: When we look at the quarter, net-net, we would assess that weather was a positive because we had a relatively cold January, and then we had the early arrival of spring in March. So as much as February was a little bit warmer and sales a little bit softer. Net-net, for the quarter, we felt very good about the weather trends. In our case, a lot has to do with how the weather relates to the prior year. And so when we make the comment that [indiscernible] was a much warmer March overall than in history, it was also much warmer than the prior year. So it does relate -- it does impact the timing of the sales. Now when we make an assessment as to what the pull forward is, we do our best to look at some of the key categories, and we look at sort of the slope of the sales line to try to understand if it was accelerated and try to project what that means to a quarter. But again, really from our business, it is best that we look at it by the half. And we have a lot of business left, and we'll probably be making a much better assessment as we move through the quarter and see how the first half comes out.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. Last quarter, there was a big discussion around Texas and the oil patch and also new store productivity with -- on the Analyst Day with some of the stores out West such as Utah. So can you talk about in terms of Texas stores and oil pat
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. Last quarter, there was a big discussion around Texas and the oil patch and also new store productivity with -- on the Analyst Day with some of the stores out West such as Utah. So can you talk about in terms of Texas stores and oil patch itself, did the gap widen or did the gap relative to the control group or however you want to say, actually stabilized at the level that you saw in the fourth quarter? And then can you talk about how you're seeing new store productivity in the stores out West?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. When it comes to the -- well, to the oil patch store, the first thing is the transaction count remained very firm. But the difference between those stores and our control group was very consistent with what we saw in Q4. So that did not change drama
componenttext: Sure. When it comes to the -- well, to the oil patch store, the first thing is the transaction count remained very firm. But the difference between those stores and our control group was very consistent with what we saw in Q4. So that did not change dramatically. But it is -- we did like the performance of the stores because they were all positive in their performance relative to the control group. And we continue to drive sales through those stores with the foot traffic that we're getting. So generally, what we see is that the ticket may be down because there's some very specific type items that are sold in those areas. But the day-to-day Basie transactions continue to occur and drive business in those stores.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Greg. As far as the Western stores, in respect to that new store performance, particularly Utah, we talked about the last call, yes, we're still building awareness in that market. And we have an executive trip that we make every quarter with the t
componenttext: This is Greg. As far as the Western stores, in respect to that new store performance, particularly Utah, we talked about the last call, yes, we're still building awareness in that market. And we have an executive trip that we make every quarter with the teams, and we chose this past quarter to make the trip out to the West. We were in Phoenix market, Utah markets, some other Western markets. And I must tell you, we feel very strongly that it's an awareness issue. And as we're seeing these stores ramp, we're feeling very good about our future prospects out there. It's about market awareness, it's about how we position. There's been some competition in those markets as we come into them that it takes a little longer. And I think we saw this a few years back when we were first entering the Florida market and the Louisiana market. So we're feeling good about it. I think the mix of our business out there is a little different than we have seen in other markets, but we are figuring that out. We're rebalancing some of the store inventories. And now with the Southwest DC in position, we can react to a lot faster. So we're feeling good actually about the West right now.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Adam Sindler with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Adam Sindler with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just real quickly on some of the -- just financials. Are you still looking at about $8.5 million for the DC for the year? I believe that's what you guided to and still about still very front half weighted.
componenttext: Just real quickly on some of the -- just financials. Are you still looking at about $8.5 million for the DC for the year? I believe that's what you guided to and still about still very front half weighted.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We had anticipated that, that would be the year-over-year drag that we would experience. So yes, pretty -- very much consistent with what we originally guided.
componenttext: We had anticipated that, that would be the year-over-year drag that we would experience. So yes, pretty -- very much consistent with what we originally guided.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just as we look at gross margins over the course of the year, could you remind us why again, the fourth quarter is having such a difficult compare despite sort of the relatively sort of in-line gross margin from last year?
componenttext: Great. And then just as we look at gross margins over the course of the year, could you remind us why again, the fourth quarter is having such a difficult compare despite sort of the relatively sort of in-line gross margin from last year?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Again, relative to the fourth quarter when we analyze it and we look at all the pluses and minuses, there's probably about 13 to 15 different impacts on that. And really, it's just a matter of looking at those and understanding what we'll be cycling
componenttext: Yes. Again, relative to the fourth quarter when we analyze it and we look at all the pluses and minuses, there's probably about 13 to 15 different impacts on that. And really, it's just a matter of looking at those and understanding what we'll be cycling against and where we see the tougher compares. And as much as it's difficult to break out all those pieces for you, it just turns out that the fourth quarter, we believe, would be one of the tougher compares.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just lastly, one thing you talked about is trying to keep on finding new products to introduce as you drive some of the in-caps and things like that. As you move more national, are there anything maybe a local product that you found that yo
componenttext: Okay. And then just lastly, one thing you talked about is trying to keep on finding new products to introduce as you drive some of the in-caps and things like that. As you move more national, are there anything maybe a local product that you found that you be able to bring back and take it more national, anything from just going out to the West just outside of just opening new stores there, maybe from a merchandising standpoint?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Adam, that's a great question. I mean, we're constantly in a test and learn mode. And whether it's local, whether it's testing in 25 stores, learning from it and rolling it forward, it's a constant pipeline of product that runs through the system and then
componenttext: Adam, that's a great question. I mean, we're constantly in a test and learn mode. And whether it's local, whether it's testing in 25 stores, learning from it and rolling it forward, it's a constant pipeline of product that runs through the system and then gets expanded. We do a monthly review of all those tests that we got going on. I'll use one example of a couple of years ago, we tested kayaks in 50 stores and sold pretty well exceeded our sell-through rate, then we expanded it to more stores. And this year, all stores have kayaks and we're continuing to see good momentum there. So I can't give you any one specific item, but I could tell you that, that pipeline is pretty full, and we're constantly reviewing the opportunity for further expansion of new merchandise.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just lastly on that, anything on the test? Is that in the stores yet or when will that hit?
componenttext: Great. And just lastly on that, anything on the test? Is that in the stores yet or when will that hit?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, actually, interesting you should ask. A couple of weeks ago, I guess maybe it was 1 week or 2 ago, we did roll forward with about 25 stores. Again, it's still in the very early stages. Stores are still setting the merchandise. And I suspect that on
componenttext: Well, actually, interesting you should ask. A couple of weeks ago, I guess maybe it was 1 week or 2 ago, we did roll forward with about 25 stores. Again, it's still in the very early stages. Stores are still setting the merchandise. And I suspect that on the next call, we'll be able to give you a better update.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Michael Lasser with UBS.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Michael Lasser with UBS.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Tony, on the $18 million [ph] should we expect that, that's going to all come out of the second quarter? So if we just look at it on last year, it's about 100 basis points to the comp. So should we model whatever our comp estimate was for this quarter,
componenttext: So Tony, on the $18 million [ph] should we expect that, that's going to all come out of the second quarter? So if we just look at it on last year, it's about 100 basis points to the comp. So should we model whatever our comp estimate was for this quarter, that we should essentially just take that down by 100 basis points?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, good question. When we look at it, there's that potential, but we really believe it's just too early to tell what the impact would -- should -- would be -- again, it's just an estimate. If you use that $18 million [ph] and you took it out of the
componenttext: Michael, good question. When we look at it, there's that potential, but we really believe it's just too early to tell what the impact would -- should -- would be -- again, it's just an estimate. If you use that $18 million [ph] and you took it out of the quarter, it would represent about a 1% change in the comp sales. But again, it's just our best estimate at the time and there's a lot of sales to be had. So it's too difficult to just make the assessment that all of it would come out of April.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And did you make any changes to your cost structure as such? Or it is what it is, we just don't [indiscernible]?
componenttext: And did you make any changes to your cost structure as such? Or it is what it is, we just don't [indiscernible]?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Obviously, we'll look at the variable expenses and the main driver would be your payroll. So we'll align our payroll with what we see the sales trends are relative to April as we move into May. And some of that is really more trending, more current tr
componenttext: No. Obviously, we'll look at the variable expenses and the main driver would be your payroll. So we'll align our payroll with what we see the sales trends are relative to April as we move into May. And some of that is really more trending, more current trending as we look at the sales in a particular period. But other than that, the expense structure, for the most part, would be intact.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then Greg, I just want to clarify your comments. When you talk about new store productivity, you referenced the western portion in the United States. We've seen previously that if there were any issue with new store productivity and the lack of brand
componenttext: And then Greg, I just want to clarify your comments. When you talk about new store productivity, you referenced the western portion in the United States. We've seen previously that if there were any issue with new store productivity and the lack of brand awareness, it was mostly around those stores in Utah. So is there something you have changed your viewpoint or is it mostly semantics?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, this -- overall, in aggregate, the new stores are performing very well and are performing at or above pro forma forecast. But in not just [indiscernible] Utah to say in a few places in the West, we have seen a little slower ramp but that's now beyond
componenttext: No, this -- overall, in aggregate, the new stores are performing very well and are performing at or above pro forma forecast. But in not just [indiscernible] Utah to say in a few places in the West, we have seen a little slower ramp but that's now beyond us, and we're now starting to see those stores perform to a level that is acceptable to us and kind of fits in with what we expected initially. So it's not just Utah, although it was a little bit of a slower start initially. We're learning. The West is a new market for us. We were in California and I think before we started expansion to the West, the furthest we were was probably Colorado. But a lot of room in between those particular states. But we're feeling very solid now that we have -- we understand those markets better. We've now been out there a little over a year of most of our store base. And I think we've -- there's no concerns for us going forward with the West.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would add Mike, that when we do our calculation in the store productivity, we did see an increase this quarter over Q4 last year.
componenttext: And I would add Mike, that when we do our calculation in the store productivity, we did see an increase this quarter over Q4 last year.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It was better than it was last year so as we calculated it, it's in the high 60s versus this quarter, 70% but that's still a little bit lower than it had been historically. So should we assume that as you add more stores out in the West and because you've
componenttext: It was better than it was last year so as we calculated it, it's in the high 60s versus this quarter, 70% but that's still a little bit lower than it had been historically. So should we assume that as you add more stores out in the West and because you've already got a base there, your brand awareness is better than new store productivity should improve over time, especially because I think you said in the past that the stores out West are actually a little bit more productive once they reach full maturity.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as we continue to grow out there in brand awareness, I think the thesis would be that it would take less time for us to gain market share as the brand becomes more aware and accepted out West.
componenttext: Yes, as we continue to grow out there in brand awareness, I think the thesis would be that it would take less time for us to gain market share as the brand becomes more aware and accepted out West.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Peter Keith with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Peter Keith with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was curious on some of the bigger ticket trends. It sounded like weather was both a positive and a negative. I guess just kind of looking forward here with some of the spring and summer merchandise with lawn mowers, how do you feel about that general de
componenttext: I was curious on some of the bigger ticket trends. It sounded like weather was both a positive and a negative. I guess just kind of looking forward here with some of the spring and summer merchandise with lawn mowers, how do you feel about that general demand and some of the category dynamics performing here for the next few quarters?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The big ticket itself, as Tony mentioned, we did see some benefit in Q1 in terms of plus numbers, mainly driven by riders as well as trailers. Some of that was a bit of a pull forward. We feel like we've got the right assortments out there. We've gone thr
componenttext: The big ticket itself, as Tony mentioned, we did see some benefit in Q1 in terms of plus numbers, mainly driven by riders as well as trailers. Some of that was a bit of a pull forward. We feel like we've got the right assortments out there. We've gone through, we've measured our assortments, we've reviewed our assortments. We are a needs-based retailer so if there's demand, I would tell you I feel pretty good about it. Tony said it's still early in the game here in Q2. And right now, it's hard to assess but I would tell you, we've got the right product out in our stores.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. My follow-up would just be on the gross margin expansion, which has obviously been observed us very good. Should we think about the margin expansion that you saw as sort of best of the year, given the what sounded like there was some kind of onetime
componenttext: Okay. My follow-up would just be on the gross margin expansion, which has obviously been observed us very good. Should we think about the margin expansion that you saw as sort of best of the year, given the what sounded like there was some kind of onetime vendor support from the DC and then maybe some benefits around that extended seasonal set?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll go ahead and start this one. This is Steve again. The one thing about gross margin specifically is that we got a plan, and it all starts there. We talked earlier about exclusive brands, product development, some of the import goods we got coming in.
componenttext: I'll go ahead and start this one. This is Steve again. The one thing about gross margin specifically is that we got a plan, and it all starts there. We talked earlier about exclusive brands, product development, some of the import goods we got coming in. We also -- our systems are much more scienced [ph] than our base price optimization, clearance price optimization. And so in Q1, there was a shift. Tony mentioned earlier that we did have some clearance coming out of Q4, but we were able to beat that with some regular price as well as some better support dollars. So what I would tell you is, is I feel good that we got a plan and the team's executing to it. And Tony, you have anything to add?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Peter, I highlighted the vendor support relative to the distribution center because that is more of a onetime issue. But when we look at the margin, we have a lot of real positives that occurred and obviously, Steve touched on. But the price management, t
componenttext: Peter, I highlighted the vendor support relative to the distribution center because that is more of a onetime issue. But when we look at the margin, we have a lot of real positives that occurred and obviously, Steve touched on. But the price management, the import, the exclusive brand were all very favorable this quarter. The fuel was positive. The way we managed promotions was much more favorable than the prior year, the way we cleared the merchandise. So net-net, as much as we've isolated that one item, I would agree with the original perception that it was a very strong margin quarter for us.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Seth Basham with Wedbush Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Seth Basham with Wedbush Securities.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I really want to talk about comps first, Tony. If we adjust out the $18 million from the 1Q results, on a 2-year stacked basis, you're still producing comps that are north of 9%. If we were to trend that out for the rest of the year, you'd be above your g
componenttext: I really want to talk about comps first, Tony. If we adjust out the $18 million from the 1Q results, on a 2-year stacked basis, you're still producing comps that are north of 9%. If we were to trend that out for the rest of the year, you'd be above your guidance range for the year. Is there a reason why on that adjusted basis, we should assume that 2-year stack comp should decelerate through the year?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: When we look at that, Steve and I are looking at each other, and I'm not sure if it's a matter of how we do our forecasting and maybe some of the concerted nature in the numbers. But we'll take a look at the seasons, we'll take a look at how we've develop
componenttext: When we look at that, Steve and I are looking at each other, and I'm not sure if it's a matter of how we do our forecasting and maybe some of the concerted nature in the numbers. But we'll take a look at the seasons, we'll take a look at how we've developed our product plans throughout the year. We'll look at the year-over-year. And in some cases, we may actually go 3 years deep to look at some of the comparisons. So our modeling is built from the bottom up. And so we think that as much as at times, it may be a little conservative, we think that as we started the year and we continue through the year, we think that it's a very reasonable guidance.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Seth, the only thing that I would add is that Q1 comparison was pretty challenging, and I think we feel really good about where we came in. Tony did mention there was some pull forward. Q2 is not going to be an easy quarter either. We had a good solid com
componenttext: Seth, the only thing that I would add is that Q1 comparison was pretty challenging, and I think we feel really good about where we came in. Tony did mention there was some pull forward. Q2 is not going to be an easy quarter either. We had a good solid comp last year favorable weather. So it's hard to look out and be able to forecast but I think we've got a pretty good plan in place.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you, fair enough. And then secondly, I was hoping you could touch a little bit more on your new store plans, where you opened geographically in the first quarter? Any differences in timing year-over-year? And then where you're trimming back as I think
componenttext: Got you, fair enough. And then secondly, I was hoping you could touch a little bit more on your new store plans, where you opened geographically in the first quarter? Any differences in timing year-over-year? And then where you're trimming back as I think you took your guidance down by up to 5 stores for the year.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The guidance for the full year was consistent with our original guidance. Again, we expect to open about 50% of the stores in the first half of the year and 50% obviously in the back half of the year. The only difference that we see this year is that a li
componenttext: The guidance for the full year was consistent with our original guidance. Again, we expect to open about 50% of the stores in the first half of the year and 50% obviously in the back half of the year. The only difference that we see this year is that a little bit less stores in the West. Our -- we had a very focused push over the last 2 years to get the number of stores, create a large base in the Southwest so that we could open the distribution centers and get -- center and get some of the economic benefit from that. So as we look at it this year, we see a few less stores in the West. We were running about 35% to 40%. We expect to be a little bit more in say, the 25% range when it comes to the Western stores. And additionally, we anticipate opening a few more second-use real estate versus build-to-suit locations. And that would mean some additional capital, probably in maybe the $5 million to $10 million range. But that -- those are the only 2 differences that we see as we move through the new store opening plan.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And one last follow-up, if I may. Greg, you mentioned that you learned a lot in the West and you're approaching your openings out there differently. Can you provide any color about what you're doing differently? That would be helpful.
componenttext: Got it. And one last follow-up, if I may. Greg, you mentioned that you learned a lot in the West and you're approaching your openings out there differently. Can you provide any color about what you're doing differently? That would be helpful.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll make it short. I think we have to keep our foot down on the pedal when it comes to marketing to make sure that we stay with these stores a little longer. There are a couple of things that are unique in some of these markets from a merch standpoint th
componenttext: I'll make it short. I think we have to keep our foot down on the pedal when it comes to marketing to make sure that we stay with these stores a little longer. There are a couple of things that are unique in some of these markets from a merch standpoint that we've learned and we've addressed that now. And I think we've become very good listeners to our teams out there. And what we're doing from a local market presence and that could be interacting with local rodeos, with different 4-H and FFA groups. So there's a heightened, what I would call, awareness out there, we are now versus our initial approach. And it's a little different than maybe what we've done in some of the markets where we have an existing presence. It's not overbearing but those learnings were applied.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question from Stephen Tanal from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question from Stephen Tanal from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you could just size the impact of freight or transport to gross margin. I know you've done that in the past. I'm just sort of curious there if you can help with that.
componenttext: If you could just size the impact of freight or transport to gross margin. I know you've done that in the past. I'm just sort of curious there if you can help with that.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can give you a general idea. I try not to break all the components down into basis points because there are so many factors that are attributed to the freight line and gross margin. So the ones that I identified as having an impact are somewhat min
componenttext: Yes, I can give you a general idea. I try not to break all the components down into basis points because there are so many factors that are attributed to the freight line and gross margin. So the ones that I identified as having an impact are somewhat minimal impact. They were generally in the same range and generally would be less than 10 basis points of impact to the gross margin line.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, okay. I guess if I think about it, it sounds like the inbound maybe getting a little bit worse than what the color that we got last quarter. Do you think that's a fair read? And separately, do you think you can start to leverage that line at some
componenttext: Got it, okay. I guess if I think about it, it sounds like the inbound maybe getting a little bit worse than what the color that we got last quarter. Do you think that's a fair read? And separately, do you think you can start to leverage that line at some point this year, even if oil prices start to move in the other direction?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: When we look out, we would expect to see a similar impact in Q2. And we would expect that to start to moderate as we move through the year and start to get the benefits of the distribution center and moving some of our vendors to Western ship points. So w
componenttext: When we look out, we would expect to see a similar impact in Q2. And we would expect that to start to moderate as we move through the year and start to get the benefits of the distribution center and moving some of our vendors to Western ship points. So we expect it to start to moderate as we move through the year. But net-net for the year, we expect it to be just a slight drag on margins.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, okay. That's helpful. And just lastly, if you could just tell us on the seasonal reset, it sounds like maybe there's another change year-on-year positive benefit in maybe 3Q, 4Q. What do you think that timing looks like
componenttext: Got it, okay. That's helpful. And just lastly, if you could just tell us on the seasonal reset, it sounds like maybe there's another change year-on-year positive benefit in maybe 3Q, 4Q. What do you think that timing looks like

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm not specifically sure. I -- can you repeat the question?
componenttext: Yes, I'm not specifically sure. I -- can you repeat the question?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Going from 3 to 5 seasonal resets, is there another change upcoming in this year and which quarter does that affect?
componenttext: Yes. Going from 3 to 5 seasonal resets, is there another change upcoming in this year and which quarter does that affect?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Earlier, I think I've mentioned that in Q1, we were able to do that. We went from 3 waves in 2 weeks to 5 waves in 8. Next in the fall, we're going to keep a very consistent program we've done traditionally. I think we're much more accurate then. So there
componenttext: Earlier, I think I've mentioned that in Q1, we were able to do that. We went from 3 waves in 2 weeks to 5 waves in 8. Next in the fall, we're going to keep a very consistent program we've done traditionally. I think we're much more accurate then. So there won't be a change in the fall.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Dan Wewer with Raymond James.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Dan Wewer with Raymond James.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, I want to follow-up on your comment about the benefits from Revionics. Are you continuing to get benefits from the initial markup module? Or are most of the current benefits coming from markdown management?
componenttext: Greg, I want to follow-up on your comment about the benefits from Revionics. Are you continuing to get benefits from the initial markup module? Or are most of the current benefits coming from markdown management?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, we're in 2 modules right now, regular price and clearance. So we kind of covered both sides. We haven't turned on promotional yet. And it's not all about markup. It's actually a combination of can we find margin or can we find -- can we drive sales?
componenttext: Dan, we're in 2 modules right now, regular price and clearance. So we kind of covered both sides. We haven't turned on promotional yet. And it's not all about markup. It's actually a combination of can we find margin or can we find -- can we drive sales? And so once you turn price optimization on, it is an ever moving and living increasing process. And when we move into different markets, we're going to try, test different price elasticity. So you're correct, you'll see some improvement on markdown or clearance on that side. We're seeing some improvements in our regular price pricing and how we can stay competitive in markets. And it's really we needed the system because in all the different pricing strategies we've got throughout the country. We're in 49 states. We're not a single regular price on everything in every state being the same. So that was another reason why we put the system in.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you think about the promotional pricing module that's available, are you committed to making that investment? And how will the payback on that compare to the first 2 applications?
componenttext: When you think about the promotional pricing module that's available, are you committed to making that investment? And how will the payback on that compare to the first 2 applications?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: At this point in time, we have not made a decision that we would move forward with a promotional pricing module. We're still working through the first 2. If we do make that decision, Dan, you can bet that we're going to see some type of return on investme
componenttext: At this point in time, we have not made a decision that we would move forward with a promotional pricing module. We're still working through the first 2. If we do make that decision, Dan, you can bet that we're going to see some type of return on investment than we would into it.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then Tony, just a follow-up, I guess, more on the sales pull forward comment. Are you seeing anything in the results in April that would confirm that you moved some revenues from April into March?
componenttext: And then Tony, just a follow-up, I guess, more on the sales pull forward comment. Are you seeing anything in the results in April that would confirm that you moved some revenues from April into March?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: There could be some potential. And again, that goes into our calculation and estimate of the $18 million. Obviously again, a little bit difficult assessment because as we moved into April, the weather was a little cooler so there was an impact there. So w
componenttext: There could be some potential. And again, that goes into our calculation and estimate of the $18 million. Obviously again, a little bit difficult assessment because as we moved into April, the weather was a little cooler so there was an impact there. So we're constantly assessing as we move through the quarter. But obviously as this warm weather has moved in, we're really optimistic about the May and June timeframe and our spring assortment.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our next question from Chuck Cerankosky with Northcoast Research.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our next question from Chuck Cerankosky with Northcoast Research.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you talk a little bit about how some of the markdown discipline you took in the fourth quarter set you up for the first quarter? And how you make sure inventories weren't too low going into the first quarter especially the seasonal merchandise?
componenttext: Could you talk a little bit about how some of the markdown discipline you took in the fourth quarter set you up for the first quarter? And how you make sure inventories weren't too low going into the first quarter especially the seasonal merchandise?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chuck, this is Steve Barbarick. There's 2 types of seasonal merchandise. There's product that we bought for Christmas that is not necessarily cold product-related, and we sold through that really well. It was a more seasonal clearance that we ended up car
componenttext: Chuck, this is Steve Barbarick. There's 2 types of seasonal merchandise. There's product that we bought for Christmas that is not necessarily cold product-related, and we sold through that really well. It was a more seasonal clearance that we ended up carrying over. And I believe at the last call, we talked about the percentage that we carried over. A lot of retailers would have probably taken markdowns a lot quicker and panicked, to some degree. But a lot of the product that we have are whole goods that are pretty much standby year-to-year. And we took a very disciplined approach. We didn't panic in Q4. We took methodical markdowns where we could. We do have a clearance price optimization tool that looks specifically at clearance by individual location so we can cluster those type of products. When the got into the first quarter, we had the benefit of that winter. Colder weather hit us in January. And we had enough of merchandise up North, knowing that we went to this 5 waves of allocation and it really paid off for us. Now we still are tearing some of that inventory over. I don't want to say that we sold completely through, but it's good inventory that we can bring out for next year. And the carryover is minimal compared to the total inventory investment that we have out there today. So the team did a really nice job. I think it was a disciplined approach. We used both art and science based on some of what we were looking at and we came out of it really well.

I would tell you where you would see the biggest and most significant impact is really more in the seasonal, some of the power equipment and things like that. So where we would have set stores probably in your area in early February, those stores would have been set a little bit later up North toward the end of February. And the Southern stores really benefited because they actually got product 2 weeks earlier than what they traditionally would have gotten products. So as Greg said earlier, we were able to capitalize on an earlier spring in the South and keep some of that colder-related merchandise out on the floor through really the month of February and start setting spring at that point.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Happy to do it, Joe. We're in, as you mentioned, 140 stores. We've got about 6 months now of learning. And what I would tell you is that the opt-in rate by our consumers have actually exceeded our original expectations. We knew that we had a fairly loyal
componenttext: Happy to do it, Joe. We're in, as you mentioned, 140 stores. We've got about 6 months now of learning. And what I would tell you is that the opt-in rate by our consumers have actually exceeded our original expectations. We knew that we had a fairly loyal customer, and it wasn't really until we had a program out there that we realized that they were very interested and willing to hear from us and being part of the program. In the stores that we've added in, we've seen nice attribution increases in understanding how our customers and getting a deeper knowledge. I'll just give you a couple of examples. In the stores where we've got the neighbor school program from a transaction standpoint, we've met one from really about mid-30s to mid-50s. So we've seen a nice increase in transaction attribution and in sales attribution, that number has gone from the low 50s to the mid-60s. We are using that data now because the goal of this was to collect information and start personalizing communication out to them using e-mail. And we've been doing just that. We've got now a record of the response rates from our customers and the communication back and forth regarding content our special offers or trying to get them to shop across the stores. So we are very enthusiastic about the program. And at this point, we are looking forward, next steps. We don't yet -- we're not prepared to make a comment as to where we're going to roll or how many stores we will get it, but we are optimistic that this is something that's going to add value.

componenttext: Well, I won't get into specifics, Joe, but I would tell you, Greg mentioned it earlier. Our customers index very high when it comes to animal ownership. And that includes dogs and cats as well. And we go through a pretty rigorous category management review of the pet aisle, supplies, treats as well as pet food every year and in some cases, twice a year. We are seeing growth. We've got -- we look at 3 different segments. We look at the grocery segment, we look at the segment we look at the premium -- superpremium segment. And I would tell you we're seeing growth in all 3 of those segments. We put a lot of our real estate as well as some of our marketing into the superpremium side of the business and our investments. And we think we're getting a very nice payoff. Customers are responding favorably and I think that's one of the things that may be growing our transaction count. We talked a lot about Q needs and this will be a good example of that.

componenttext:
Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Tractor Supply Company's conference call to discuss first quarter 2016 results. [Operator Instructions] .
Please be advised that reproduction of this call in whole or in part is not permitted without written authorization of Tractor Supply Company. And as a reminder, this call is being recorded. 
I would now like to introduce your host for today's call, Ms. Christine Skold of Tractor Supply Company. Christine, please go ahead.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for Tractor Supply Company's quarterly earnings conference call. Before we begin, let me reference the Safe Harbor provisions under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. T
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for Tractor Supply Company's quarterly earnings conference call. 
Before we begin, let me reference the Safe Harbor provisions under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. This call may contain forward-looking statements that are subject to significant risks and uncertainties, including the future operating and financial performance of the company. Although the company believes the expectations reflected in its forward-looking statements are reasonable, it can give no assurance that such expectations or any of its forward-looking statements will prove to be correct. 
Important risk factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those reflected in the forward-looking statements are included in the company filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
The information contained in this call is accurate only as of the date discussed. Investors should not assume that statements will remain operative at a later time. 
Lastly, Tractor Supply Company undertakes no obligation to update any information discussed in the call. 
I'm now pleased to introduce Greg Sandfort, Tractor Supply Company's President and Chief Executive Officer. Greg, please go ahead.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. On the call with me today are Tony Crudele, our EVP and Chief Financial Officer; and Steve Barbarick, our EVP and Chief Merchandising, Marketing and Supply Chain Officer. We are pleased with our re
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. On the call with me today are Tony Crudele, our EVP and Chief Financial Officer; and Steve Barbarick, our EVP and Chief Merchandising, Marketing and Supply Chain Officer. 
We are pleased with our results and execution of our business in the first quarter. Comparable store sales increased 4.9% and were driven by increases in both traffic and ticket. This was our 32nd consecutive quarter of positive comparable transaction counts. Our sales were balanced across product categories and regions, with all of our major product categories and geographic regions generating positive comparable store sales. Once again, the Tractor Supply team did an excellent job managing the business this quarter, and we believe our results demonstrate the resiliency of our business model.
Our customers rely on us to be the most dependable supplier of everyday basic products for their rural lifestyle needs. They shop our stores regularly, and they buy what they need when they need it, for their pets, animals, land and equipment. Some of their needs are year-round, some are seasonal, and some are weather related. We know the seasons and weather can influence the timing of when our customers shop certain products, and we also know it's our job to manage our inventory accordingly. 
One change that we implemented in the first quarter of this year was the flow of our seasonal inventory into our stores. Last year, we had 3 regional set dates for spring merchandise, which ranged from mid-January through early February. Acting on feedback from our store managers and analyzing sales and the inventory data, we changed our approach for 2016 and moved to 5 set dates this year, starting with the South in late December and ending with the North in late February, early March. This allowed us to capture early spring sales in the South and additional late winter sales in the North. Combining this with our clearance pricing tool from Revionics, we were able to drive sales, preserve margin and reduce inventory levels as we transitioned our business during the first quarter.
This quarter, we did have a little help from mother nature. And we had the right products in stock to meet our customers' needs in both seasonal and everyday queue products. When the snow and cold finally arrived in many of our markets in January, we had the inventory to meet those customer needs, and we sold through a good portion of our winter seasonal merchandise. 
Similarly, when spring-like conditions developed in a number of our southern markets in March, we were again ready, and our continued investments in everyday queue products kept us positioned to drive this segment of our business throughout the quarter as well. As a result, we experienced solid sales across both everyday and seasonal products for the quarter.
This year's Chick Days event, which was another success, generating strong traffic, driving sales and growing awareness regarding backyard poultry across a wide range of customers. The event features live chicks and ducklings, along with all the necessary products for their care and maintenance. This is one of our most popular events of the year and positions Tractor Supply as an authority in the areas of animal care and sustainable living. It speaks to the self reliance and sustainability trend that we continue to see in our marketplace and is a great example of how we are appealing to a wider consumer base.
As we discussed briefly at our Investment Community Day in February, we have identified broad consumer trends around 4 areas of our business, those being pets, services, my land and sustainable living. We believe these are go-forward areas of opportunity for Tractor Supply, and we are developing and testing strategies for products and events that will address these trends.
Another area of growing importance is the application of technology into our business, including systems involving inventory management, allocation, customer information capture and mobile. We continue to improve our processes to better manage inventory, enhance our assortments and grow the business longer term. 
One example is our new planogram facility, which we call our Merchandise Innovation Center, (sic) [Merchandising Innovation Center] or MIC. This facility enables our teams and vendors to work in a simulated store environment as we plan changes through assortment mix, in-store visuals and overall flow changes within the 4-wall store. 
In addition to the MIC, enhancements across our planning and allocation systems are important tools that we are utilizing to improve our business to meet the ever-evolving needs of our customers. 
And as we look ahead to the remainder of 2016, we will continue to enhance our omnichannel platform, customer relationship marketing and our IT security across the entire organization. We're also in the process of implementing the EMV chip-and-signature platform in our stores, with completion expected by mid of this year.
On the merchandising side, our focus will continue to be on new and differentiated products across the store as well as opportunities to expand our offerings and exclusive brands, always being mindful of the positioning for the key national brands that our customers expect to find within our assortments.
On the store operations side of our business, we are improving our in-store special ordering process and making it easier for our team members to assist customers in locating hard-to-find products, to expanded product offerings, utilizing our Drop Ship Vendors. 
And we are embarking on the largest store sustainability project to date with the retrofitting of the entire store base with new LED lighting in 2016 and 2017. Thus far, we have converted 1/3 of our stores planned for 2016 with LED lighting, and those stores are benefiting from improved lighting quality as well as lower energy and maintenance costs. 
So in closing, let me extend my sincere thanks to all of the hard-working dedicated team members of Tractor Supply. And it is really our people who serve our customers everyday and execute our business strategies that drive our continued success as a company.
With that said, I'd like to turn the call over to Tony now for a more detailed commentary on our first quarter results and our outlook for 2016. Tony?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg, and good afternoon, everyone. For the quarter ended March 26, 2016, on a year-over-year basis, net sales increased 10.2% to $1.47 billion, net income increased 16.6% to $66.7 million, and EPS increased 19% to $0.50 per diluted share. Comp
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg, and good afternoon, everyone. For the quarter ended March 26, 2016, on a year-over-year basis, net sales increased 10.2% to $1.47 billion, net income increased 16.6% to $66.7 million, and EPS increased 19% to $0.50 per diluted share. 
Comp store sales increased 4.9% in the first quarter compared to an increase of 5.7% in last year's first quarter. Comp transaction count increased for the 32nd consecutive quarter, gaining 4.2% on top of a 4.8% increase last year. 
As Greg mentioned, sales trends were broad-based, both from a product and a geographic perspective. Everyday items continued to perform well and were a key driver of the comp transaction increase. 
Average comp ticket increased by 73 basis points on top of last year's 84 basis point increase. The increase was driven principally by an increase in the number of SKUs per transaction, partially offset by deflation.
Sale of spring seasonal merchandise were also strong in the quarter as we experienced a March that was warmer than average and also warmer than last year. Spring seasonal categories, such as lawn and garden, riding lawn mowers, fencing, animal health and fly control performed very well. 
Winter seasonal sales were strong in January as the cold weather rolled in, but sales softened in February, which was much warmer than last year. Cold weather in January gave us the opportunity to clear most of our winter clothing, specifically insulated outerwear. However, the cold weather was too brief to drive significant sales in certain hardline categories such as heating and log splitters. 
Other comments regarding sales in the quarter. Comp sales were positive across all regions and major product categories, with the strongest sales coming in the Southeast, which was impacted less by the mild winter season. 
Big-ticket comp sales increased slightly, but below chain average and were driven by early spring season, riding lawn mower and trailer sales, partially offset by soft sales in winter power equipment and log splitters. 
Transactions drove the increase in the big-ticket comps, but overall, the increase in big-ticket did not materially impact overall company comps. 
We estimate that deflation impacted sales by approximately 25 basis points, driven principally by livestock feed, lubricant and propane categories. 
As I mentioned, mild March temperatures benefited the sale of early spring merchandise. Also, Easter was 1 week earlier than last year, thereby shifting the strong Friday and Saturday sales days into our first quarter. We estimate that these 2 factors positively impacted first quarter results by pulling forward approximately $18 million in sales and $0.02 per diluted share.
The oil patch stores continued to comp positive but below chain average, consistent with the trend in Q4. Transaction count remained firm in these stores. We are expecting that the impact will moderate through the year as we begin to cycle the trend from last year. 
Now turning to gross margin, which increased 30 basis points to 33.7% versus a decrease of 8 basis points last year. The merchandise team did a great job driving gross margin while managing through our winter seasonal clearance. We benefited from our key margin initiatives of price management, imports and exclusive brands. The benefit of these initiatives more than offset the impact from heavier clearance sales of winter seasonal merchandise. 
The merchandise team continues to work diligently with our vendor community on both the product development and cost sides of the business, which is improving margin. We also benefited from vendor support programs associated with the initial stocking of our new Arizona DC. 
While we loaded the DC with inventory late last year, we began shipping to stores in late December and recognizing the benefit as we sold through the merchandise in Q1. We estimate this positively impacted gross margin by approximately 15 basis points. 
We estimate that deflation had a minimal impact on gross margin as deflation continued to decline in the feed category. 
Lower diesel prices and the decrease in outbound stem miles to our Western stores were more than offset by an increase in inbound miles to our Arizona DC and a higher mix of freight-intensive categories. The mix of merchandise had a slight negative impact in gross margin. Higher sales of riding lawn mowers were offset by lower sales of heating products, both of which carried below chain average margins. 
For the quarter, SG&A, including depreciation and amortization, was 26.3% of sales, an improvement of 11 basis points over the prior year's quarter. Overall, SG&A benefited from a strong comp sales increase. However, we are very pleased with the expense control and leverage that we achieved, given that we had an estimated headwind of $3.5 million or approximately 24 basis points from the startup of our Arizona DC and the 2 mixing centers that were not in operation last year at this time.
We are very pleased with our payroll management in Q1 as the team reacted well and allocated payroll appropriately with the sales trends, resulting in leverage in the quarter. Medical and related payroll expenses levered as well. We also leveraged occupancy as we benefited from lower utilities and store winter maintenance expense as a result of the mild winter weather. This benefit was partially offset by the rental leverage that we experienced as we opened new stores. 
Incentive compensation did not have a material impact on SG&A in this quarter. 
The tax rate for the quarter was 36.8% compared to 36.9% last year due to additional state tax credits. Both periods include onetime state tax credits that we do not anticipate receiving at the same level in subsequent years.
Now turning to the balance sheet. At the end of Q1, we had a cash balance of $74.5 million and $230 million in outstanding debt compared to cash balance of $57 million and $60 million in outstanding debt last year. 
During the first quarter, under our stock repurchase program, we acquired close to 1.2 million shares for $99.1 million. 
Inventory per store increased 1%, and annualized inventory turns decreased to 2.94. We had anticipated that turns would decrease in Q1 as we began the quarter heavy with winter seasonal merchandise as well as stocking our new Arizona DC. 
We are pleased how the team managed the markdown cadence and inventory purchases, bringing the quarter-end balances down essentially to last year's levels. We believe we're well positioned as we head into the second quarter.
Capital expenditures for the quarter were $36.7 million compared to $48.8 million last year. 
We opened 36 stores and closed 3 Del's stores in the first quarter compared to 41 new stores opened and 1 Del's store closed in the first quarter of 2015. 
So with respect to our financial expectations for the full year 2016, as noted in today's press release, we have reiterated our previous guidance. 
While our Q1 performance was strong, there's still a lot of business ahead of us in the spring and summer season. As we have said in the past, it is best to evaluate our performance by the half as we see the spring season play out in full. Therefore, we believe it's prudent to revisit our guidance at the end of the second quarter.
As a reminder, we expect full year sales to range from $6.9 billion to $7 billion. We have forecasted comp sales to range between 3.5% and 5%. We are targeting a 20 to 25 basis point improvement in EBIT margin compared to 2015. We anticipate net income to range from approximately $455 million to $467 million or $3.40 to $3.48 per diluted share. We expect to open between 115 to 120 new stores, with approximately 50% scheduled to be opened in the first half of the year. Additionally, we forecast our effective tax rate will be approximately 36.9%.
While we still expect capital expenditures in 2016 to range between $230 million to $250 million, and we're making good progress on our LED lighting retrofit, expect to be completing this year's target of half of the chain by mid-third quarter. 
We'll continue to make purchases on the share repurchase program as part of our long-term balanced approach to shareholder return. We expect to be in a borrowed position at the end of each quarter, and target year-end debt position to be approximately $200 million. We continue to expect deflation to be less of a headwind, ranging between 20 basis points early in the year and flat in the second half of the year. 
So that concludes our prepared remarks. Operator, we will now turn the call over for questions.

componenttext: Seth, this is Steve Barbarick. I would tell you, it's really hard to quantify that specifically. As Greg mentioned, in years past, we had 3 waves over 2 weeks. This year, we went to 5 waves over 8 weeks. Our planning department and our inventory teams have really matured to a level where we're able to do this, and we've got the technology now to do it. I would tell you what we experienced in Q1 was quite favorable for us, and that's something we'll do going forward. In the back half of the year, I think we've got a pretty good plan. We made some adjustments in years past, and I don't see us making a lot of changes for the fall.

I think you said Q1 was going to be the most difficult year to get leverage. Obviously, Q1's SG&A leverage was pretty good. Tony, are you finding other opportunities here? headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: When we look at it, we obviously have a lot of initiatives that we have in place try to drive costs out of SG&A. However, as we indicated in the first conference call, as we look out over the year, we do anticipate SG&A being somewhat flattish to potentia
componenttext: When we look at it, we obviously have a lot of initiatives that we have in place try to drive costs out of SG&A. However, as we indicated in the first conference call, as we look out over the year, we do anticipate SG&A being somewhat flattish to potentially negative. And that should moderate some as we move through the year as we start to cycle against the Arizona distribution center and the mixing centers. And again, I remind you that probably the fourth quarter, we have the best potential to leverage SG&A because we have the additional sales week of the 53rd week.
