componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then Tony, just with the debt that's on the balance sheet now and you gave kind of the year-end target, what are you thinking in terms of interest expense for the year? And then longer term, how should we think about your appetit
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then Tony, just with the debt that's on the balance sheet now and you gave kind of the year-end target, what are you thinking in terms of interest expense for the year? And then longer term, how should we think about your appetite to add leverage to this model as we go forward?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Obviously, we anticipate interest expense to increase, but not dramatically because as much as we anticipate having outstanding balances at the end of each quarter, there are periods where we have obviously the strong sales as we move through spring
componenttext: Sure. Obviously, we anticipate interest expense to increase, but not dramatically because as much as we anticipate having outstanding balances at the end of each quarter, there are periods where we have obviously the strong sales as we move through spring where we would not be in the borrowed position. So we don't see it being a significant increase relative to an appetite. I think that one of the biggest drivers is the share repurchase program, and so that would be a driver. And again, given how we set up the program using the matrix and how the stock price moves dictate how much we attribute to that program, and that would drive some of the outstanding debt on the balance sheet. So I think we clearly would like to support the stock and continue to do so. But we have a lot of flexibility when it comes to the capital structure because of the repurchase program.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Simeon Gutman with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Simeon Gutman with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Joshua Siber on for Simeon. Can you parse out the $18 million sales difference between the Eastern impact and the warm weather impact?
componenttext: This is Joshua Siber on for Simeon. Can you parse out the $18 million sales difference between the Eastern impact and the warm weather impact?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Joshua, this is Tony. A little difficult to do, and I would tell you, it's really our best estimate this time. And until we see how the full season plays out, it really is just that, is an estimate. Again, hard to quantify. If I gave you my best thought o
componenttext: Joshua, this is Tony. A little difficult to do, and I would tell you, it's really our best estimate this time. And until we see how the full season plays out, it really is just that, is an estimate. Again, hard to quantify. If I gave you my best thought on it, it'd probably be 1/3 Eastern and the other 1/2 would be considered the pull forward. But again, it's really a combination of the 2, so we really prefer not to parse it out.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. My follow-up then is in the Southeast or in geographies where weather was more consistent with the norm, can you talk about what the trends look like there? Were the months evenly spread out or did March accelerate?
componenttext: Sure. My follow-up then is in the Southeast or in geographies where weather was more consistent with the norm, can you talk about what the trends look like there? Were the months evenly spread out or did March accelerate?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: When we look at the geographic distribution, the strongest, as I had mentioned on the call, was the Southeast. And that was -- that area was a little bit more smooth throughout the 3 months. But for the most part, as I had indicated, January strong, Febru
componenttext: When we look at the geographic distribution, the strongest, as I had mentioned on the call, was the Southeast. And that was -- that area was a little bit more smooth throughout the 3 months. But for the most part, as I had indicated, January strong, February a little bit softer, and then obviously some strength in March itself. But in all cases, all 3 months were positive, and I want to say pretty much throughout all geographic locations throughout the quarter.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Jessica Mace with Nomura Securities.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Jessica Mace with Nomura Securities.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question is about the health of the consumer. On your last call, you made some comments about seeing some caution amongst consumers. And I was just wonder if on the other side of the first quarter, you have any updates or any changes you've notic
componenttext: My first question is about the health of the consumer. On your last call, you made some comments about seeing some caution amongst consumers. And I was just wonder if on the other side of the first quarter, you have any updates or any changes you've noticed in that behavior.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jessica, this is Tony. I'll answer that since I have such a handle on the consumers themselves. But I would tell you that, really, our outlook hasn't changed. We are a basic need company and people are coming to us for their everyday needs. And that is re
componenttext: Jessica, this is Tony. I'll answer that since I have such a handle on the consumers themselves. But I would tell you that, really, our outlook hasn't changed. We are a basic need company and people are coming to us for their everyday needs. And that is really the consistency of our business model. As we talked about, big-ticket, relatively consistent, and again, consistent with chain average for the most part in the quarter. So again, we have a resilient model because of the basic needs and supporting that of the rural lifestyle. And we did not see any significant changes in the consumer patterns throughout the quarter.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you. And then my second question is on the transportation cost. I just -- was wondering if you could review some of the moving pieces a little bit, what you get a benefit from as a result of the Southwest distribution center. And then on some
componenttext: Okay, thank you. And then my second question is on the transportation cost. I just -- was wondering if you could review some of the moving pieces a little bit, what you get a benefit from as a result of the Southwest distribution center. And then on some of the inbound freight costs, what the outlook is for those for the rest of the year.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly. When it comes to the transportation costs, the key to the Arizona distribution center is that obviously, we're reducing the outbound stem miles to the store. And we're very successful there, and we saw a reduction in those transportation costs.
componenttext: Certainly. When it comes to the transportation costs, the key to the Arizona distribution center is that obviously, we're reducing the outbound stem miles to the store. And we're very successful there, and we saw a reduction in those transportation costs. But obviously, the inbound from many of our Eastern-based vendors, the inbound miles increased substantially as well. So the key to the program go forward is to make sure that we have either additional facilities of the Eastern vendor base and they open up additional facilities out West and/or we bring on Western-based vendors. So when -- but the key to the distribution center really is, as we move forward, and then the stores that we open in the West now will not have that deleveraging impact that we experienced as we had that accelerated growth out West. So as we bring on new stores out West, they'll be less impactful to our transportation costs. And that's really the key benefit to the Arizona distribution center.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Ben Bienvenu with Stephens.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Ben Bienvenu with Stephens.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just looking at the ticket, the improvement there, you spoke to the basket getting bigger. What are some of the areas where you're seeing product merchandise resonate with customers to drive this? And how sustainable do you think this trend is going forwa
componenttext: Just looking at the ticket, the improvement there, you spoke to the basket getting bigger. What are some of the areas where you're seeing product merchandise resonate with customers to drive this? And how sustainable do you think this trend is going forward?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ben, Steve Barbarick here. What I would tell you is, we've got a number of different levers to drive sales, and one of those is drive aisle. And that's the End Caps, the power panels, clip strips and the Center Court. Greg referenced Chick Days earlier in
componenttext: Ben, Steve Barbarick here. What I would tell you is, we've got a number of different levers to drive sales, and one of those is drive aisle. And that's the End Caps, the power panels, clip strips and the Center Court. Greg referenced Chick Days earlier in his canned remarks. And we also had a garden event that took place in the center court. And we're seeing really good movement in both of those events as well as getting behind and working with our vendors on our End Cap programs. So that's really what helped to drive some of the increase in the basket. In terms of sustainability, this is a focus for us. And it's something we're getting better at. And I would hate to tell you that -- or I wouldn't want to suggest that this is sustainable and every quarter we're going to sit here and talk about the gains. But I can tell you, we're making a concerted effort to put in front of the customers those impulse buys as they shop our stores for needs-based products.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then looking at import sales, continues to nicely tick up as a percentage of total sales. What are some of the categories that are driving the majority of the growth? And then, when you look out to the future, where do you see a lot of opportun
componenttext: Great. And then looking at import sales, continues to nicely tick up as a percentage of total sales. What are some of the categories that are driving the majority of the growth? And then, when you look out to the future, where do you see a lot of opportunities? What gets you excited about continuation of that penetration rate?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Over the last few years, we've really put a concerted effort into the -- into our exclusive brand program and product development. We've got a number of agents that we work with overseas, and the team -- and the merchandising team has done a very nice job
componenttext: Over the last few years, we've really put a concerted effort into the -- into our exclusive brand program and product development. We've got a number of agents that we work with overseas, and the team -- and the merchandising team has done a very nice job building our exclusive brands. If you look at some of the new things we've added, for example, we've got in the travel line, a new lighting set for truck accessories. We've got GroundWorks (sic) [GroundWork] that came in, which is our garden program. And there's a variety of things that we've been bringing in that customers seem to really respond to. So this continues to be a focus for us, and I believe that there's still a lot of runway ahead of us.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Christopher Horvers with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Christopher Horvers with JPMorgan.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I wanted to follow up on the spring pull forward a little bit. I mean, as you step back, I mean, weather overall sounded like it was probably neutral, considering how it played out for you on February as you look at the trend of the quarter. Is that fa
componenttext: So I wanted to follow up on the spring pull forward a little bit. I mean, as you step back, I mean, weather overall sounded like it was probably neutral, considering how it played out for you on February as you look at the trend of the quarter. Is that fair? And if you just think about -- with what you're seeing in April and the -- what you saw in March, it -- was March more -- okay, was warmer than last year, but in the grand scheme of things, it arrived on a more on-time basis relative to the longer history of how seasonal sets up?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: When we look at the quarter, net-net, we would assess that weather was a positive because we had a relatively cold January, and then we had the early arrival of spring in March. So as much as February was a little bit warmer and sales were a little bit so
componenttext: When we look at the quarter, net-net, we would assess that weather was a positive because we had a relatively cold January, and then we had the early arrival of spring in March. So as much as February was a little bit warmer and sales were a little bit softer. Net-net, for the quarter, we felt very good about the weather trends. In our case, a lot has to do with how the weather relates to the prior year. And so when we make the comment that one, it was a much warmer March overall than in history, it was also much warmer than the prior year. So it does relate -- it does impact the timing of the sales. Now when we make an assessment as to what the pull forward is, we do our best to look at some of the key categories, and we look at sort of the slope of the sales line to try to understand if it was accelerated and try to project what that means to a quarter. But again, really, for our business, it is best that we look at it by the half. And we have a lot of business left, and we'll probably be -- make a much better assessment as we move through the quarter and see how the first half comes out.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. Last quarter, there was a big discussion around Texas and the oil patch and also new store productivity with -- on the Analyst Day with some of the stores out West, such as Utah. So can you talk about in terms of Texas stores and the oi
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. Last quarter, there was a big discussion around Texas and the oil patch and also new store productivity with -- on the Analyst Day with some of the stores out West, such as Utah. So can you talk about in terms of Texas stores and the oil patch itself, did the gap widen? Or did the gap, relative to the control group or however you want to say it, actually stabilize at the level that you saw in the fourth quarter? And then can you talk about how you're seeing new store productivity in the stores out West?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. When it comes to the -- well, referring to the oil patch store, the first thing is the transaction count remained very firm. But the difference between those stores and our control group was very consistent with what we saw in Q4. So that did not ch
componenttext: Sure. When it comes to the -- well, referring to the oil patch store, the first thing is the transaction count remained very firm. But the difference between those stores and our control group was very consistent with what we saw in Q4. So that did not change dramatically. But it is -- we did like the performance of the stores because they were all positive in their performance relative to the control group. And we continue to drive sales through those stores with the foot traffic that we're getting. So generally, what we see is that the ticket may be down, because there's some very specific-type items that are sold in those areas, but the day-to-day basic transactions continue to occur and drive business in those stores. Yes, if...

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chris, this is Greg. As far as the Western stores, in respect to that new store performance, particularly Utah, we talked about the last call, yes, we're still building awareness in that market. And we have an executive trip that we make every quarter wit
componenttext: Chris, this is Greg. As far as the Western stores, in respect to that new store performance, particularly Utah, we talked about the last call, yes, we're still building awareness in that market. And we have an executive trip that we make every quarter with the teams, and we chose this past quarter to make the trip out to the West. We were in Phoenix markets, Utah markets, some other Western markets. And I must tell you, we feel very strongly that it's an awareness issue. And as we're seeing these stores ramp, we're feeling very good about our future prospects out there. It's about market awareness, it's about how we position. There's been some competition in those markets as we've come into them that it takes a little longer. And I think we saw this a few years back when we were first entering the Florida market and the Louisiana market. So we're feeling good about it. I think the mix of our business out there is a little different than we had seen in other markets, but we are figuring that out. We're rebalancing some of the store inventories. And now with the Southwest DC in position, we can react a lot faster. So we're feeling good, actually, about the West right now.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Adam Sindler with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Adam Sindler with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tony, real quickly on some of the -- just the financials. Are you still looking at about $8.5 million for the DC for the year? I believe that's what you guided to, and still about -- still very front-half weighted.
componenttext: Tony, real quickly on some of the -- just the financials. Are you still looking at about $8.5 million for the DC for the year? I believe that's what you guided to, and still about -- still very front-half weighted.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We had anticipated that, that would be the year-over-year drag that we would experience. So yes, pretty -- yes, very much consistent with what we originally guided.
componenttext: We had anticipated that, that would be the year-over-year drag that we would experience. So yes, pretty -- yes, very much consistent with what we originally guided.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just as we look at gross margins over the course of the year, could you remind us why, again, the fourth quarter is going to have such a difficult compare despite sort of the relatively sort of in-line gross margin from last year?
componenttext: Great. And then just as we look at gross margins over the course of the year, could you remind us why, again, the fourth quarter is going to have such a difficult compare despite sort of the relatively sort of in-line gross margin from last year?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Again, relative to the fourth quarter when we analyze it and we look at all the pluses and minuses, there's probably about 13 to 15 different impacts on that. And really, it's just a matter of looking at those and understanding what we'll be cycling
componenttext: Yes. Again, relative to the fourth quarter when we analyze it and we look at all the pluses and minuses, there's probably about 13 to 15 different impacts on that. And really, it's just a matter of looking at those and understanding what we'll be cycling against and where we see the tougher compares. And as much as -- it's difficult to break out all those pieces for you. It just turns out that the fourth quarter, we believe, would be one of the tougher compares.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just lastly, one thing you talked about is trying to keep on finding new products to introduce as you drive some of the End Caps and things like that. As you've moved to more national, are there anything -- maybe a local product that you fo
componenttext: Okay. And then just lastly, one thing you talked about is trying to keep on finding new products to introduce as you drive some of the End Caps and things like that. As you've moved to more national, are there anything -- maybe a local product that you found that you've been be able to bring back and take it more national? Anything from just going out to the West just outside of just opening new stores there, maybe from a merchandising standpoint?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Adam, that's a great question. I mean, we're constantly in a test-and-learn mode. And whether it's local, whether it's testing in 25 stores, learning from it and rolling it forward, it's a constant pipeline of product that runs through the system and then
componenttext: Adam, that's a great question. I mean, we're constantly in a test-and-learn mode. And whether it's local, whether it's testing in 25 stores, learning from it and rolling it forward, it's a constant pipeline of product that runs through the system and then gets expanded. We do a monthly review of all those tests that we've we got going on. I'll use one example. A couple of years ago, we tested kayaks in 50 stores and sold -- they sold pretty well. They exceeded our sell-through rate, then we expanded it to more stores. And this year, all stores have kayaks, and we're continuing to see good momentum there. So I can't give you any one specific item, but I could tell you that, that pipeline's pretty full, and we're constantly reviewing the opportunity for further expansion of new merchandise.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just lastly on that, anything on the ammo test? Is that in the stores yet? Or when will that hit?
componenttext: Great. And just lastly on that, anything on the ammo test? Is that in the stores yet? Or when will that hit?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, actually, interesting you should ask. A couple of weeks ago, I guess, maybe it was 1 week or 2 ago, we did roll forward with about 25 stores. Again, it's still in the very early stages. Stores are still setting the merchandise. And I suspect that on
componenttext: Well, actually, interesting you should ask. A couple of weeks ago, I guess, maybe it was 1 week or 2 ago, we did roll forward with about 25 stores. Again, it's still in the very early stages. Stores are still setting the merchandise. And I suspect that on the next call, we'll be able to give you a better update.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Michael Lasser with UBS.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Michael Lasser with UBS.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Tony, on the $18 million should we expect that, that's going to all come out of the second quarter? So if we just look at it on last year, it's about 100 basis points to the comp. So should we model whatever our comp estimate was before this quarter, t
componenttext: So Tony, on the $18 million should we expect that, that's going to all come out of the second quarter? So if we just look at it on last year, it's about 100 basis points to the comp. So should we model whatever our comp estimate was before this quarter, that we should essentially just take that down by 100 basis points?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, good question. When we look at it, there's that potential, but we really believe it's just too early to tell what the impact would -- should -- would be -- again, it's just an estimate. If you use that $18 million and you took it out of the quart
componenttext: Michael, good question. When we look at it, there's that potential, but we really believe it's just too early to tell what the impact would -- should -- would be -- again, it's just an estimate. If you use that $18 million and you took it out of the quarter, it would represent about a 1% change in the comp sales. But again, it's just our best estimate at the time and there's a lot of sales to be had. So it's too difficult to just make the assessment that all of it would come out of April.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And did you make any changes to your cost structure as such? Or it is what it is and we'd just go with it?
componenttext: And did you make any changes to your cost structure as such? Or it is what it is and we'd just go with it?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Obviously, we'll look at the variable expenses and the main driver would be your payroll. So we'll align our payroll with what we see the sales trends are relative to April as we move into May. And some of that is really more trending -- more current
componenttext: No. Obviously, we'll look at the variable expenses and the main driver would be your payroll. So we'll align our payroll with what we see the sales trends are relative to April as we move into May. And some of that is really more trending -- more current trending as we look at the sales in a particular period. But other than that, the expense structure, for the most part, would be intact.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then Greg, I just want to clarify your comments. When you talk about new store productivity, you referenced the western portion in the United States. We've seen previously that if there were any issue with new store productivity and the lack of brand
componenttext: And then Greg, I just want to clarify your comments. When you talk about new store productivity, you referenced the western portion in the United States. We've seen previously that if there were any issue with new store productivity and the lack of brand awareness, it was mostly around those stores in Utah. So is there something to have changed your viewpoint or is it mostly semantics?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, this -- overall, in aggregate, the new stores are performing very well and are performing at or above pro forma forecast. But in -- not to sum up and just say Utah, I'll just say in a few places in the West, we have seen a little slower ramp, but that
componenttext: No, this -- overall, in aggregate, the new stores are performing very well and are performing at or above pro forma forecast. But in -- not to sum up and just say Utah, I'll just say in a few places in the West, we have seen a little slower ramp, but that's now beyond us, and we're now starting to see those stores perform to a level that is acceptable to us and kind of fits in with what we expected initially. So it's not just Utah, although it was a little bit of a slower start initially. We're learning. The West is a new market for us. We were in California, and I think before we started expansion to the West, I think the furthest we were was probably Colorado. There's a lot of room in between those particular states. But we're feeling very solid now that we have -- we understand those markets better. We've now been out there a little over a year with most of our store base. And I think we've -- there's no concerns for us at going forward with the West.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would add, Michael, that when we do our calculation in new store productivity, we did see an increase this quarter over Q4 last year.
componenttext: And I would add, Michael, that when we do our calculation in new store productivity, we did see an increase this quarter over Q4 last year.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It was better than it was last year, so as we calculated it, it was in the high 60s versus this quarter, 70%. But that's still a little bit lower than it had been historically. So should we assume that as you add more stores out in the West and because yo
componenttext: It was better than it was last year, so as we calculated it, it was in the high 60s versus this quarter, 70%. But that's still a little bit lower than it had been historically. So should we assume that as you add more stores out in the West and because you've already got a base there, your brand awareness is better, that new store productivity should improve over time? Especially because I think you said in the past that the stores out West are actually a little bit more productive once they reach full maturity.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As we continue to grow out there in brand awareness, I think the thesis would be that it would take less time for us to gain market share as we -- as the brand becomes more aware and accepted out West.
componenttext: Yes. As we continue to grow out there in brand awareness, I think the thesis would be that it would take less time for us to gain market share as we -- as the brand becomes more aware and accepted out West.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Peter Keith with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Peter Keith with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was curious on some of the bigger ticket trends. It sounded like weather was both a positive and a negative. I guess, just kind of looking forward here with some of the spring and summer merchandise with lawn mowers, how do you feel about that general d
componenttext: I was curious on some of the bigger ticket trends. It sounded like weather was both a positive and a negative. I guess, just kind of looking forward here with some of the spring and summer merchandise with lawn mowers, how do you feel about that general demand and some of the category dynamics performing here for the next few quarters?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The big ticket itself, as Tony mentioned, we did see some benefit in Q1 in terms of plus numbers, mainly driven by riders as well as trailers. Some of that was a bit of a pull forward. We feel like we've got the right assortments out there. We've gone thr
componenttext: The big ticket itself, as Tony mentioned, we did see some benefit in Q1 in terms of plus numbers, mainly driven by riders as well as trailers. Some of that was a bit of a pull forward. We feel like we've got the right assortments out there. We've gone through, we've measured our assortments, we reviewed our assortments. We are a needs-based retailer, so if there's demand, I would tell you I feel pretty good about it. Tony said it's still early in the game here in Q2 and right now, it's hard to assess, but I would tell you, we've got the right product out in our stores.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks for that, Steve. My follow-up would just be on the gross margin expansion, which has obviously been observed as very good. Should we think about the margin expansion that you saw as sort of best of the year, given the -- what sounded like the
componenttext: Okay. Thanks for that, Steve. My follow-up would just be on the gross margin expansion, which has obviously been observed as very good. Should we think about the margin expansion that you saw as sort of best of the year, given the -- what sounded like there was some -- a onetime vendor support for the DC and then maybe some benefits around that extended seasonal set?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I'll go ahead and start this one. This is Steve, again. The one thing about gross margin, specifically, is that we got a plan, and it all starts there. We talked earlier about exclusive brands, product development, some of the imported goods we've g
componenttext: Okay, I'll go ahead and start this one. This is Steve, again. The one thing about gross margin, specifically, is that we got a plan, and it all starts there. We talked earlier about exclusive brands, product development, some of the imported goods we've got coming in. We also -- our systems are much more scienced than art-based price optimization, clearance price optimization. And so in Q1, there was a shift. Tony mentioned earlier that we did have some clearance coming out of Q4, but we were able to beat that with some regular price as well as some vendor support dollars. So what I would tell you is, is I feel good that we've got a plan, and the team's executing to it. Tony, you have anything to add?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Peter, I highlighted the vendor support relative to the distribution center because that is more of a onetime issue. But when we look at the margin, we have a lot of real positives that occurred and, obviously, Steve touched on. But the price managem
componenttext: Yes, Peter, I highlighted the vendor support relative to the distribution center because that is more of a onetime issue. But when we look at the margin, we have a lot of real positives that occurred and, obviously, Steve touched on. But the price management, the import, the exclusive brands were all very favorable this quarter. The fuel was positive, the way we managed promotions was much more favorable than the prior year, the way we cleared the merchandise. So net-net, as much as we've isolated that one item, I would agree with the original perception that it was a very strong margin quarter for us.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Seth Basham with Wedbush Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Seth Basham with Wedbush Securities.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I really want to talk about comps first, Tony. If we adjust out the $18 million from the 1Q results, on a 2-year stacked basis, you're still producing comps that are north of 9%. If we were to trend that out for the rest of the year, you'd be above your g
componenttext: I really want to talk about comps first, Tony. If we adjust out the $18 million from the 1Q results, on a 2-year stacked basis, you're still producing comps that are north of 9%. If we were to trend that out for the rest of the year, you'd be above your guidance range for the year. Is there a reason why, on that adjusted basis, we should assume that 2-year stack comps should decelerate through the year?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, when we look at that -- Steve and I are looking at each other, and I'm not sure if it's a matter of how we do our forecasting and maybe some of the conservative nature in the numbers. But we'll take a look at the seasons, we'll take a look at how we'
componenttext: Yes, when we look at that -- Steve and I are looking at each other, and I'm not sure if it's a matter of how we do our forecasting and maybe some of the conservative nature in the numbers. But we'll take a look at the seasons, we'll take a look at how we've developed our product plans throughout the year. We'll look at the year-over-year. And in some cases, we may actually go 3-years deep to look at some of the comparisons. So our modeling is built from the bottom up. And so we think that as much as at times, it may be a little conservative, we think that as we started the year and we continue through the year, we think that it's a very reasonable guidance.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Seth, the only thing that I would add is that Q1 comparison was pretty challenging, and I think we feel really good about where we came in. Tony did mention there was some pull forward. Q2 is not going to be an easy quarter either. We had a good, solid co
componenttext: Seth, the only thing that I would add is that Q1 comparison was pretty challenging, and I think we feel really good about where we came in. Tony did mention there was some pull forward. Q2 is not going to be an easy quarter either. We had a good, solid comp last year, albeit some favorable weather. So it's hard to look out and be able to forecast, but I think we've got a pretty good plan in place.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you, fair enough. And then secondly, I was hoping you could touch a little bit more on your new store plans, where you opened geographically in the first quarter, any differences in timing year-over-year. And then where you're trimming back. I think y
componenttext: Got you, fair enough. And then secondly, I was hoping you could touch a little bit more on your new store plans, where you opened geographically in the first quarter, any differences in timing year-over-year. And then where you're trimming back. I think you took your guidance down by up to 5 stores for the year.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The guidance for the full year was consistent with our original guidance. Again, we expect to open about 50% of the stores in the first half of the year and 50%, obviously, in the back half of the year. The only difference that we see this year is that a
componenttext: The guidance for the full year was consistent with our original guidance. Again, we expect to open about 50% of the stores in the first half of the year and 50%, obviously, in the back half of the year. The only difference that we see this year is that a little bit less stores in the West. Our -- we had a very focused push over the last 2 years to get the number of stores, create a large base in the Southwest so that we could open the distribution centers and get -- center and get some of the economic benefit from that. So as we look out this year, we see a few less stores in the West. We were running about 35% to 40%. We expect to be a little bit more in say, the 25% range when it comes to the Western stores. And additionally, we anticipate opening a few more second-use real estate versus build-to-suit locations. And that would mean some additional capital, probably in maybe the $5 million to $10 million range. But that -- those are the only 2 differences that we see as we move through the new store opening plan.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And one last follow-up, if I may. Greg, you mentioned that you've learned a lot in the West and you're approaching your openings out there differently. Can you provide any color about what you're doing differently? That would be helpful.
componenttext: Got it. And one last follow-up, if I may. Greg, you mentioned that you've learned a lot in the West and you're approaching your openings out there differently. Can you provide any color about what you're doing differently? That would be helpful.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll make it short. I think we have to keep our foot down on the pedal when it comes to marketing to make sure that we stay with these stores a little longer. There are a couple of things that are unique in some of these markets from a merch standpoint th
componenttext: I'll make it short. I think we have to keep our foot down on the pedal when it comes to marketing to make sure that we stay with these stores a little longer. There are a couple of things that are unique in some of these markets from a merch standpoint that we've learned, and we've addressed that now. And I think we've become very good listeners to our teams out there. And what we're doing, from a local market presence, and that could be interacting with local rodeos, with different 4-H and FFA groups. So there's a heightened, what I would call, awareness out there, who we are now versus our initial approach. And it's a little different than maybe what we've done in some of the markets where we have an existing presence. It's not overbearing, but those learnings, were applying.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: Our next question from Stephen Tanal from Goldman Sachs.

componenttext: Yes, I can give you a general idea. I try not to break all the components down into basis points because there are so many factors that are attributed to the freight line and gross margin. So the ones that I identified as having an impact are somewhat minimal impact, they were generally in the same range and generally would be less than 10 basis points of impact to the gross margin line.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: Got it, okay. I guess, just as I think about it, it sounds like the inbound may be getting a little bit worse than -- with the color that we got last quarter. Do you think that's a fair read? Or -- and separately, do you think you can start to leverage that line at some point this year, even if oil prices start to move in the other direction?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: When we look out, we would expect to see a similar impact in Q2. And we would expect that to start to moderate as we move through the year and start to get the benefits of the distribution center and moving some of our vendors to Western ship points. So w
componenttext: When we look out, we would expect to see a similar impact in Q2. And we would expect that to start to moderate as we move through the year and start to get the benefits of the distribution center and moving some of our vendors to Western ship points. So we expect it to start to moderate as we move through the year. But net-net for the year, we expect it to be just a slight drag on margin.

componenttext: Yes, I'm not specifically sure. I said -- can you repeat the question?

componenttext: No. Yes, I -- earlier, I think I've mentioned that in Q1, we were able to do that. We went from 3 waves in 2 weeks to 5 waves in 8. Next -- in the fall, we're going to keep a very consistent program to what we've done traditionally. I think we're much more accurate then. So there won't be a change in the fall.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: We'll take our next question from Dan Wewer with Raymond James.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, I wanted to follow-up on your comment about the benefits from Revionics. Are you continuing to get benefits from the initial markup module? Or are most of the current benefits coming from markdown management?
componenttext: Greg, I wanted to follow-up on your comment about the benefits from Revionics. Are you continuing to get benefits from the initial markup module? Or are most of the current benefits coming from markdown management?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, we're in 2 modules right now, regular price and clearance. So we kind of cover both sides. We haven't turned on promotional yet. And it's not all about markup. It's actually a combination of can we find margin or can we find -- can we drive sales? An
componenttext: Dan, we're in 2 modules right now, regular price and clearance. So we kind of cover both sides. We haven't turned on promotional yet. And it's not all about markup. It's actually a combination of can we find margin or can we find -- can we drive sales? And so once you turn price optimization on, it is an ever-moving and living, increasing process. And when we move into different markets, we're going to try, test different price elasticities. So you're correct, you'll see some improvement on markdown or clearance on that side. We're seeing some improvements in our regular price pricing and how we can stay competitive in markets. And it's really -- we needed this system because of all the different pricing strategies we've got throughout the country. We're in 49 states. We're not a single regular price on everything and every state being the same. So that was another reason why we put the system in.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you think about the promotional pricing module that's available, are you committed to making that investment? And how will the payback on that compare to the first 2 applications?
componenttext: When you think about the promotional pricing module that's available, are you committed to making that investment? And how will the payback on that compare to the first 2 applications?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: At this point in time, we have not made a decision that we would move forward with a promotional pricing module. We're still working through the first 2. If we do make that decision, Dan, you can bet that we're going to see some type of return on investme
componenttext: At this point in time, we have not made a decision that we would move forward with a promotional pricing module. We're still working through the first 2. If we do make that decision, Dan, you can bet that we're going to see some type of return on investment or we wouldn't into it.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then Tony, just a follow-up, I guess, towards more on the sales pull forward comment. Are you seeing anything in the results in April that would confirm that you moved some revenues from April into March?
componenttext: And then Tony, just a follow-up, I guess, towards more on the sales pull forward comment. Are you seeing anything in the results in April that would confirm that you moved some revenues from April into March?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: There could be some potential. And again, that goes into our calculation and estimate of the $18 million. Obviously, again, a little bit difficult assessment because as we moved into April, the weather was a little cooler so there was an impact there. So
componenttext: There could be some potential. And again, that goes into our calculation and estimate of the $18 million. Obviously, again, a little bit difficult assessment because as we moved into April, the weather was a little cooler so there was an impact there. So we're constantly assessing as we move through the quarter. But obviously, as this warm weather has moved in, we're really optimistic about the May and June timeframe and our spring assortment.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our next question from Chuck Cerankosky with Northcoast Research.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our next question from Chuck Cerankosky with Northcoast Research.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you talk a little bit about how some of the markdown discipline you took in the fourth quarter set you up for the first quarter, and how you make sure inventories weren't too low going into the first quarter, especially the seasonal merchandise?
componenttext: Could you talk a little bit about how some of the markdown discipline you took in the fourth quarter set you up for the first quarter, and how you make sure inventories weren't too low going into the first quarter, especially the seasonal merchandise?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Chuck, this is Steve Barbarick. There's 2 types of seasonal merchandise. There's product that we bought for Christmas that is not necessarily cold product-related, and we sold through that really well. It was a more seasonal clearance that we ended u
componenttext: Yes, Chuck, this is Steve Barbarick. There's 2 types of seasonal merchandise. There's product that we bought for Christmas that is not necessarily cold product-related, and we sold through that really well. It was a more seasonal clearance that we ended up carrying over. And I believe at the last call, we talked about the percentage that we carried over. A lot of retailers would have probably taken markdowns a lot quicker and panicked, to some degree. But a lot of the product that we have are whole goods that are pretty much standby year-to-year. And we took a very disciplined approach. We didn't panic in Q4. We took methodical markdowns where we could. We do have a clearance price-optimization tool that looks specifically at clearance by individual location so we can cluster those type of products. When the got into the first quarter, we had the benefit of that winter. Colder weather hit us in January. And we had enough of merchandise up North, knowing that we went to this 5 waves of allocation and it really paid off for us. Now we still are carrying some of that inventory over. I don't want to say that we sold completely through, but it's good inventory that we can bring out for next year. And the carryover is minimal compared to the total inventory investment that we have out there today. So the team did a really nice job. I think it was a disciplined approach. We used both art and science based on some of what we were looking at and we came out of it really well.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And regarding the 5 waves, from my perspective in Northeast Ohio, am I seeing some of that, like -- it looks like Chick program's coming in later here this year than last?
componenttext: And regarding the 5 waves, from my perspective in Northeast Ohio, am I seeing some of that, like -- it looks like Chick program's coming in later here this year than last?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That would be maybe part of it. I would tell you where you would see the biggest and most significant impact is really more in the seasonal, some of the power equipment and things like that. So where we would have set stores probably in your area in early
componenttext: That would be maybe part of it. I would tell you where you would see the biggest and most significant impact is really more in the seasonal, some of the power equipment and things like that. So where we would have set stores probably in your area in early February, those stores would have been set a little bit later up North toward the end of February. And the Southern stores really benefited because they actually got product 2 weeks earlier than what they traditionally would've gotten products. So as Greg said earlier, we were able to capitalize on an earlier spring in the South and keep some of that colder-related merchandise out on the floor through really the month of February and start setting spring at that point.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: We'll take our next question from Scot Ciccarelli with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just kind of a -- great -- I guess, just a strategic question. I know you'd kind of talked around it and a lot of weather-related questions. But when you wind up getting the kind of weather impact that you did in the first quarter, does that change how yo
componenttext: Just kind of a -- great -- I guess, just a strategic question. I know you'd kind of talked around it and a lot of weather-related questions. But when you wind up getting the kind of weather impact that you did in the first quarter, does that change how you're playing your merchandising or inventory sets for 2Q?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, this is Steve Barbarick. We set for season. We don't set necessarily for a quarter. And our quarters are, while they're fiscal, they're kind of calendar, so that March, April timeframe, you never know. There's always a bit of a shift. So we look at
componenttext: Again, this is Steve Barbarick. We set for season. We don't set necessarily for a quarter. And our quarters are, while they're fiscal, they're kind of calendar, so that March, April timeframe, you never know. There's always a bit of a shift. So we look at the season and we manage to the season. We don't necessarily manage inventories to the quarter.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that makes sense. And then just a quick follow-up for Tony. Something that was -- people have asked about previously and just wondering if you have any more recent thoughts on it, is the potential ability to improve payables inventory ratio and pote
componenttext: Okay, that makes sense. And then just a quick follow-up for Tony. Something that was -- people have asked about previously and just wondering if you have any more recent thoughts on it, is the potential ability to improve payables inventory ratio and potentially take some working capital out of your operation. You had inventory up by $100 million, payables essentially flat. Just wondering what's the right way to think about the payables inventory ratio kind of going forward. And again, what is the opportunity set there?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Scot, I absolutely agree with you, and I think you should continue to call Steve Barbarick on that one. But we do have some plans in place, but I would agree wholeheartedly. It's something that we need to have more discipline around and be more aggre
componenttext: Yes. Scot, I absolutely agree with you, and I think you should continue to call Steve Barbarick on that one. But we do have some plans in place, but I would agree wholeheartedly. It's something that we need to have more discipline around and be more aggressive relative to that because it clearly is sort of the one holdback when it comes to our return on invested capital.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Joe Feldman with Telsey Advisory Group.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Joe Feldman with Telsey Advisory Group.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask about the loyalty program. There's one -- something I don't think we talked about today, just latest trend. I know at the Analyst Day, you said it was about 140 stores in the test mode. And just any more data or color you could share wo
componenttext: Just wanted to ask about the loyalty program. There's one -- something I don't think we talked about today, just latest trend. I know at the Analyst Day, you said it was about 140 stores in the test mode. And just any more data or color you could share would be helpful.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Happy to do it, Joe. We're in, as you mentioned, 140 stores. We've got about 6 months now of learning. And what I would tell you is, is that the opt-in rate by our consumers have actually exceeded our original expectations. We knew that we had a fairly lo
componenttext: Happy to do it, Joe. We're in, as you mentioned, 140 stores. We've got about 6 months now of learning. And what I would tell you is, is that the opt-in rate by our consumers have actually exceeded our original expectations. We knew that we had a fairly loyal customer, and it wasn't really till we had a program out there that we realized that they were very interested and willing to hear from us and being part of a program. In the stores that we've had it in, we've seen nice attribution increases in understanding how our customer is and getting a deeper knowledge. And I'll just give you a couple of examples. In the stores where we've got the Neighbor's Club program, from a transaction standpoint, we've met one from really about mid-30s to mid-50s. So we've seen a nice increase in transaction attribution. And in sales attribution, that number has gone from the low 50s to the mid-60s. We're using that data now, because the goal of this was to collect information and then start personalizing communication out to them using e-mail. And we've been doing just that. We've got now a record of the response rates from our customers and the communication back and forth regarding either content our special offers or trying to get them to shop across the stores. So we're very enthusiastic about the program. And at this point, we are looking toward next steps. We don't yet -- we're not prepared to make a comment as to where we're going to roll it or how many stores will get it, but we are optimistic that this is something that's going to add value.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. Thanks for the update on that. And then, one other quick question. Any -- also an update on some of the pet resets that you've done in terms of maybe lift, and if there's any kind of way you can see what's been driving it, how much that's dr
componenttext: That's great. Thanks for the update on that. And then, one other quick question. Any -- also an update on some of the pet resets that you've done in terms of maybe lift, and if there's any kind of way you can see what's been driving it, how much that's driven comp or -- if you could share that.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I won't get into specifics, Joe, but I would tell you, Greg mentioned it earlier, our customers index very high when it comes to animal ownership. And that includes dogs and cats as well. And we go through a pretty rigorous category management revie
componenttext: Well, I won't get into specifics, Joe, but I would tell you, Greg mentioned it earlier, our customers index very high when it comes to animal ownership. And that includes dogs and cats as well. And we go through a pretty rigorous category management review of the pet aisle, supplies, treats as well as pet food every year and, in some cases, twice a year. We are seeing growth. We've got -- we look at 3 different segments. We look at the grocery segment, we look at the science segment, we look at the premium -- superpremium segments. And I would tell you, we're seeing growth in all 3 of those segments. We put a lot of our real estate as well as some of our marketing into the superpremium side of the business and our investments. And we think we're getting a very nice payoff. Customers are responding favorably, and I think that's one of the things that may be growing our transaction count. We talked a lot about queue and being needs based, and this would be a good example of that.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: And that concludes today's question-and-answer session. Mr. Sandfort, at this time, I will turn the conference back to you for any additional or closing remarks.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, operator. As we look ahead to 2016, we continue to be excited about the opportunities that lie ahead for Tractor Supply. We are pleased with the first quarter results, and the year is off to a good, solid start. But there's still a lot of
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, operator. As we look ahead to 2016, we continue to be excited about the opportunities that lie ahead for Tractor Supply. We are pleased with the first quarter results, and the year is off to a good, solid start. But there's still a lot of business ahead, as Tony mentioned. 
We will continue to invest in our infrastructure, our system improvements and our omnichannel business as we target mid-teens EPS growth. 
Thank you for your support of our company. We look forward to speaking to you again in July regarding our second quarter performance.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
