componenttextpreview: No. Yes, I -- earlier, I think I've mentioned that in Q1, we were able to do that. We went from 3 waves in 2 weeks to 5 waves in 8. Next -- in the fall, we're going to keep a very consistent program to what we've done traditionally. I think we're much mor
componenttext: No. Yes, I -- earlier, I think I've mentioned that in Q1, we were able to do that. We went from 3 waves in 2 weeks to 5 waves in 8. Next -- in the fall, we're going to keep a very consistent program to what we've done traditionally. I think we're much more accurate then. So there won't be a change in the fall.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Dan Wewer with Raymond James.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Dan Wewer with Raymond James.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, I wanted to follow-up on your comment about the benefits from Revionics. Are you continuing to get benefits from the initial markup module? Or are most of the current benefits coming from markdown management?
componenttext: Greg, I wanted to follow-up on your comment about the benefits from Revionics. Are you continuing to get benefits from the initial markup module? Or are most of the current benefits coming from markdown management?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, we're in 2 modules right now; regular price and clearance. So we kind of cover both sides. We haven't turned on promotional yet. And it's not all about markup. It's actually a combination of can we find margin or can we find -- can we drive sales? An
componenttext: Dan, we're in 2 modules right now; regular price and clearance. So we kind of cover both sides. We haven't turned on promotional yet. And it's not all about markup. It's actually a combination of can we find margin or can we find -- can we drive sales? And so once you turn price optimization on, it is an ever-moving and living, increasing process. And when we move into different markets, we're going to try different things, test different price elasticities. So you're correct, you'll see some improvement on markdown or clearance on that side. We're seeing some improvements in our regular price pricing and how we can stay competitive in markets. And it's really -- we needed this system because of all the different pricing strategies we've got throughout the country -- we're in 49 states -- we're not a single regular price on everything and every state being the same. So that was another reason why we put the system in.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you think about the promotional pricing module that's available, are you committed to making that investment? And how will the payback on that compare to the first two applications?
componenttext: When you think about the promotional pricing module that's available, are you committed to making that investment? And how will the payback on that compare to the first two applications?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: At this point in time, we have not made a decision that we would move forward with a promotional pricing module. We're still working through the first two. If we do make that decision, Dan, you can bet that we're going to see some type of return on invest
componenttext: At this point in time, we have not made a decision that we would move forward with a promotional pricing module. We're still working through the first two. If we do make that decision, Dan, you can bet that we're going to see some type of return on investment or we wouldn't into it.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then Tony, just a follow-up, I guess once more on the sales pull forward comment. Are you seeing anything in the results in April that would confirm that you moved some revenues from April into March?
componenttext: And then Tony, just a follow-up, I guess once more on the sales pull forward comment. Are you seeing anything in the results in April that would confirm that you moved some revenues from April into March?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: There could be some potential. And again, that goes into our calculation and estimate of the $18 million. Obviously, again, a little bit difficult assessment because as we moved into April, the weather was a little cooler so there was an impact there. So
componenttext: There could be some potential. And again, that goes into our calculation and estimate of the $18 million. Obviously, again, a little bit difficult assessment because as we moved into April, the weather was a little cooler so there was an impact there. So we're constantly assessing as we move through the quarter. But obviously, as this warm weather has moved in, we're really optimistic about the May and June timeframe and our spring assortment.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our next question from Chuck Cerankosky with Northcoast Research.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our next question from Chuck Cerankosky with Northcoast Research.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you talk a little bit about how some of the markdown discipline you took in the fourth quarter set you up for the first quarter, and how you make sure inventories weren't too low going into the first quarter, especially the seasonal merchandise?
componenttext: Could you talk a little bit about how some of the markdown discipline you took in the fourth quarter set you up for the first quarter, and how you make sure inventories weren't too low going into the first quarter, especially the seasonal merchandise?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Chuck, this is Steve Barbarick. There's 2 types of seasonal merchandise. There's product that we bought for Christmas that is not necessarily cold product-related, and we sold through that really well. It was the more seasonal clearance that we ended
componenttext: Yes, Chuck, this is Steve Barbarick. There's 2 types of seasonal merchandise. There's product that we bought for Christmas that is not necessarily cold product-related, and we sold through that really well. It was the more seasonal clearance that we ended up carrying over. And I believe at the last call, we talked about the percentage that we carried over. A lot of retailers would have probably taken markdowns a lot quicker and panicked, to some degree. But a lot of the product that we have are whole goods that are pretty much standbys year-to-year. And we took a very disciplined approach. We didn't panic in Q4. We took methodical markdowns where we could. We do have a clearance price-optimization tool that looks specifically at clearance by individual location so we can cluster those type of products. When we got into the first quarter, we had the benefit of that winter. Colder weather hit us in January. And we had enough of merchandise up North, knowing that we went to this 5 waves of allocation, and it really paid off for us. Now we still are carrying some of that inventory over. I don't want to say that we sold completely through, but it's good inventory that we can bring out for next year. And the carryover is minimal compared to the total inventory investment that we have out there today. So the team did a really nice job. I think it was a disciplined approach. We used both art and science based on some of what we were looking at and we came out of it really well.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And regarding the 5 waves, from my perspective in Northeast Ohio, am I seeing some of that, like -- it looks like the Chick program's coming in later here this year than last?
componenttext: And regarding the 5 waves, from my perspective in Northeast Ohio, am I seeing some of that, like -- it looks like the Chick program's coming in later here this year than last?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That would be maybe part of it. I would tell you where you would see the biggest and most significant impact is really more in the seasonal, some of the power equipment and things like that. So where we would have set stores probably in your area in early
componenttext: That would be maybe part of it. I would tell you where you would see the biggest and most significant impact is really more in the seasonal, some of the power equipment and things like that. So where we would have set stores probably in your area in early February, those stores would have been set a little bit later up North toward the end of February. And the Southern stores really benefited because they actually got product 2 weeks earlier than what they traditionally would've gotten products. So as Greg said earlier, we were able to capitalize on an earlier spring in the South and keep some of that colder-related merchandise out on the floor through really the month of February and start setting spring at that point.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Scot Ciccarelli with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Scot Ciccarelli with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just kind of a I guess, just a strategic question. I know you'd kind of talked around it and a lot of weather-related questions. But when you wind up getting the kind of weather impact that you did in the first quarter, does that change how you're playing
componenttext: Just kind of a I guess, just a strategic question. I know you'd kind of talked around it and a lot of weather-related questions. But when you wind up getting the kind of weather impact that you did in the first quarter, does that change how you're playing your merchandising or inventory sets for 2Q?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, this is Steve Barbarick. We set for a season. We don't set necessarily for a quarter. And our quarters are, while they're fiscal, they're kind of calendar, so that March, April timeframe, you never know. There's always a bit of a shift. So we look
componenttext: Again, this is Steve Barbarick. We set for a season. We don't set necessarily for a quarter. And our quarters are, while they're fiscal, they're kind of calendar, so that March, April timeframe, you never know. There's always a bit of a shift. So we look at the season and we manage to the season. We don't necessarily manage our inventories to the quarter.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that makes sense. And then just a quick follow-up for Tony. Something that was -- people have asked about previously and just wondering if you have any more recent thoughts on it, is the potential ability to improve payables to inventory ratio and p
componenttext: Okay, that makes sense. And then just a quick follow-up for Tony. Something that was -- people have asked about previously and just wondering if you have any more recent thoughts on it, is the potential ability to improve payables to inventory ratio and potentially take some working capital out of your operation. You had inventory up by $100 million, payables essentially flat. Just wondering what's the right way to think about the payables inventory ratio kind of going forward. And again, what is the opportunity set there?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Scot, I absolutely agree with you, and I think you should continue to call Steve Barbarick on that one. But we do have some plans in place, but I would agree wholeheartedly. It's something that we need to have more discipline around and be more aggre
componenttext: Yes. Scot, I absolutely agree with you, and I think you should continue to call Steve Barbarick on that one. But we do have some plans in place, but I would agree wholeheartedly. It's something that we need to have more discipline around and be more aggressive relative to that, because it clearly is sort of the one holdback when it comes to our return on invested capital.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Joe Feldman with Telsey Advisory Group.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Joe Feldman with Telsey Advisory Group.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask about the loyalty program. There's one -- something I don't think we talked about today, just latest trend. I know at the Analyst Day, you said it was about 140 stores in the test mode. And just any more data or color you could share wo
componenttext: Just wanted to ask about the loyalty program. There's one -- something I don't think we talked about today, just latest trend. I know at the Analyst Day, you said it was about 140 stores in the test mode. And just any more data or color you could share would be helpful.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Happy to do it, Joe. We're in, as you mentioned, 140 stores. We've got about 6 months now of learning. And what I would tell you is, is that the opt-in rate by our consumers have actually exceeded our original expectations. We knew that we had a fairly lo
componenttext: Happy to do it, Joe. We're in, as you mentioned, 140 stores. We've got about 6 months now of learning. And what I would tell you is, is that the opt-in rate by our consumers have actually exceeded our original expectations. We knew that we had a fairly loyal customer, and it wasn't really till we had a program out there that we realized that they were very interested and willing to hear from us and being part of a program. In the stores that we've had it in, we've seen nice attribution increases in understanding who our customer is and getting a deeper knowledge. And I'll just give you a couple of examples. In the stores where we've got the Neighbor's Club program, from a transaction standpoint, we've met -- went from really about mid-30s to mid-50s. So we've seen a nice increase in transaction attribution. And in sales attribution, that number has gone from the low 50s to the mid-60s. We're using that data now, because the goal of this was to collect information and then start personalizing communication out to them using e-mail. And we've been doing just that. We've got now a record of the response rates from our customers and the communication back and forth regarding either content or special offers or trying to get them to shop across the stores. So we're very enthusiastic about the program. And at this point, we are looking toward next steps. We don't yet -- we're not prepared to make a comment as to where we're going to roll it or how many stores will get it, but we are optimistic that this is something that's going to add value.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. Thanks for the update on that. And then, one other quick question. Any -- also an update on some of the pet resets that you've done in terms of maybe lift, and if there's any kind of way you can see what's been driving -- how much that's dri
componenttext: That's great. Thanks for the update on that. And then, one other quick question. Any -- also an update on some of the pet resets that you've done in terms of maybe lift, and if there's any kind of way you can see what's been driving -- how much that's driven comp or ... if you could share that.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I won't get into specifics, Joe, but I will tell you, Greg mentioned it earlier, our customers index very high when it comes to animal ownership. And that includes dogs and cats as well. And we go through a pretty rigorous category management review
componenttext: Well, I won't get into specifics, Joe, but I will tell you, Greg mentioned it earlier, our customers index very high when it comes to animal ownership. And that includes dogs and cats as well. And we go through a pretty rigorous category management review of the pet aisle; supplies, treats as well as pet food every year and, in some cases, twice a year. We are seeing growth. We've got -- we look at 3 different segments. We look at the grocery segment, we look at the science segment, we look at the premium -- superpremium segments. And I would tell you, we're seeing growth in all 3 of those segments. We put a lot of our real estate as well as some of our marketing into the superpremium side of the business and our investments. And we think we're getting a very nice payoff. Customers are responding favorably, and I think that's one of the things that may be growing our transaction count. We talked a lot about queue and being needs based, and this would be a good example of that.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, operator. As we look ahead to 2016, we continue to be excited about the opportunities that lie ahead for Tractor Supply. We are pleased with the first quarter results, and the year is off to a good, solid start. But there's still a lot of
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, operator. As we look ahead to 2016, we continue to be excited about the opportunities that lie ahead for Tractor Supply. We are pleased with the first quarter results, and the year is off to a good, solid start. But there's still a lot of business ahead, as Tony mentioned. 
We will continue to invest in our infrastructure, our system improvements and our omnichannel business as we target mid-teens EPS growth. 
Thank you for your support of our company. We look forward to speaking to you again in July regarding our second quarter performance.

[Operator Instructions] Please be advised that reproduction of this call, in whole or in part, is not permitted without written authorization of Tractor Supply Company. And as a reminder, this call is being recorded.
I would now like to introduce the host for today's call, Ms. Christine Skold of Tractor Supply Company. Christine, please go ahead.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom, and good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for Tractor Supply Company's quarterly earnings conference call.Before we begin, let me reference the safe harbor provisions under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. This c
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom, and good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for Tractor Supply Company's quarterly earnings conference call.
Before we begin, let me reference the safe harbor provisions under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. This call may contain forward-looking statements that are subject to significant risks and uncertainties, including the future operating and financial performance of the company. Although the company believes the expectations reflected in its forward-looking statements are reasonable, it can give no assurance that such expectations or any of its forward-looking statements will prove to be correct.
Important risk factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those reflected in the forward-looking statements are included in the company filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The information contained in this call is accurate only as of the date discussed. Investors should not assume that statements will remain operative at a later time.
Lastly, Tractor Supply Company undertakes no obligation to update any information discussed in this call.
I'm now pleased to introduce Greg Sandfort, Tractor Supply Company's Chief Executive Officer. Greg, please go ahead.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. On the call with me today are Tony Crudele, our EVP and Chief Financial Officer; and Steve Barbarick, our President and Chief Merchandising Officer.As you are all aware from our prerelease on
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. On the call with me today are Tony Crudele, our EVP and Chief Financial Officer; and Steve Barbarick, our President and Chief Merchandising Officer.
As you are all aware from our prerelease on June 29, we had a challenging second quarter. Not the typical Tractor Supply performance. And clearly, the weather was not favorable. The bottom line is, our business was heavily influenced by weather in Q2. We have worked very hard to be the most dependable supplier of products to the rural lifestyle customers. And the fact remains that some of those products, being seasonal in nature, can be impacted by weather.
Weather has always been a factor in our business and we know it's our job to manage around those external factors. However, we generally have not experienced the extreme conditions in variability in the weather from region to region like we saw in this second quarter. Hot and dry in the West, cold and wet in the East and Midwest and severe flooding and damage in the South Central. Just about every region experienced some form of weather variance and the conditions were very different from region to region.
When the weather began to normalize in June, so did our business. But the turn was not enough to offset the weakness in April and May. And not enough for us to anticipate that a significant shift in seasonal sales will occur coming into the third quarter. As a result, we have become a bit more cautious in our outlook for the remainder of the year, although last year's sales comparisons are more favorable than the second half.
During the quarter, very strong demand for our core animal and pet offerings continued, and we believe we are gaining share in these areas. We also saw continued momentum with events that directly support the sustainable lifestyle. Chick Days and our garden event both experienced strong year-over-year growth. We saw healthy demand for outdoor furniture, pest-control products, barbecue grills. But unfavorable weather and a difficult year-over-year sales comparisons challenged our ability to drive sales providing lawnmowers, lawn and garden products and utility vehicles.
We did see increased demand in departments where we continued to innovate and introduce newness such as truck lighting and accessories, trailers and outdoor water recreation. Our inventory and planning teams did an excellent job reacting to the softer sales trends in the quarter. And through a balance approach, managed the sales margin and inventory investment in relationship to customer demand. Tractor Supply will continue to invest in our business to drive sales, shorten our supply chain timeline and increase our overall productivity and profitability as a company.
In addition to implementing an improved allocation system, we are continuing our test and learn process on the merchandise side, expanding our new customer loyalty program pilot, growing our store mobile point-of-sale test and conducting a comprehensive DC network analysis. And we are pleased with the progress we are making on all of these initiatives.
Just this month, we expanded test of our Neighbor's Club customer loyalty program to the California market, and now have over 190 stores participating. While still early in the process, the initial enrollment rates continue to be ahead of our expectations. We are finding that our Neighbor's Club members are highly engaged to a tractor, and we are experiencing higher open and click-through rates on our targeted e-mails and communications to them.
We have now completed the implementation of our new allocation system. The new system is designed to improve efficiency and accuracy of our allocation process, and is scalable to support our long-term store growth targets. We continue to expand the test of mobile POS devices into our stores. And as the functionality has improved, the adaptation from our team members and customers have also increased. This capability will enable us and our team members to sell and assist customers with products from any point in or outside our stores.
And lastly, we are continuing the analysis of our DC network and systems, which we believe will be critical in supporting our growth to 2,500 stores, and evolving our supply chain strategy and capability for the longer-term.
Overall, we believe these and other investments have made our business more nimble and less susceptible to external factors. But recent results remind us that extreme weather conditions from region to region can impact our business in the short-term, and this is not likely to change. We continue to manage the business with the future in mind, and believe continuous improvement in our product and service offerings in addition to improving systems and efficiencies will keep Tractor Supply well positioned for growth.
Looking forward into the second half of the year, we are a bit more cautious. Despite the more normalized trends in June, we do not believe that we will see much of an extended spring selling season to recoup the sales lost in the second quarter. We revised our full year guidance in our June 29 business update press release and are reiterating that guidance today. Tony will take you through this in greater detail in a moment.
From a product and inventory perspective, we believe we are in a solid position to meet the needs of our customers as we transitioned the business from summer to fall. 
And before I wrap up, I want to thank the nearly 23,000 members of the Tractor Supply team for their continued hard work and dedication to our customers and our overall business. I also want to congratulate Tony on his planned retirement and Kurt Barton on his planned promotion to CFO. As we announced in today's earnings press release, Tony has notified the company that he plans to retire during the first quarter of fiscal 2017. Kurt Barton, the company's Senior Vice President and Corporate Controller, will succeed Tony as Senior Vice President, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer. Kurt has been with Tractor Supply for 17 years and is a talented financial leader with a proven track record of creating value. We all have the utmost confidence in his ability to continue leading the financial team forward. To ensure a smooth transition of duties, Kurt and Tony will work together over the next 7 months, with Kurt increasing his interface with the investment community to investors meetings and calls in the back half of the year.
I'll now turn the call over to Tony for more detailed commentary on our second quarter results and outlook for the remainder of 2016.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg, and good afternoon, everyone. For the quarter ended June 25, 2016, on a year-over-year basis, net sales increased 4.5% to $1.85 billion, net income grew 2% to $156.4 million and EPS increased 3.6% to $1.16 per diluted share.Comp store sale
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg, and good afternoon, everyone. For the quarter ended June 25, 2016, on a year-over-year basis, net sales increased 4.5% to $1.85 billion, net income grew 2% to $156.4 million and EPS increased 3.6% to $1.16 per diluted share.
Comp store sales decreased 0.5% in the second quarter compared to a very strong increase of 5.6% in last year's second quarter. Comp store sales were challenged throughout the quarter, with April and May impacted primarily from unfavorable weather patterns and tough comparisons from prior year. Beginning with Memorial Day weekend and warmer weather, seasonal sales trends normalized and comp store sales were in line with our expectations in the month of June.
Sales were the weakest in the northern regions of the country where unseasonably cool temperatures reduced demand for many spring items. The southern regions, which were less impacted by the cooler weather, performed more consistently with our expectations and had positive comps, except for the Texas region.
In addition to the impact of the oil patch economy, certain areas of Texas were negatively impacted by heavy rains and flooding, which limited some of the spring season activities. Comp transaction count increased for the 33rd consecutive quarter, gaining 1.5% on top of a 4.2% increase last year. As C.U.E. items such as pet and animal food continued to post high single-digit comps.
Average comp ticket decreased by 190 basis points compared to last year's 130 basis point increase. Big ticket drove last year's increase and was the principal driver of this year's average ticket decrease. Comparable sales of big ticket items declined approximately 8.5% as big ticket items such as riding lawnmowers and utility vehicles were challenged due to strong comparisons through last year and this year's unfavorable selling conditions. Deflation also had a slight impact on average ticket and contributed approximately 25 basis points to the decrease.
Now turning to gross margin, which decreased 22 basis points to 35% compared to a 50-basis-point improvement in last year's second quarter. Product mix had a negative impact on margin, although margin benefited from soft sales of some of the key big ticket items such as riding lawnmowers, this benefit was more than offset by the soft sales in other high margin departments and the strong sales of lower margin C.U.E. items. 
With respect to margin rate, while promotion cadence was relatively consistent with last year with the exception of a friends and neighbors events, we were slightly sharper on price to drive sales.
Freight was unfavorable as an increase in inbound transportation cost more than offset the benefits from lower diesel prices and a reduction in the outbound stem miles. We estimate deflation had a slight favorable impact on gross margin.
For the quarter, SG&A, including depreciation and amortization as a percentage of sales delevered by 15 basis points to 21.6% of sales compared to 21.4% of sales in the prior year's quarter. SG&A growth was impacted by several factors: the deleverage was primarily due to the lower comparable sales results as SG&A expense grew only 5.2% from the prior year. Excluding incentive compensation expense, SG&A expense increased 6.7%, which is below the SG&A growth rate of the past several quarters.
We experienced strong cost control in personnel, including store level, distribution center and store support payroll as well as medical expense.
Occupancy expense was well managed as we began to benefit from our LED lighting retrofit. The a strong expense management was achieved against the headwind from our Arizona distribution center that was not open at this time last year. We estimate the deleverage from the center's operation to be approximately 15 basis points.
Our effective income tax rate decreased to 36.8% in Q2 compared to 37.2% last year due to additional federal and the state tax credits.
Turning to the balance sheet. At the end of Q2 this year, we had cash balance of $151.1 million and $196.2 million in outstanding debt, principally comprised of the term loan compared to a cash balance of $56 million and no outstanding debt last year.
During the second quarter, we have limited purchases under our stock repurchase program. Average inventory levels per store decreased 1.2% compared to a 4.1% increase in last year's second quarter and inventory turns decreased compared to last year. We had strong inventory management in the quarter considering the soft sales environment. The transition between second and third quarters generally does not have significant markdown exposure. We are comfortable with our seasonal inventory as we move into the third quarter and we expect a normal markdown cadence exiting the season.
Capital expenditures for the quarter were $64.3 million compared to $48.2 million last year. We opened 22 stores and closed 1 Del's store in the second quarter compared to 17 new stores and 1 closed store in the second quarter of 2015.
The CapEx increase relates to our new store expansion, which includes an emphasis on retrofit locations that generally require renovation capital and our LED lighting retrofit project.
Now looking ahead, based on the trends and results for the first half of the year, we revised our outlook for the full year fiscal 2016 in our June 29 business update. We are reiterating that outlook today. We expect full year sales to range from $6.8 billion to $6.9 billion, comparable store sales to increase between 2.5% and 3.5% and net income to range between $451 million to $456 million with earnings per diluted share to be $3.35 to $3.40.
Assumed in this guidance is an EBIT margin improvement of about 10 to 15 basis points, a tax rate of 36.8% and capital expenditures of $230 million to $250 million. We will continue to make purchases under our share repurchase program and currently project full year diluted shares outstanding to be approximately $134.5 million to $134.8 million. 
In our June 29 business update, we stated that although June sales were more normalized, we did not expect a shift of spring sales into the third quarter. While it is still early in the third quarter, the trends through the first few weeks of July would appear to support this expectation. From a comparison standpoint in the third quarter, we face our toughest year-over-year comparison in July and our easiest comparison in September.
As a reminder, we had a record mild winter last year, and therefore, we believe that any upside in our forecast will be in the fourth quarter. We also have our 53rd week and an additional comp sales day in the fourth quarter. The additional sales week will provide incremental expense leverage in the fourth quarter and we estimate that the additional week will provide $0.03 to $0.04 increase to EPS, which is contained in our guidance.
In our original full year guidance, we forecasted a $0.01 negative EPS impact from the closing of several Del's stores in the fourth quarter as part of our transition to Tractor Supply stores in Washington state. We have now made a decision to close to those stores closer to their lease expiration with most of them expiring in 2017. We are pleased with the performance to date of the Tractor Supply stores that we have opened in the former Del's markets.
We continue to expect limited deflation in the back half of the year in the 15 to 20 basis points range. As we look at the back half of the year, we expect improvement of EBIT margin driven principally by improved gross margin in both the third and fourth quarters and expense leverage from the 53rd week. While transportation expenses will continue to be a headwind as we cycle the decline in diesel prices, we expect our gross margin initiatives to continue to drive improvement.
With respect to SG&A, we were very pleased with our expense management in Q2. We will continue to drive cost saving programs in the back half and we'll react accordingly to sales trends but we would expect year-over-year increase in SG&A to track closer to the overall growth in sales. We expect to maintain the appropriate payroll allocation to drive sales in the back half and incur a more normalized incentive compensation expense. We will continue to have the headwind of the Arizona distribution center until we cycle its opening in late December.
That concludes our prepared remarks. Operator, we will now turn the call over fore questions.

componenttext: David, this is Greg. It's really early for us to say that we're seeing anything significant because of it. But what I can tell you is that the reason we took -- the program expanded to California is we really like what we're seeing in Michigan with the engagement and how the customers are responding to it very openly. So we want to move it to California and take it another step. And I think 6 months from now, we'll probably have a better idea to give you some ideas on how it is impacting. We don't have enough data yet to say that we can use that to really reach back to customers and either poll them for information about how they're feeling and what they're buying or not buying. So now just gathering the data and getting them into a database, to be honest.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then as a follow-up, I guess it relates to the merchandising for really 2 days away, I believe, from the next open buying day. Can you just briefly talk about what departments, in your mind, right as of today, represent the greatest revenue margin opp
componenttext: And then as a follow-up, I guess it relates to the merchandising for really 2 days away, I believe, from the next open buying day. Can you just briefly talk about what departments, in your mind, right as of today, represent the greatest revenue margin opportunity, especially from a productivity standpoint in the box? I mean, I know from our pricing and our reports and from our own visits, seems to stick out just given the space allocation but heading into an event like the open buying day on Friday and so forth, is there -- are there anything that you guys can talk about that you're looking forward to you see a lot of opportunities on the merchandising side?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, this is Steve again. What I would tell you is it's kind of two-pronged here. The advantage of the open buying day is we're going to get an opportunity to see 300, 400 folks come through and talk to our teams, all of which are doing business with Tr
componenttext: Steve, this is Steve again. What I would tell you is it's kind of two-pronged here. The advantage of the open buying day is we're going to get an opportunity to see 300, 400 folks come through and talk to our teams, all of which are doing business with Tractor Supply today and really getting a better understanding of what's going on in the marketplace because most of these folks, either seller or competitors or they're somewhere else out there that we can get a better read on what's happening in the marketplace. Everyone who signs up, we will give some time too. And so we don't really narrow it down  in any 1 given category. In terms of what we're looking at in the box itself to move our business forward, we've talked a lot about the C.U.E. business and you'll see a number of resets that are going to take place in the back half of this year that will support that, whether it'd be what we're doing in feed with the launch of our DuMOR equine program or we're going to see in terms of Blue Seal, which will expand out to another couple of hundred stores in the Northeast and down the corridor. So there's a lot of things that are happening within the box right now, not just in terms of resets but also events such as deer feeding that we've got out there right now that's doing particularly well or the stock or shop tool event. And in that then itself, we're going to have about 60% new products that we didn't have a year ago to really give our customers a treasure hunt experience. So I could go on and on about all the things that we're working on but I would say across the board, we've got a lot of things cooking.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly, you made it abundantly clear the impact of weather on the business, particularly in the first 2 periods of the quarter. I guess, can you maybe shed a little bit more color than why, if you feel so strongly it is weather-related, you are increme
componenttext: Certainly, you made it abundantly clear the impact of weather on the business, particularly in the first 2 periods of the quarter. I guess, can you maybe shed a little bit more color than why, if you feel so strongly it is weather-related, you are incrementally more cautious for the second half? And then I do have a follow-up.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alan, this is Greg. A couple of things to note. The second quarter was difficult. And there was just incredibly, I'll say a challenging weather in some of the regions of the country where we have typically been able to weather those storms in the past, bu
componenttext: Alan, this is Greg. A couple of things to note. The second quarter was difficult. And there was just incredibly, I'll say a challenging weather in some of the regions of the country where we have typically been able to weather those storms in the past, but I'll give an example, in Texas, very, very difficult. Massive flooding, a lot of destruction. That will take time for that market to come back. It's not -- it doesn't snap back tomorrow. So our feeling was, let's be a little more conservative as we go into the second half. We know it's going to take some time for a large market like that where we have 170-plus stores to recover. And as we talked amongst ourselves, our feeling was, we're always kind of a conservative group here. We would rather be more conservative and give ourselves an opportunity to exceed that than to say, well, we think -- we can't forecast the future. We could only kind of deal with the past and try to look at that and understand what could be in front of us. So that's really -- we're just being a little more conservative given the fact that we had such a difficult second quarter with the weather variations.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And as a follow-up, so if we were to dissect your business in another way, namely, classes of stores added in more recent years, let's call it 2013, '14, '15, are the stores that were added in those classes possibly more susceptible to the weather t
componenttext: Okay. And as a follow-up, so if we were to dissect your business in another way, namely, classes of stores added in more recent years, let's call it 2013, '14, '15, are the stores that were added in those classes possibly more susceptible to the weather than prior classes?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Alan, this is Tony. We generally -- other than in sort of '14, '15, where we're trying to build our base out in the Southwest to create the volume for our Arizona distribution center, we generally are very geographically dispersed. So I don't think
componenttext: Well, Alan, this is Tony. We generally -- other than in sort of '14, '15, where we're trying to build our base out in the Southwest to create the volume for our Arizona distribution center, we generally are very geographically dispersed. So I don't think there was a particular emphasis. And in this case, the Southwest has performed very well for us and so there's less of a concern. Obviously, if you ran into a significant drought situation in a particular area of the country that may have an impact. But generally because of the geographic disbursement of the stores, we tend to be somewhat insulated from 1 -- some particular area of the country having some weather event.
