headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Seth, this is Tony. Based on our prepared remarks, the message that we're trying to send is that as we move through the quarter, we're hopeful that with sort of the softness in April and May that we'd see a little bit stronger bounce back in June. We
componenttext: Yes, Seth, this is Tony. Based on our prepared remarks, the message that we're trying to send is that as we move through the quarter, we're hopeful that with sort of the softness in April and May that we'd see a little bit stronger bounce back in June. We did not see that so as part of our update on our June 29 business update, we had anticipated that we would not see significant spring sales falling in the July time period, so -- and the last 3 weeks has verified that expectation. So we expect it'll be limited as we move through the rest of the quarter. And obviously, our easiest compare is in the September timeframe and a lot of that can be driven by cooler weather as people start to ramp up for the winter season. And right now, we expect that it will be cooler in September than last year, but still will be warmer than normal. So obviously, it's just too early to have an indication as to the third quarter.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then I just want to follow up on Peter's question about the network analysis that you're doing. Is there a scenario here where you need to significantly increase your spending? Or do you feel like the earnings growth algorithm that you laid out previo
componenttext: And then I just want to follow up on Peter's question about the network analysis that you're doing. Is there a scenario here where you need to significantly increase your spending? Or do you feel like the earnings growth algorithm that you laid out previously should account for any potential investments that you need to make?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Seth, this is Greg. That analysis, that's part of the analysis we're working through right now as far as what looks plausible. Anytime you do all these analysis, they do -- it's ran on a model of the perfect scenario, correct? Nothing is a perfect scenari
componenttext: Seth, this is Greg. That analysis, that's part of the analysis we're working through right now as far as what looks plausible. Anytime you do all these analysis, they do -- it's ran on a model of the perfect scenario, correct? Nothing is a perfect scenario. We have some buildings in places that honestly if we wanted back 10 years ago, we may not have put them in this city, maybe we put it in a city 200 miles to the east or to the west. So that's what we're sorting through right now. We do believe that the cost of this as we go forward will be part of our capital plan that we have had and we continue to invest to and the next leg of the growth. So yes, we believe it will be part of that plan. And again, we'll share more of this with you and when we get to the third quarter call, we'll have all this sorted through at that time.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'l take our next question from Michael Lasser with UBS.
componenttext: We'l take our next question from Michael Lasser with UBS.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, there have been points in the past where Tractor Supply has been burdened by the weather but it was able to power through either because store base is maturing and driving growth or because you still had a plethora merchandising activities and new p
componenttext: Greg, there have been points in the past where Tractor Supply has been burdened by the weather but it was able to power through either because store base is maturing and driving growth or because you still had a plethora merchandising activities and new products introduced. Is there a case where maybe just given the company's size or stage of development, it's harder now to overcome external factors like the weather?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Michael. I would tell you that we have worked at this and looked at this and no, that would not be the case. There's plenty of newness, plenty of things that we're bringing to the customer. But we did look back and did some study over the last several
componenttext: No, Michael. I would tell you that we have worked at this and looked at this and no, that would not be the case. There's plenty of newness, plenty of things that we're bringing to the customer. But we did look back and did some study over the last several years of where the trends and things and it's just become a little bit more, I'll call it unpredictable. Meaning that it's moving the sales around a little bit more than we thought. And so we're reacting to that freely well, keeping our inventories in control and moving our assortments to the product categories of the customers are willing to buy and want to buy. But now I don't think the size has anything really to do with it. We're still as nimble as we were. We saw plenty of newness. So I think this is us learning something new about how we need to react as these -- I think what we're going to see is more and more of this type of weather patterning and it's a new learning to be very honest.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe That being said, is there anything you could've done differently to help drive a better comp during the quarter?
componenttext: Maybe That being said, is there anything you could've done differently to help drive a better comp during the quarter?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think so because when you look at the weather patterns in parts of the country that was affected and how it affected them, we managed inventories extremely well by region. So I think we did that part extremely well. And to say that there was other
componenttext: I don't think so because when you look at the weather patterns in parts of the country that was affected and how it affected them, we managed inventories extremely well by region. So I think we did that part extremely well. And to say that there was other opportunities that we may have missed on, we looked at it very thoroughly. Steve and the team spent hours. And we took advantage of every opportunity that was there. The customer demand just didn't develop in second quarter. That's the answer.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then on the new store productivity, which all flow has been trending a bit below average, was that metric impacted by the weather? Or is that still a lingering effect of some of the lack of brand awareness on the West Coast?
componenttext: And then on the new store productivity, which all flow has been trending a bit below average, was that metric impacted by the weather? Or is that still a lingering effect of some of the lack of brand awareness on the West Coast?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Michael, this is Tony. We actually are pleased with where we are with the new store productivity. It's plateaued pretty much over the last 3 quarters and the stores out West are performing better. I think that as we cycle through, you'll see that the
componenttext: No. Michael, this is Tony. We actually are pleased with where we are with the new store productivity. It's plateaued pretty much over the last 3 quarters and the stores out West are performing better. I think that as we cycle through, you'll see that the newer stores that did open this year are again exceeding pro forma. And we should be able to maintain that new store productivity that's not increasing.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Christopher Horvers with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Christopher Horvers with JPMorgan.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mentioned that you were a bit more sharper on price and adding a friends and neighbor event. Was that mainly in response to the spring seasonal business? And as you've transitioned away from that time of year for that business, are you back to a compa
componenttext: You mentioned that you were a bit more sharper on price and adding a friends and neighbor event. Was that mainly in response to the spring seasonal business? And as you've transitioned away from that time of year for that business, are you back to a comparable, I guess, promotional and pricing posture on a year-over-year basis?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Christopher, this is Steve Barbarick. And one of the things we've talked a lot about, Tractor Supply being a fairly nimble company, and we're able to react pretty quickly to the needs of our consumer. And what we saw in the Q2 in the softness in a lo
componenttext: Yes, Christopher, this is Steve Barbarick. And one of the things we've talked a lot about, Tractor Supply being a fairly nimble company, and we're able to react pretty quickly to the needs of our consumer. And what we saw in the Q2 in the softness in a lot of seasonal businesses, we felt like we needed to react with something so we did put a promotional piece out there as Tony referred to. As we look forward, we're going to continue to use all the arrows in our quiver to best support the business. And whether that be using inventory to help move our business forward, it could be looking at additional promotional pieces, and it could be a variety of things. Maybe it's getting more targeted around some of the key businesses. Another thing that we're doing is local presentations. So right now, where it's hot and dry out West, we've got our store teams out there, putting together water movement and fans and things that we're doing down in Texas. So we're constantly moving the business around based on the needs of the consumer. I'm not suggesting that we're going to steer one-way any too far any one way because we use a balanced approach and we've got plenty of initiatives to move us forward, but I also don't want to rule anything out either.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. I guess to clarify that, I mean, that response is going to make people think that you're being -- continue to be more promotional and it's a reaction to current demand trends. So is that the message that we're expected to understand?
componenttext: Okay, understood. I guess to clarify that, I mean, that response is going to make people think that you're being -- continue to be more promotional and it's a reaction to current demand trends. So is that the message that we're expected to understand?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I wouldn't suggest that whatsoever. I mean, we've run our business the same way we have since I've been here and has been for the last 18 years. And I wouldn't want anybody to think that we're going to steer one way heading too far one way left or on
componenttext: Yes, I wouldn't suggest that whatsoever. I mean, we've run our business the same way we have since I've been here and has been for the last 18 years. And I wouldn't want anybody to think that we're going to steer one way heading too far one way left or one way right. We try to present value to our customers day in, day out and that's what they come in for. So again I wouldn't read anything into that.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then as you think about the oil patch and the performance of the stores, you had baked in lapping that I think it fell of -- those stores really fell off at the end of the third quarter. As you look over the first half of this year, how was your outlo
componenttext: And then as you think about the oil patch and the performance of the stores, you had baked in lapping that I think it fell of -- those stores really fell off at the end of the third quarter. As you look over the first half of this year, how was your outlook for the performance of those stores as we start to lap the follow-offs later? Is there anything changed? And are we expecting them to return to positive?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Chris. This is Tony. When we look at the last 3 quarters, their performance relative to the control group is relatively consistent to the impact on the comps has been again relatively consistent for the last few quarters. As we move forward, we will
componenttext: Sure, Chris. This is Tony. When we look at the last 3 quarters, their performance relative to the control group is relatively consistent to the impact on the comps has been again relatively consistent for the last few quarters. As we move forward, we will start cycling in and I agree with what you said that we really started to see sort of that fall off in the third and fourth quarter. So as much as we do anticipate that, it will moderate. We do believe that will still be a drag in the back half of the year but not to the extent that it has been in the first half.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Simeon Gutman with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Simeon Gutman with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Were there any undertones that discretionary spending is slowing? Or the weather just make it very difficult to judge that?
componenttext: Were there any undertones that discretionary spending is slowing? Or the weather just make it very difficult to judge that?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Simeon, let me take that one. I would tell you that what we saw in the second quarter, we can directly tie that back to the weather and how it slowed the development of some of the businesses. We had a very favorable end of March. And it seems like since
componenttext: Simeon, let me take that one. I would tell you that what we saw in the second quarter, we can directly tie that back to the weather and how it slowed the development of some of the businesses. We had a very favorable end of March. And it seems like since we got there and we have that early Easter shift, and looked like we had a bit of a reversal in trends, all of a sudden, in April and May versus where we were at the end of March. And we started seeing some pullback a little bit on big ticket because we've seen a good pull forward at the end of the first quarter. So we felt well, this is going to be trade-off between a couple of months. But as we said in the 29th update, we really haven't seen anything significant with the customers' use of credit or shift to spending and so on and so forth at this point and it's fundamentally they're still buying as need, they're still shopping for us, our traffic counts are up. So it was a bit of a tough pill to swallow when we saw the business has not developed and again in the warmness in June and we saw nice Michigan in the business. So it's just a very unusual but no, can say that we have anything that would give us an indication that there's some kind of current trend with the consumer because we would've seen some of the signals and we haven't seen. Our core business couldn't be stronger.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then my follow up on inventory's gross margin, Tony made a comment regarding third quarter that's there's not a big transitional quarter, a big mark down quarter. I guess you're not getting the pickup in seasonal July, one, is there some carryover tha
componenttext: And then my follow up on inventory's gross margin, Tony made a comment regarding third quarter that's there's not a big transitional quarter, a big mark down quarter. I guess you're not getting the pickup in seasonal July, one, is there some carryover that [indiscernible] and then if we do see some when we talk in the third quarter, if we do hear that there were some markdowns, what would explain that, our mark down during the quarter, what would have explained that or is that just likely out of the question?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Simeon, it's Steve Barbarick here. I felt that the team did a really nice job managing to the demands of the business. And we saw that early and we're able to pullback in a lot of the ordering and our seasonal inventories are in a very great position righ
componenttext: Simeon, it's Steve Barbarick here. I felt that the team did a really nice job managing to the demands of the business. And we saw that early and we're able to pullback in a lot of the ordering and our seasonal inventories are in a very great position right now for spring. So I have very little concern about markdown or clearance going into the third quarter or fourth quarter for spring product.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Ben Bienvenu with Stephens Inc.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Ben Bienvenu with Stephens Inc.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just following on that question as it relates to inventory and some of the variability that we've seen around weather. Has there been any deviation or evolution in the number of resets that you anticipate to do for the fall selling period? Or do you an
componenttext: So just following on that question as it relates to inventory and some of the variability that we've seen around weather. Has there been any deviation or evolution in the number of resets that you anticipate to do for the fall selling period? Or do you anticipate sticking with that traditional reset cadence?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We went back and we've looked at what we're doing in the back half of this year and looked at the categories that may be most impacted that we think that our customers still a lot of demand for. And we've modified our approach a slightly but it's really a
componenttext: We went back and we've looked at what we're doing in the back half of this year and looked at the categories that may be most impacted that we think that our customers still a lot of demand for. And we've modified our approach a slightly but it's really around some key areas and I feel really good about in the recent work that we're going to be delayed. So it is around a lot of the key merchandise. But in addition to that, we went back, we've reset our stores for footwear and leather and in rubber. We've got a heating resets that are going to be taking place and assortment adjustments there as well. So generally, when you look across the 4 walls, I feel very confident that the work the team's doing is going to be in line with what we're seeing our customer demand for.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then you touched in the past on some MO tests in a handful of stores. I'd be curious to hear how that's progressing. And then any change in thought process either around extending the number of stores that offer that SKU and/or potentially adding fire
componenttext: And then you touched in the past on some MO tests in a handful of stores. I'd be curious to hear how that's progressing. And then any change in thought process either around extending the number of stores that offer that SKU and/or potentially adding firearms or some kind to your assortment?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would tell you at this point, it's too early in the test. It's in 25 stores and we're getting some results now. We still need to dissect and determine whether or not it meets our threshold for being a successful test so that it would move forward a
componenttext: Yes. I would tell you at this point, it's too early in the test. It's in 25 stores and we're getting some results now. We still need to dissect and determine whether or not it meets our threshold for being a successful test so that it would move forward and more stores. In terms of firearms, it's way too early in the game to even talk about that. I would need that for future date.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Peter Keith with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Peter Keith with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just look at the mix dynamic in Q2. As far back as I can remember when you've had these late springs or colder springs, you usually have had this mix benefit because of the lower OPE sales. It seems like there's a bit of a change here in Q2, c
componenttext: I wanted to just look at the mix dynamic in Q2. As far back as I can remember when you've had these late springs or colder springs, you usually have had this mix benefit because of the lower OPE sales. It seems like there's a bit of a change here in Q2, can you identify there was some higher-margin items. Could you just maybe provide more specifics there? And anything that's kind of surprised you on the weakness?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. When it comes to the bigger ticket, we definitely had a benefit, in particular when it came to the riding mower category. So the softer sales in that category did help margin because it is well below chain average. When we look at some of the other
componenttext: Sure. When it comes to the bigger ticket, we definitely had a benefit, in particular when it came to the riding mower category. So the softer sales in that category did help margin because it is well below chain average. When we look at some of the other key departments, obviously, the first thing that comes to mind is the strength of the C.U.E. items in particular, the animal feed and pet food, which had just slightly below chain average margin but that strength, obviously deleveraged on margin. So that had a negative impact. And then when you look at some of the other spring items that are higher margins that we're soft as well and even some of the other hard line items, the softness in those sales that we didn't obvious a pickup the margin there as well. So those 2 factors offset the benefit that they get the larger ticket hard-line category.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And anything there, in that last comment, Tony, that was different from previous cold springs?
componenttext: And anything there, in that last comment, Tony, that was different from previous cold springs?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Generally, we would have some key categories of the spring that would sell well. In this case, some of those categories we didn't get that lift, so we would generally get some offset. And so it just -- we just didn't have the same lift that we would get f
componenttext: Generally, we would have some key categories of the spring that would sell well. In this case, some of those categories we didn't get that lift, so we would generally get some offset. And so it just -- we just didn't have the same lift that we would get from the other higher key categories. I know Steve had some comments he would like to make.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. A year ago, when we were sitting here talking about this front of the business, a lot of it was driven by seasonal and a lot of it was driven -- we had a new OPE line up. We saw demand across the board in trailers and a lot of other categories. And w
componenttext: Yes. A year ago, when we were sitting here talking about this front of the business, a lot of it was driven by seasonal and a lot of it was driven -- we had a new OPE line up. We saw demand across the board in trailers and a lot of other categories. And we were comping that this year in all fairness. And to your stack, I think it really feel good about the but unfortunately, we're comping ourselves and we've -- that's what we need to be doing and wouldn't do it like we should have this quarter. But if you look at the totality of the business, it still as strong, there are some very strong fundamentals and the business but we're lapping what was a very robust Q2 last year in the seasonal category.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, well I have you too, so you've mentioned the rollout of new and improved inventory allocation system. The have any early wins or insights you could share? And how might that benefit the back half of the year?
componenttext: So, well I have you too, so you've mentioned the rollout of new and improved inventory allocation system. The have any early wins or insights you could share? And how might that benefit the back half of the year?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's rolling out now to the entire team and I would tell you, and we do think it's going to have a positive impact on the business. It's really going to help us mainly with things like end caps, and vet merchandise, a lot of the seasonal build's both
componenttext: Yes. It's rolling out now to the entire team and I would tell you, and we do think it's going to have a positive impact on the business. It's really going to help us mainly with things like end caps, and vet merchandise, a lot of the seasonal build's both initial and and in season and those are the ones that a lot of get the greatest benefits. And talking with the team, we believe we'll see a lot of those benefits in Q4 because the work we're doing right now is going to have that impact.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Stephen Tanal with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Stephen Tanal with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the one thing I was trying to sort of understand on the weather, if we think about that $25 million pull forward into 1Q and sort of normalized for that, it's about 140 bps I think, to Q2 and you kind of add it in and pull it out of 1Q and it does actu
componenttext: So the one thing I was trying to sort of understand on the weather, if we think about that $25 million pull forward into 1Q and sort of normalized for that, it's about 140 bps I think, to Q2 and you kind of add it in and pull it out of 1Q and it does actually look like the underlying rate slowed. Is that a fair way to think about it? Or do you think that doesn't really capture the entire seasonal effect? And if you could just maybe just give us a number, an all-in number on the weather impact for 2Q, if you guys have something on your head, that would be pretty helpful too.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Stephen, I think what you're trying to get to is you try to minimize looking at the pull forward and you push that through and kind of work the numbers that I think what you're saying is, that we see a bit of a slowdown in second quarter just in general f
componenttext: Stephen, I think what you're trying to get to is you try to minimize looking at the pull forward and you push that through and kind of work the numbers that I think what you're saying is, that we see a bit of a slowdown in second quarter just in general from what we saw in the first quarter in sale, if we did that.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, ex the weather, the core kind of trend rate here.
componenttext: Yes, ex the weather, the core kind of trend rate here.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, with the slowdown that we did see is, again, in the big ticket categories. No question that was part of it but we believe that, that was due to the fact that the weather just was not complementary for some of those kinds of products. Our customers,
componenttext: Well, with the slowdown that we did see is, again, in the big ticket categories. No question that was part of it but we believe that, that was due to the fact that the weather just was not complementary for some of those kinds of products. Our customers, as you know, by very much to need. And so when we look at that, we did some normalization of our open numbers. Those big ticket categories our riding lawnmowers as Steve mention a few other categories, you to these, which I know very robust a year ago at this time, did not anniversary themselves.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: But just to be clear, is the big ticket impact part of that $25 million or not?
componenttext: But just to be clear, is the big ticket impact part of that $25 million or not?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Some, but not...
componenttext: Some, but not...

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It definitely is. We got off to a very strong riding season in March, so we clearly had anticipated that growing through into Q2.
componenttext: It definitely is. We got off to a very strong riding season in March, so we clearly had anticipated that growing through into Q2.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: But it didn't roll through.
componenttext: But it didn't roll through.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: But it didn't. As we stated in our prepared remarks them of the ticket was down 8%, and in particular after being very strong in the March timeframe. So you can adjust the month but it's still trend is a very consistent to the overall trends where April a
componenttext: But it didn't. As we stated in our prepared remarks them of the ticket was down 8%, and in particular after being very strong in the March timeframe. So you can adjust the month but it's still trend is a very consistent to the overall trends where April and May were softer than June.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just lastly and as we think about kind of the weather, obviously, a big comp if we look at everything that's happening. It's been hot, which I think is generally good but it's also been dry. And I think in June, we typically like wetter weather and to
componenttext: And just lastly and as we think about kind of the weather, obviously, a big comp if we look at everything that's happening. It's been hot, which I think is generally good but it's also been dry. And I think in June, we typically like wetter weather and to be honest, I'm not sure what we root for in July. Does the dryness hurt you? Do you want it to be wetter in general? Or how should we think about weather just high-level?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, for the most part, we do prefer wet because things will continue to grow and it's a continuation of spring. But when you look at the moisture generally throughout the springtime, we've had good moisture throughout. So as we move into the summer, it
componenttext: Well, for the most part, we do prefer wet because things will continue to grow and it's a continuation of spring. But when you look at the moisture generally throughout the springtime, we've had good moisture throughout. So as we move into the summer, it shouldn't be a significant impact. Obviously, when you look at the drought map, tends to be a little bit in sort of the Southwest and the California area. But because there's too much rain in say the Texas area, the heat is good because it helps dries out a little bit sooner. But generally, we look for moisture. It will be positive thing as we move through the year.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just last one for me, if there's any update you could share from the inbound freight issues with the cost of grand DC, have you made some headway with the vendors or have you switched up vendors? How's that going?
componenttext: And just last one for me, if there's any update you could share from the inbound freight issues with the cost of grand DC, have you made some headway with the vendors or have you switched up vendors? How's that going?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Steve. This is going to be an ongoing challenge for our merchant team and our sourcing team to continue to bring new folks on. We have made some headway in that but when you're talking about is many product categories as we carry and 70-plus perce
componenttext: This is Steve. This is going to be an ongoing challenge for our merchant team and our sourcing team to continue to bring new folks on. We have made some headway in that but when you're talking about is many product categories as we carry and 70-plus percent of those go through our network. This is not a one and done kind of scenario. So we are making headway. We've got about another 20 or 30 vendors that we are looking right now in terms to either resource or find secondary vendors out west to be able to reduce system miles.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Scott Mushkin with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Scott Mushkin with Wolfe Research.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Chris for Scott. Our first question was taking a step back, you guys have obviously it's a very strong track record, but it's more recently the annual comp algorithm has kind of slowed a bit, [indiscernible] putting weather aside in the last coupl
componenttext: This is Chris for Scott. Our first question was taking a step back, you guys have obviously it's a very strong track record, but it's more recently the annual comp algorithm has kind of slowed a bit, [indiscernible] putting weather aside in the last couple of quarters but last couple of years, why do you think this is happening? And then as a follow-up, like do you think that your current what initiatives can lead to we accelerated comp looking forward? Or are you kind of comfortable in this range?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chris, let me start with that. Tony will probably jump in. I've been with the company now, I'd be 9 years in November. And I would say that the last 4 had been the most interesting from a standpoint of the mix of our products and when things are selling,
componenttext: Chris, let me start with that. Tony will probably jump in. I've been with the company now, I'd be 9 years in November. And I would say that the last 4 had been the most interesting from a standpoint of the mix of our products and when things are selling, when things peaked, introductions and newness and so on, but I can't underestimate and we used to, I think of things we can control more things around some of the weather patterning across the country but as we've gotten now into 49 states and that store dispersion is a good thing generally. I would tell you that it makes it more challenging for us to understand sometimes how these ebb and flows will affect the overall business on an annual basis. We typically can work our way through some of these slight, if we call it, troubled spots where we have I would say less-than-ideal weather and less-than-ideal conditions for selling certain products. But we're in a new learning curve here, I believe, as we look at some of these things moving forward and the team has done some great work as we forecast forward through the second half and into next year. And I'm convinced that we can kind of pushing this thing back on this growth trajectory that is kind of expected from Tractor. I mean, we're a test and learn company. We learn over time. There's no lack of newness, as Steve mentioned earlier. We continue to introduce new products and those are the things that really drive our footsteps and then were getting far better in this localization component. And that's going to be a key as we go forward because that helps us defend ourselves when conditions are less than ideal for selling some products. I can't reiterate enough, our customers buy to demand or to need. They don't buy early. They haven't been for a long time.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I'll just add that over my 11 years here, we don't necessarily see what the next silver bullet is going to be but being the test and learn, we're constantly coming up with really good ideas and products. And we let our customers dictate what the next
componenttext: And I'll just add that over my 11 years here, we don't necessarily see what the next silver bullet is going to be but being the test and learn, we're constantly coming up with really good ideas and products. And we let our customers dictate what the next best item is going to be. But when it comes to the model itself, generally, our forecasting is always in the 3% to 5% range. We don't need to reach the high-single-digit comps anymore to have a really successful year. And so as we look out, we think that the model work just terrifically at the 3% to 5% comp level.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one brief follow-up along the same strategy. How much do you think is left in there, like what inning do you think we're in? If you benchmarked yourself in the industry, talking to the suppliers, are you taking share there? Like do you think your cus
componenttext: Just one brief follow-up along the same strategy. How much do you think is left in there, like what inning do you think we're in? If you benchmarked yourself in the industry, talking to the suppliers, are you taking share there? Like do you think your customers have adopted into the premium brand in the space yet, kind of what's left there are you thinking the next call it 3 to 5 years?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Steve. We still see more opportunity here and we're seeing continued growth over the last several years. And it's really driving footsteps into our stores. Our focus is really around the priced right. It's about having the right inventories a
componenttext: Yes. This is Steve. We still see more opportunity here and we're seeing continued growth over the last several years. And it's really driving footsteps into our stores. Our focus is really around the priced right. It's about having the right inventories and it's about expanding our assortments and we've continued to do that very well. I still think that there is upside and a lot of momentum here that we still have. Depending upon the category you look at, I'll use, if you benchmark maybe our overall pet business versus industry, I think if you look at that, you'll probably say we're outstripping and indexing higher than industry and therefore, you have to make the assumption that you are taking share. If you look at our feed business, I would tell you based on what we hear from our suppliers, there's a good likelihood that we're taking market share there as well and you could go across the 4 walls, whether it'd be in lubricants, whether it'd be in lawn and garden or other categories such as betting. And I think we continue to do a nice job, offering a great assortment the past writing start, at great value prices for our customers everyday. So I still think there's a more upside here.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Chuck Cerankosky with Northcoast Research.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Chuck Cerankosky with Northcoast Research.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a real quick question on the big ticket items in this most recent quarter. Are there attached products that went missing because somebody wasn't buying an ATV, say a trailer or hitches, things like that that took away from the total sales beyond just
componenttext: Just a real quick question on the big ticket items in this most recent quarter. Are there attached products that went missing because somebody wasn't buying an ATV, say a trailer or hitches, things like that that took away from the total sales beyond just a big ticket merchandise?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Steve and that's a great question. Because when you talk seasonal, there's a lot of attachments that come with OPE, there's a lot of replacement parts and whatnot and we saw relative softness across many of those compared to year prior's strong co
componenttext: This is Steve and that's a great question. Because when you talk seasonal, there's a lot of attachments that come with OPE, there's a lot of replacement parts and whatnot and we saw relative softness across many of those compared to year prior's strong comp store sales theres. So many of those attachments and accessories do carry a higher-margin, that was a question asked will year and we did saw those sales be soft over the course of the second quarter.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Dan Wewer with Raymond James.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Dan Wewer with Raymond James.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, the way that those 3 measures in the store productivity began to weaken a bit about a year ago from your perspective, it really doesn't have much of change but based in the publicly available information, that how the number shakeout and then a few
componenttext: Greg, the way that those 3 measures in the store productivity began to weaken a bit about a year ago from your perspective, it really doesn't have much of change but based in the publicly available information, that how the number shakeout and then a few quarters after that, we saw the weakness, the negative comps in the fourth quarter last year and now another negative quarter. Of you have any concern your part that perhaps some of the weaker new store openings could be a leading indicator of call it saturation and that could be contributing to this current sales trends?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, what I can tell you is the facts. No question when we first opened in the Western markets, we saw some weakness there in a few markets and that drag for about 1 year in 18 months was near. The process we use in finding and aligning new stores and how
componenttext: Dan, what I can tell you is the facts. No question when we first opened in the Western markets, we saw some weakness there in a few markets and that drag for about 1 year in 18 months was near. The process we use in finding and aligning new stores and how we plan for cannibalization in this, we are seeing a more normalization again, we're seeing stores performing back to that level and on a year-over-year basis, so very similar. So we did have a little period of time there when it was Gee, what happened and we looked at it and it was really very concentrated in really the Utah market. So no, we're not seeing new store productivity sliding. As a matter fact, it's as good today as it was a few years back. But we did have a little blip in there and I think we worked our way through that.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The second question I ask revolves around an your pricing optimization, you've been very bullish about the benefit post margin rate. in light of the recent sales trends, have you taken a fresh look at elasticity of demand, and perhaps come to the conclusi
componenttext: The second question I ask revolves around an your pricing optimization, you've been very bullish about the benefit post margin rate. in light of the recent sales trends, have you taken a fresh look at elasticity of demand, and perhaps come to the conclusion that perhaps we squeeze about as much out of pricing as we can and in fact maybe there's the case that you made promotional, which sounds like you did during the quarter?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dan, this is Steve. I mean, the pricing tools that we is in regular price are ongoing. And they give us recommendations based on demands around area of the country. And so we're constantly looking and fine-tuning that, challenging ourselves and we ha
componenttext: Yes, Dan, this is Steve. I mean, the pricing tools that we is in regular price are ongoing. And they give us recommendations based on demands around area of the country. And so we're constantly looking and fine-tuning that, challenging ourselves and we have upside in take-up and where we think we need to be aggressive, we move those prices down. So from that perspective, I think that there's still more we can get out of the tools. As a matter of fact, we just recently extended our contract with Revionics because we continue to see value there. In addition to that, the clearance module that we use has still been very effective for us and helping us work our way through a lot of that product while it's still in home before it gets moved and try to move it through while we're still in season. Our units in terms of SKU products, we're still seeing a strong comp store units movement and we really track units as much as we do sales in many cases. Now you've heard the last couple of years, we have seen some deflation there so we've got some headwinds to overcome. But generally speaking, I still think that there is some more opportunity for us in using that tool.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just really quickly on the July, we've known that the year-over-year comparison would be difficult for 12 months, in fact, as I recall, July of 2014 was a very strong month for Tractor Supply as well. So based on your comments about the first 2 weeks
componenttext: And just really quickly on the July, we've known that the year-over-year comparison would be difficult for 12 months, in fact, as I recall, July of 2014 was a very strong month for Tractor Supply as well. So based on your comments about the first 2 weeks of July of 2016, are you saying they're weak but it's exactly the way it was budgeted? Or is the company communicating we knew it can be a tough comparison [indiscernible] we're running below where we though we would be?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, this is Tony. Let me answer that one. What we're seeing is that we did not see a shift of sales, spring sales from Q2 into Q3. And so we're not making a statement one way or the other relative to the performance to our expectations or comparison to c
componenttext: Dan, this is Tony. Let me answer that one. What we're seeing is that we did not see a shift of sales, spring sales from Q2 into Q3. And so we're not making a statement one way or the other relative to the performance to our expectations or comparison to comps of last year. I won't -- and I would say I'm in agreement with you. We've had 3 very strong Julys in a row. And obviously, when we look out and we forecast -- we would forecast July not to be the strongest of the 3 months in the quarter.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you're cautiousness, this reflects the fact that you're not recovering the lost in April and May but you're not necessarily saying that the current run rate is below plan? Simply you're not making up for the ground that was lost?
componenttext: So you're cautiousness, this reflects the fact that you're not recovering the lost in April and May but you're not necessarily saying that the current run rate is below plan? Simply you're not making up for the ground that was lost?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll go next to Scott Ciccarelli with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go next to Scott Ciccarelli with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tony, you referenced earlier, you said in the past what spring should be good for 3Q trends and it does extend the growing season. Are you expecting any benefit from that this so-called 3 -- third quarter or is it something different this year?
componenttext: Tony, you referenced earlier, you said in the past what spring should be good for 3Q trends and it does extend the growing season. Are you expecting any benefit from that this so-called 3 -- third quarter or is it something different this year?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. As we say, we had anticipated that with the moisture and with the slow start to the spring that it would be a delayed spring and will continue into Q3. But since we did not experience that bounce back in June, we were very cautious and did not anticip
componenttext: No. As we say, we had anticipated that with the moisture and with the slow start to the spring that it would be a delayed spring and will continue into Q3. But since we did not experience that bounce back in June, we were very cautious and did not anticipate extending out. So yes, it is a little bit different than what we've seen in the past. But we did not expect any additional spring sales in the July, August time frame.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: But you have discussed in the past more and more static ground actually helps you through balance on 3Q or am I just misunderstanding that?
componenttext: But you have discussed in the past more and more static ground actually helps you through balance on 3Q or am I just misunderstanding that?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, that's correct. And again, as we saw throughout the quarter with the softness in sales as well as the big ticket being soft as well as having the last sort of 3 years of strong Q3 in particular, strong July, August, it's a more difficult comparison.
componenttext: No, that's correct. And again, as we saw throughout the quarter with the softness in sales as well as the big ticket being soft as well as having the last sort of 3 years of strong Q3 in particular, strong July, August, it's a more difficult comparison.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Adam Sindler with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Adam Sindler with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a focus on margins for a couple of minutes here. As we look through the second half of the year, what are the major puts and takes in the gross margin line in the third and fourth quarters? Is it more the impact of inbound freights on C.U.E. on the W
componenttext: Just a focus on margins for a couple of minutes here. As we look through the second half of the year, what are the major puts and takes in the gross margin line in the third and fourth quarters? Is it more the impact of inbound freights on C.U.E. on the West Coast, DC, is it mix? Just as we think about how the weather plays out, what are the different things we should try and think about?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: As we move into the back half of the year, they tend to be, the margins, as well as most of the P&L, tends to be a little bit more predictable. Now obviously as we work our way through the quarter and sales and how we react to sales and continue to drive
componenttext: As we move into the back half of the year, they tend to be, the margins, as well as most of the P&L, tends to be a little bit more predictable. Now obviously as we work our way through the quarter and sales and how we react to sales and continue to drive sales, obviously, we can have an impact. But really as we look year-over-year, there is not any significant aberrations from last year that we're going to be comping. So I would say generally, relatively consistent. We look to see that in both quarters, we anticipate improving our gross margin which will help us drive the EBIT margin improvement for the overall company and in the back half of the year.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just slightly higher gross margins both in the third and fourth quarters?
componenttext: Just slightly higher gross margins both in the third and fourth quarters?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then on the expense line, I mean that is one thing that has changed quite a bit over the last 3 years. Not only has sales but a little bit as you pulled back your square footage and as you've lost the very significant benefit of inflation that you had
componenttext: And then on the expense line, I mean that is one thing that has changed quite a bit over the last 3 years. Not only has sales but a little bit as you pulled back your square footage and as you've lost the very significant benefit of inflation that you had several years ago. But your SG&A is now running up closer to 10% a year versus maybe 6%, 7%, 8%, 9% a year and then that's converged with sales, so obviously, there's a need to continue to invest in the business. But at the same time, so where is the though process around what can be done perhaps to try and get a little bit more of a greater spread between sales dollar growth and SG&A dollar growth?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: True. We continuously look at the cost savings initiatives. And in actuality, we feel that we've been very successful, one, in managing headcount both of the Store Support Center and in the stores and you can see that in Q2 in particular as we really mana
componenttext: True. We continuously look at the cost savings initiatives. And in actuality, we feel that we've been very successful, one, in managing headcount both of the Store Support Center and in the stores and you can see that in Q2 in particular as we really manage the payroll expense and the variability relative to the softer sales. And we have some key initiatives looking at all levels of expense structure. So when you look at the increase of -- we believe that it really is very focused on growth areas and areas that we need to make investments in. And as I alluded to in our prepared remarks, as much as we only ran about a 6% increase year-over-year net of the incentive compensation, we do expect as we continue to move forward to be in somewhere in the 9% to 10% range of -- consistent with our growth in sales in particular because of some of the investments that we made last year that we're cycling in particular the Arizona distribution center and the mixing centers.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess this is longer-term though, at least where you stand right now, it's sort of just perpetuity investment mode, is that the way to think about it?
componenttext: I guess this is longer-term though, at least where you stand right now, it's sort of just perpetuity investment mode, is that the way to think about it?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I wouldn't necessarily say perpetuity but as we continue to grow the chain obviously a fairly significant of 110 to 120 stores, we're going to continue to invest in the infrastructure and that's where the majority of the dollars are going.
componenttext: Yes. I wouldn't necessarily say perpetuity but as we continue to grow the chain obviously a fairly significant of 110 to 120 stores, we're going to continue to invest in the infrastructure and that's where the majority of the dollars are going.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Eric Bosshard with Cleveland Research.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Eric Bosshard with Cleveland Research.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two things. First of all, from a competitive standpoint, I'm just curious from a competitive standpoint if you're seeing anything different, if you're seeing challenges or opportunities in that regard that you sort of look forward to pursuing.
componenttext: Two things. First of all, from a competitive standpoint, I'm just curious from a competitive standpoint if you're seeing anything different, if you're seeing challenges or opportunities in that regard that you sort of look forward to pursuing.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric, are you talking about, let me say competitive, other farm stores competitors in particular?
componenttext: Eric, are you talking about, let me say competitive, other farm stores competitors in particular?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: You can say farm store or where else your customers may acquire the product that they get at your store.
componenttext: You can say farm store or where else your customers may acquire the product that they get at your store.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say to you that from a competitive standpoint, I think the overall farm community or farm business is probably fairly healthy from a retail standpoint. And we're opening stores and markets where competitions at vice versa, they're opening a f
componenttext: Yes. I would say to you that from a competitive standpoint, I think the overall farm community or farm business is probably fairly healthy from a retail standpoint. And we're opening stores and markets where competitions at vice versa, they're opening a few in our markets. And we have plans and I'll call it tactics to challenge that and offset that. So we're not seeing any real competitive intrusion to any great degree, anything different than we've seen in the past. One of the things we don't and will not do is go out and try to buy sales for the short-term. Steve mentioned earlier that we're going to look at all the ways that we can be in front of our customer with our mix and the brand itself. But the more stores that we put out there in the landscape, the more often and more chances we have to win customers over. So I think our plans as we go forward are solid. I think our store expansion strategy is solid and there is not that competitive intrusion that's causing any issues for us at this point.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, just to understand from a big ticket standpoint, obviously, diluted to the second quarter comps, do you expect big ticket to run below the average comp in the third quarter as well?
componenttext: And then secondly, just to understand from a big ticket standpoint, obviously, diluted to the second quarter comps, do you expect big ticket to run below the average comp in the third quarter as well?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's probably pretty difficult for us to project. Being the optimistic retailers, we wanted to take each one of our categories and drive our comp increase in each one of those categories. As we look at the back half, it tends to be less sensitive to big
componenttext: That's probably pretty difficult for us to project. Being the optimistic retailers, we wanted to take each one of our categories and drive our comp increase in each one of those categories. As we look at the back half, it tends to be less sensitive to big ticket. However, as we saw last December, there, we do have some big ticket items. Our focus is going to be to continue to drive value. And as Greg has indicated, our core business has been very strong. So are going to pertain to emphasize in those key categories that will drive footsteps. And hopefully, as we get those customers into the store, we'll be able to get them to create a bigger basket and drive the comp sales in the back half of the year.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just one last point. In terms of core categories being strong which is great to hear, anything within the core categories that have slowed a little bit relative to where they were previous year is that sort of other than big ticket everything els
componenttext: And then just one last point. In terms of core categories being strong which is great to hear, anything within the core categories that have slowed a little bit relative to where they were previous year is that sort of other than big ticket everything else is running where it's been?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Eric, this is Steve. I would tell you that the business continues to be pretty strong in a lot of those basic core businesses. And Tony, I believe, talked about it in his prepared remarks, we continue to see big growth in the animal side of our busin
componenttext: Yes, Eric, this is Steve. I would tell you that the business continues to be pretty strong in a lot of those basic core businesses. And Tony, I believe, talked about it in his prepared remarks, we continue to see big growth in the animal side of our business across all species. And so I don't see a slowdown there whatsoever. I think we continue to invest in those businesses and our assortments, our prices and our in-stock and we're seeing the traction and the benefit of those investments.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we do have a final question for Seth Basham with Wedbush Securities.
componenttext: And we do have a final question for Seth Basham with Wedbush Securities.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: With The business now bouncing back as much as it historically has in June, July with the levels in late spring, is that bounce more limited in the big ticket or in the quarter consumables part of the business?
componenttext: With The business now bouncing back as much as it historically has in June, July with the levels in late spring, is that bounce more limited in the big ticket or in the quarter consumables part of the business?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's clearly was not in the big ticket categories and one of the things you need to understand about our business is that there's a cycle and timing to this. And when you get past a certain point, our customers and they will say to us, it's too late in th
componenttext: It's clearly was not in the big ticket categories and one of the things you need to understand about our business is that there's a cycle and timing to this. And when you get past a certain point, our customers and they will say to us, it's too late in the season now to buy that X product. I'll wait now until next year. And we have heard that in a number of instances and as we've been out in the stores ourselves, so that really is the culprit right there.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: As you assess to move into sign ]more kayaks and more ATVs based on what you experienced this season, is it something that you continue to expect to repeat next year or you changed the merchandising plan around those types of outdoor rec categories?
componenttext: As you assess to move into sign ]more kayaks and more ATVs based on what you experienced this season, is it something that you continue to expect to repeat next year or you changed the merchandising plan around those types of outdoor rec categories?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Steve. Well, we have a challenging overall top line. I would tell you that there were a lot of gems in the quarter. We talked about a lot what we did about gardening and organics sustainability. We saw a lot of growth there, we saw a lot of g
componenttext: Yes, this is Steve. Well, we have a challenging overall top line. I would tell you that there were a lot of gems in the quarter. We talked about a lot what we did about gardening and organics sustainability. We saw a lot of growth there, we saw a lot of growth in our Chick Days event and a lot of what we're doing there as well. When it comes to what we're doing with our outdoor rec, we saw nice growth. Our kayak business really drove a lot of incremental units and top line sales there. So there's a lot of things in the box that are working incredibly well and I know that gets overshadowed by the overall top line sales for the quarter. But I would be remiss if I didn't say a lot of that as well as our core business being a strong in the foot traffic coming in for those categories. So again, overall, when you look at the quarter, it was a miss. I think we're all disappointed by that but at the same time, we can build on those the things that really work this year for next year in this category is that suffer this year a little bit, will have a plan to reconcile.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Mr. Sanford, there are no further questions. I'll turn the call back to you for closing remarks.
componenttext: And Mr. Sanford, there are no further questions. I'll turn the call back to you for closing remarks.

componenttext: Okay. Thank you, all, for your continued support and your interest in Tractor Supply and we look forward to speaking to you again in October regarding our third quarter performance.
