componenttextpreview: Sure, Chris. This is Tony. When we look at the last 3 quarters, their performance relative to the control group has been relatively consistent. So the impact on the comps has been, again, relatively consistent for the last 3 quarters. As we move forward,
componenttext: Sure, Chris. This is Tony. When we look at the last 3 quarters, their performance relative to the control group has been relatively consistent. So the impact on the comps has been, again, relatively consistent for the last 3 quarters. As we move forward, we will start cycling in. And I agree with what you said that we really started to see sort of that fall-off in the third and fourth quarters. So as much as we do anticipate that it will moderate, we do believe that it will still be a drag in the back half of the year, but not to the extent that it has been in the first half.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Simeon Gutman with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Simeon Gutman with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Were there any undertones that discretionary spending is slowing or the weather just make it very difficult to judge that?
componenttext: Were there any undertones that discretionary spending is slowing or the weather just make it very difficult to judge that?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Simeon, let me take that one. I would tell you that what we saw in the second quarter, we could directly tie that back to the weather and how it slowed the development of some of the businesses. We had a very favorable end of March. And it seems like as s
componenttext: Simeon, let me take that one. I would tell you that what we saw in the second quarter, we could directly tie that back to the weather and how it slowed the development of some of the businesses. We had a very favorable end of March. And it seems like as soon as we got -- and we had that early Easter shift. And it looked like we had a bit of a reversal in trends, all of a sudden, in April and May versus where we were at the end of March. And we started seeing some pullback a little bit on big ticket because we had seen a good pull forward at the end of first quarter. So we thought, well, that's just going to be a trade-off between a couple of months. But as we said in the 29th update, we really haven't seen anything significant with the customers' use of credit or shift to spending and so on and so forth at this point. It's fundamentally they're still buying the things they need, they're still shopping for us, our traffic counts are up. So it was a bit of a tough pill to swallow when we saw the business just not developed and then, again, a little warmness in June and we saw a nice push again in the business. So it's just a very unusual, but no, I can't say that we have anything that would give us any indication that there's some current trend with the consumer because we would have seen some of the signals, and we haven't seen it. Our core business couldn't be stronger.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my follow-up on inventory's gross margin. Tony made a comment regarding third quarter that's there's not a big transitional quarter, a big markdown quarter. I guess, you're not getting the pickup in seasonal July. One, is there some carryov
componenttext: Okay. And then my follow-up on inventory's gross margin. Tony made a comment regarding third quarter that's there's not a big transitional quarter, a big markdown quarter. I guess, you're not getting the pickup in seasonal July. One, is there some carryover from those items? And then if we do see some -- when we talk in the third quarter, if we do hear that there was some markdown, what would explain that? Our markdown during the quarter, what would have explained that? Or is that just likely out of the question?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Simeon, Steve Barbarick here. I thought the team did a really nice job managing to the demands of the business. And we saw that early, and we were able to pull back in a lot of the ordering. And our seasonal inventories are in a great position right now f
componenttext: Simeon, Steve Barbarick here. I thought the team did a really nice job managing to the demands of the business. And we saw that early, and we were able to pull back in a lot of the ordering. And our seasonal inventories are in a great position right now for spring. So I have very little concern about markdown or clearance going into the third quarter or fourth quarter for spring product.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Ben Bienvenu with Stephens Inc.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Ben Bienvenu with Stephens Inc.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just following on that question as it relates to inventory and some of the variability that we've seen around weather. Has there been any deviation or evolution in the number of resets that you anticipate to do for the fall selling period? Or do you an
componenttext: So just following on that question as it relates to inventory and some of the variability that we've seen around weather. Has there been any deviation or evolution in the number of resets that you anticipate to do for the fall selling period? Or do you anticipate sticking with that traditional reset cadence?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We went back and we looked at what we're doing in the back half of this year and looked at the categories that may be most impacted, that we think that our customers still have a lot of demand for. And we've modified our approach slightly, but it's really
componenttext: We went back and we looked at what we're doing in the back half of this year and looked at the categories that may be most impacted, that we think that our customers still have a lot of demand for. And we've modified our approach slightly, but it's really around some key areas. And I feel really good about the reset work that we're going to be doing. So it is around a lot of the C.U.E. merchandise. But in addition to that, we went back, we've reset our stores for footwear and leather and in rubber. We've got heating resets that are going to be taking place and assortment adjustments there as well. So generally, when you look across the 4 walls, I feel very confident that the work the team's doing is going to be in line with what we're seeing our customer demand for.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then you touched in the past on some ammo [ph] tests in a handful of stores. I'd be curious to hear how that's progressing. And then any change in thought process either around extending the number of stores that offer that SKU set and/or
componenttext: Okay, great. And then you touched in the past on some ammo [ph] tests in a handful of stores. I'd be curious to hear how that's progressing. And then any change in thought process either around extending the number of stores that offer that SKU set and/or potentially adding firearms of some kind to your assortment?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would tell you, at this point, it's still early in the test. It's in 25 stores, and we're getting some results now. We still need to dissect it and determine whether or not it meets our threshold for being a successful test so that it would roll fo
componenttext: Yes. I would tell you, at this point, it's still early in the test. It's in 25 stores, and we're getting some results now. We still need to dissect it and determine whether or not it meets our threshold for being a successful test so that it would roll forward in more stores. In terms of firearms, it's way too early in the game to even talk about that. So I leave that for a future date.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Peter Keith with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Peter Keith with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just look at the mix dynamic in Q2. As far back as I can remember when you've had these late springs or colder springs, you usually have had this mix benefit because of the lower OPE sales. It seems like there was a bit of a change here in Q2,
componenttext: I wanted to just look at the mix dynamic in Q2. As far back as I can remember when you've had these late springs or colder springs, you usually have had this mix benefit because of the lower OPE sales. It seems like there was a bit of a change here in Q2, and you identified there was some higher-margin items. Could you just maybe provide some more specifics there and anything that kind of surprised you on the weakness?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. When it comes to the bigger ticket, we definitely had a benefit, in particular, when it came to the riding mower category. So the softer sales in that category did help margin because it is well below chain average. When we look at some of the other
componenttext: Sure. When it comes to the bigger ticket, we definitely had a benefit, in particular, when it came to the riding mower category. So the softer sales in that category did help margin because it is well below chain average. When we look at some of the other key departments, obviously, the first thing that comes to mind is the strength of the C.U.E. items, in particular, the animal feed and pet food, which have just a slightly below chain average margin. But that strength obviously delevers on margin. So that had a negative impact. And then when you look at some of the other spring items that are higher margin, that were soft as well, and even some of the other hard line items, the softness in those sales, we didn't obviously pick up the margin there as well. So those 2 factors offset the benefit that we get on the larger ticket hard line category.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And anything there, in that last comment, Tony, that was different from previous cold springs?
componenttext: And anything there, in that last comment, Tony, that was different from previous cold springs?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Generally, we would have some key categories of spring that would sell well. In this case, some of those categories, we didn't get that lift. So we would generally get some offset. And so it just -- we just didn't have the same lift that we would get from
componenttext: Generally, we would have some key categories of spring that would sell well. In this case, some of those categories, we didn't get that lift. So we would generally get some offset. And so it just -- we just didn't have the same lift that we would get from the other higher key categories. I know Steve has some comments that he would like to make.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. A year ago, when we were sitting here talking about the strength of the business, a lot of it was driven by seasonal, and a lot of it was driven -- we had a new OPE lineup. We saw demand across the board in trailers and a lot of other categories. And
componenttext: Yes. A year ago, when we were sitting here talking about the strength of the business, a lot of it was driven by seasonal, and a lot of it was driven -- we had a new OPE lineup. We saw demand across the board in trailers and a lot of other categories. And we were comping that this year, in all fairness. And to your stack, I think you'd feel really good about, but unfortunately, we are comping ourselves and we -- that's what we need to be doing, and we didn't do it like we should have this quarter. But if you looked at the totality of the business, it's still strong, there are some very strong fundamentals in the business, but we are lapping what was a very robust Q2 last year in the seasonal category.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. Steve, while I have you, too, so you've mentioned you've rolled out the new and improved inventory allocation system. Do you have any early wins or insights you could share? And how might that benefit the back half of the year?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. Steve, while I have you, too, so you've mentioned you've rolled out the new and improved inventory allocation system. Do you have any early wins or insights you could share? And how might that benefit the back half of the year?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's rolled out now to the entire team. And I would tell you, I really do think it's going to have a positive impact on the business. It's really going to help us mainly with things like end caps, event merchandise, a lot of the seasonal builds, both
componenttext: Yes. It's rolled out now to the entire team. And I would tell you, I really do think it's going to have a positive impact on the business. It's really going to help us mainly with things like end caps, event merchandise, a lot of the seasonal builds, both initial and end of season. And those are the ones that are going to get the greatest benefits. And talking with the team, we believe we'll see a lot of those benefits in Q4 because the work we're doing right now is going to have that impact.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Stephen Tanal with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Stephen Tanal with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the one thing I was trying to sort of understand on the weather, if we think about that $25 million pull forward into 1Q and sort of normalize for that, it's about 140 bps, I think, to 2Q, and you kind of add it in, pull it out of 1Q and it does actual
componenttext: So the one thing I was trying to sort of understand on the weather, if we think about that $25 million pull forward into 1Q and sort of normalize for that, it's about 140 bps, I think, to 2Q, and you kind of add it in, pull it out of 1Q and it does actually look like the underlying rate slowed. Is that a fair way to think about it? Or do you think that doesn't really capture the entire seasonal effect? And if you could maybe just give us a number, an all-in number on the weather impact for 2Q. If you guys have something in your head, that would be pretty helpful, too.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Stephen, I think what you're referring to is if you try to normalize, looking at the pull forward and you push that through and kind of work the numbers, that I think what you're saying is, did we see a bit of a slowdown in second quarter just in general
componenttext: Stephen, I think what you're referring to is if you try to normalize, looking at the pull forward and you push that through and kind of work the numbers, that I think what you're saying is, did we see a bit of a slowdown in second quarter just in general from what we saw in first quarter in sale, if we did that.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, x the weather, like the core kind of trend rate here.
componenttext: Yes, x the weather, like the core kind of trend rate here.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, with the slowdown that we did see was, again, in the big ticket categories. No question. That was part of it. But we believe that, that was due to the fact that the weather just was not complementary for selling those kinds of products. Our customer
componenttext: Well, with the slowdown that we did see was, again, in the big ticket categories. No question. That was part of it. But we believe that, that was due to the fact that the weather just was not complementary for selling those kinds of products. Our customers, as you know, buy very much to need. And so when we looked at that, we did some normalization of our own with the numbers. Those big ticket categories are riding lawnmowers, as Steve mentioned, and a few other categories, UTVs, which were very robust a year ago at this time, did not anniversary themselves.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. But just to be clear, is the big ticket impact part of that $25 million or not?
componenttext: Understood. But just to be clear, is the big ticket impact part of that $25 million or not?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Some, but not...
componenttext: Some, but not...

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It definitely is.
componenttext: It definitely is.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes.
componenttext: Yes, yes.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We got off to a very strong rider season in March, and so we clearly had anticipated that rolling through into Q2.
componenttext: We got off to a very strong rider season in March, and so we clearly had anticipated that rolling through into Q2.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: But it didn't roll through.
componenttext: But it didn't roll through.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: But it didn't. And as we stated in the prepared remarks, big ticket was down 8% and, in particular, after being very strong in the March time frame. So you can adjust the month, but still, the trend was a very consistent to the overall trends, where April
componenttext: But it didn't. And as we stated in the prepared remarks, big ticket was down 8% and, in particular, after being very strong in the March time frame. So you can adjust the month, but still, the trend was a very consistent to the overall trends, where April and May were softer than June.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. And just lastly, and as we think about kind of the weather, obviously, a big comp because of everything that's happening. It's been hot, which I think is generally good, but it's also been dry. And I think in June, we typically like wetter w
componenttext: Okay. Got it. And just lastly, and as we think about kind of the weather, obviously, a big comp because of everything that's happening. It's been hot, which I think is generally good, but it's also been dry. And I think in June, we typically like wetter weather. And to be honest, I'm not sure what we root for in July. Does the dryness hurt you? Do you want it to be wetter in general? Or how should we think about weather just high-level?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, for the most part, we do prefer wet because things will continue to grow, and it's a continuation of spring. But when you look at the moisture generally throughout the springtime, we've had good moisture throughout. So as we move into the summer, it
componenttext: Well, for the most part, we do prefer wet because things will continue to grow, and it's a continuation of spring. But when you look at the moisture generally throughout the springtime, we've had good moisture throughout. So as we move into the summer, it shouldn't be a significant impact. Obviously, when you look at the drought map, tends to be a little bit in sort of the Southwest and the California area. But because there's too much rain in, say, the Texas area, the heat is good because it helps dries out a little bit sooner. But generally, we look for moisture. It will be a positive thing as we move through the year.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just last one for me, if there's any update you could share on sort of the inbound freight issues with the Casa Grande. Have you made some headway with the vendors? Or have you switched up vendors? How's that going?
componenttext: Great. And just last one for me, if there's any update you could share on sort of the inbound freight issues with the Casa Grande. Have you made some headway with the vendors? Or have you switched up vendors? How's that going?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Steve. This is going to be an ongoing challenge for our merchant team and our sourcing team, to continue to bring new folks on. We have made some headway in that, but when you're talking about as many product categories as we carry and 70-plus per
componenttext: This is Steve. This is going to be an ongoing challenge for our merchant team and our sourcing team, to continue to bring new folks on. We have made some headway in that, but when you're talking about as many product categories as we carry and 70-plus percent of those go through our network, this is not a one and done kind of scenario. So we are making headway. We've got about another 20 or 30 vendors that we're looking at right now in terms to either resource or find secondary vendors out west to be able to reduce those stem miles.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Scott Mushkin with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Scott Mushkin with Wolfe Research.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Chris Bottiglieri on for Scott Mushkin. Our first question was, taking a step back, you guys have -- obviously, it's a very strong track record, but it seems more recently, the annual comp algorithm has kind of slowed a bit. So, one, kind of putti
componenttext: This is Chris Bottiglieri on for Scott Mushkin. Our first question was, taking a step back, you guys have -- obviously, it's a very strong track record, but it seems more recently, the annual comp algorithm has kind of slowed a bit. So, one, kind of putting weather aside in the last couple of quarters, but in the last couple of years, like why do you think this is happening? And then as a follow-up, like do you think that your current growth initiatives can lead to reaccelerated comp [indiscernible] looking forward? Or are you kind of comfortable in this range?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chris, let me start with that. Tony will probably jump in. I've been with the company now -- I'll be 9 years in November. And I would say that the last 4 had been the most interesting from a standpoint of the mix of our products, when things were selling,
componenttext: Chris, let me start with that. Tony will probably jump in. I've been with the company now -- I'll be 9 years in November. And I would say that the last 4 had been the most interesting from a standpoint of the mix of our products, when things were selling, when things peaked, introductions of newness and so on. But I can't underestimate and we used to -- I think that we could control more things around some of the weather patterning across the country. But as we've gotten now into 49 states, and that store dispersion is a good thing generally, I would tell you that it makes it more challenging for us to understand sometimes how these ebb and flows will affect the overall business on an annual basis. We typically can work our way through some of these slight, if you call it, troubled spots where we have, I will say, less-than-ideal weather and less-than-ideal conditions for selling certain products. But we're in a new learning curve here, I believe, as we look at some of these things moving forward. And the team has done some great work as we forecast forward through the second half and into next year. And I'm convinced that we can kind of push this thing back on this growth trajectory that is kind of expected from Tractor. I mean, we're a test and learn company. We learn all the time. There's no lack of newness, as Steve mentioned earlier. We continue to introduce new products, and those are things that really drive all the footsteps. And then we're getting far better at this localization component, and that's going to be a key as we go forward because that helps us defend ourselves when conditions are less than ideal for selling some products. I can't reiterate enough, our customers buy to demand or to need. They don't buy early, and they haven't been for a long time.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I'll just add that over my 11 years here, we don't necessarily see what the next silver bullet is going to be, but being the test and learn, we're constantly coming up with really good ideas and products. And we let our customer dictate what the next
componenttext: And I'll just add that over my 11 years here, we don't necessarily see what the next silver bullet is going to be, but being the test and learn, we're constantly coming up with really good ideas and products. And we let our customer dictate what the next best item is going to be. But when it comes to the model itself, generally, our forecasting is always in the 3% to 5% range. We don't need to reach the high-single-digit comps anymore to have a really successful year. And so as we look out, we think that the model will work just terrifically at the 3% to 5% comp level.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one brief follow-up about the C.O.E. strategy. How much do you think is left in there? Like what inning do you think we're in? If you benchmark yourself to the industry, like talking to your suppliers, are you taking share there? Like do you think yo
componenttext: Just one brief follow-up about the C.O.E. strategy. How much do you think is left in there? Like what inning do you think we're in? If you benchmark yourself to the industry, like talking to your suppliers, are you taking share there? Like do you think your customers have adopted the premium brand in the space yet? Like kind of what's left there you think in the C.O.E. like the next, call it, 3 to 5 years?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Steve. We still see more opportunity here, and we've seen continued growth over the last several years. And it's really driving footsteps into our stores. Our focus is really around being priced right. It's about having the right inventories,
componenttext: Yes, this is Steve. We still see more opportunity here, and we've seen continued growth over the last several years. And it's really driving footsteps into our stores. Our focus is really around being priced right. It's about having the right inventories, and it's about expanding our assortments. And we've continued to do that very well. I still think that there's upside and a lot of momentum here that we still have. Depending upon the category you look at, I'll use -- if you benchmark maybe our overall pet business versus industry, I think if you looked at that, you would probably say we're outstripping and indexing higher than industry, and therefore, you would have to make the assumption that you are taking share. If you look at our feed business, I would tell you, based on what we hear from our suppliers, there's a good likelihood that we're taking market share there as well. And you could go across the 4 walls, whether it'd be in lubricants, whether it'd be in lawn and garden or other categories such as betting, and I think we continue to do a nice job, offering a great assortment that has the right in-stock at great value prices for our customers every day. So I still think that there's a more upside here.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Chuck Cerankosky with Northcoast Research.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Chuck Cerankosky with Northcoast Research.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a real quick question on the big ticket items in this most recent quarter. Are there attached products that went missing because somebody wasn't buying an ATV, say, a trailer or hitches, things like that, that took away from the total sales beyond ju
componenttext: Just a real quick question on the big ticket items in this most recent quarter. Are there attached products that went missing because somebody wasn't buying an ATV, say, a trailer or hitches, things like that, that took away from the total sales beyond just a big ticket merchandise?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Steve. And that's a great question because when you talk seasonal, there's a lot of attachments that come with OPE, there's a lot of replacement parts and whatnot. And we saw a relative softness across many of those compared to a year prior's
componenttext: Yes, this is Steve. And that's a great question because when you talk seasonal, there's a lot of attachments that come with OPE, there's a lot of replacement parts and whatnot. And we saw a relative softness across many of those compared to a year prior's strong comp store sales there. So many of those attachments and accessories do carry a little higher margin. That was a question asked earlier. And we did see those sales be soft over the course of the second quarter.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Dan Wewer with Raymond James.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Dan Wewer with Raymond James.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, the way that those 3 measures in the store productivity began to weaken a bit about a year ago, I know that from your perspective, there really hasn't been much change. But based on the publicly available information, that's how the number shake out
componenttext: Greg, the way that those 3 measures in the store productivity began to weaken a bit about a year ago, I know that from your perspective, there really hasn't been much change. But based on the publicly available information, that's how the number shake out. And then a few quarters after that, we saw the weakness, the negative comps in the fourth quarter last year and now another negative quarter. Is there any concern from your part that perhaps some of the weaker new store openings could be a leading indicator of, call it, saturation and that could be contributing to this current sales trend?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, what I can tell you is the facts. No question, when we first opened in the western markets, we saw some weakness there in a few markets, and that drag for about 1 year to 18 months was there. But the process we use in finding and aligning new stores
componenttext: Dan, what I can tell you is the facts. No question, when we first opened in the western markets, we saw some weakness there in a few markets, and that drag for about 1 year to 18 months was there. But the process we use in finding and aligning new stores and how we plan for cannibalization in this, we are seeing a more normalization again. We are seeing stores performing back to that level. And on a year-over-year basis, the run rates are very similar. So we did have a little period of time there when it was, gee, what happened and we looked at it and it was really very concentrated in really the Utah market. So no, we're not seeing new store productivity sliding. As a matter fact, it's as good today as it was a few years back. But we did have a little blip in there, and I think we got to -- we've worked our way through that.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The second question I have revolves around Revionics and your pricing optimization. You've been very bullish about the benefit to gross margin rate. In light of the recent sales trends, have you taken a fresh look at elasticity of demand and perhaps come
componenttext: The second question I have revolves around Revionics and your pricing optimization. You've been very bullish about the benefit to gross margin rate. In light of the recent sales trends, have you taken a fresh look at elasticity of demand and perhaps come to the conclusion, perhaps we squeeze about as much out of pricing as we can and, in fact, maybe there is a case that can be made for [indiscernible] promotional, which sounds like you did during the quarter?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dan, this is Steve. I mean, the pricing tools that we use in regular price are ongoing, and they give us recommendations based on demand by area of the country. So we're constantly looking and fine-tuning that, challenging it ourselves. And where we
componenttext: Yes, Dan, this is Steve. I mean, the pricing tools that we use in regular price are ongoing, and they give us recommendations based on demand by area of the country. So we're constantly looking and fine-tuning that, challenging it ourselves. And where we have upside, we take it up. And where we think we need to be more aggressive, we'll move those prices down. So from that perspective, I think that there's still more we can get out of the tools. As a matter of fact, we just recently extended our contract with Revionics because we continue to see value there. In addition to that, the clearance module that we use has still been very effective for us and helping us work our way through a lot of that product while it's still in home before it gets moved and try to move it through while we're still in season. Our units in terms of SKU products, we're still seeing strong comp store units movement, and we really track units as much as we do sales in many cases. Now you've heard the last couple of years, we have seen some deflation there, so we've got some headwinds to overcome. But generally speaking, I still think that there is some more opportunity for us in using that tool.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just real quickly on the comments about July, we've known that the year-over-year comparison would be difficult for 12 months. In fact, as I recall, July of 2014 was a very strong month for Tractor Supply as well. So based on your comments about
componenttext: Okay. And just real quickly on the comments about July, we've known that the year-over-year comparison would be difficult for 12 months. In fact, as I recall, July of 2014 was a very strong month for Tractor Supply as well. So based on your comments about the first 2 weeks of July of 2016, are you saying they're weak but that's exactly the way it was budgeted? Or is the company communicating -- we knew it was going to be a tough comparison, and even taking that into account, we're running below where we thought we would be?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, this is Tony. Let me answer that one. What we're saying is that we did not see a shift of sales, spring sales from Q2 into Q3. And so we're not making a statement one way or the other relative to the performance to our expectations or comparison to c
componenttext: Dan, this is Tony. Let me answer that one. What we're saying is that we did not see a shift of sales, spring sales from Q2 into Q3. And so we're not making a statement one way or the other relative to the performance to our expectations or comparison to comps of last year. I will say -- and I would say I'm in agreement with you. We've had 3 very strong Julys in a row. And obviously, when we look out and we forecast, we would forecast July not to be the strongest of the 3 months in the quarter.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So your cautiousness, this reflects the fact that you're not recovering the sales lost in April and May, but you're not necessarily saying that the current run rate is below plan, that simply, you're not making up for the ground that was lost?
componenttext: So your cautiousness, this reflects the fact that you're not recovering the sales lost in April and May, but you're not necessarily saying that the current run rate is below plan, that simply, you're not making up for the ground that was lost?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll go next to Scot Ciccarelli with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go next to Scot Ciccarelli with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tony, you referenced earlier and you said in the past, that a wet spring should be good for 3Q trends because it does extend the growing season. Are you expecting any benefit from that -- this, call it, 3 -- third quarter? Or is something different this y
componenttext: Tony, you referenced earlier and you said in the past, that a wet spring should be good for 3Q trends because it does extend the growing season. Are you expecting any benefit from that -- this, call it, 3 -- third quarter? Or is something different this year?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. As we say, we had anticipated that -- with the moisture and with the slow start to the spring, that it would be a delayed spring and would continue into Q3. But since we did not experience that bounce back in June, we were very cautious and did not an
componenttext: No. As we say, we had anticipated that -- with the moisture and with the slow start to the spring, that it would be a delayed spring and would continue into Q3. But since we did not experience that bounce back in June, we were very cautious and did not anticipate extending out. So yes, it is a little bit different than what we've seen in the past. But we did not expect any additional spring sales in the July, August time frame.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: But haven't you discussed in the past that more moisture in the ground actually helps you kind of throughout the balance of 3Q? Or am I misunderstanding that?
componenttext: But haven't you discussed in the past that more moisture in the ground actually helps you kind of throughout the balance of 3Q? Or am I misunderstanding that?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think that's correct. And again, as we saw throughout the quarter, with the softness in sales as well as the big ticket being soft as well as having the last sort of 3 years of strong Q3, in particular, strong July, August, it's just -- it's a more
componenttext: No, I think that's correct. And again, as we saw throughout the quarter, with the softness in sales as well as the big ticket being soft as well as having the last sort of 3 years of strong Q3, in particular, strong July, August, it's just -- it's a more difficult comparison.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Adam Sindler with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Adam Sindler with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a focus on margins for a couple of minutes here. As we look through the second half of the year, what are the major puts and takes in the gross margin line in the third and fourth quarters? Is it more the impact of inbound freights on C.U.E. on the W
componenttext: Just a focus on margins for a couple of minutes here. As we look through the second half of the year, what are the major puts and takes in the gross margin line in the third and fourth quarters? Is it more the impact of inbound freights on C.U.E. on the West Coast, D.C.? Is it mix? Just as we think about how the weather plays out, what are the different things we should try and think about?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: As we move into the back half of the year, they tend to be -- the margins as well as most of the P&L tends to be a little bit more predictable. Now obviously, as we work our way through the quarter and sales and how we react to sales and continue to drive
componenttext: As we move into the back half of the year, they tend to be -- the margins as well as most of the P&L tends to be a little bit more predictable. Now obviously, as we work our way through the quarter and sales and how we react to sales and continue to drive sales, obviously, can have an impact. But really, as we look year-over-year, there is not any significant aberrations from last year that we're going to be comping. So I would say generally, relatively consistent. We look to see that in both quarters, we anticipate improving our gross margin, which will help us drive the EBIT margin improvement for the overall company and in the back half of the year.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So slightly higher gross margins both in the third and fourth quarters?
componenttext: So slightly higher gross margins both in the third and fourth quarters?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the expense line, I mean, so that is one thing that really sort of has changed quite a bit over the last 3 years, not only has sales, but a little bit as you pulled back your square footage and as you've lost the very significant benefit
componenttext: Okay. And then on the expense line, I mean, so that is one thing that really sort of has changed quite a bit over the last 3 years, not only has sales, but a little bit as you pulled back your square footage and as you've lost the very significant benefit of inflation that you had several years ago. But your SG&A is now running up closer to 10% a year versus maybe 6%, 7%, 8%, 9% a year, and that has converged with sales. So obviously, there's a need to continue to invest in the business. But at the same time, sort of what is the thought process around what can be done perhaps to try and get a little bit of a greater spread between sales, dollar growth and SG&A dollar growth?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We continuously look at cost savings initiatives. And in actuality, we feel that we've been very successful, one, in managing headcount both at the Store Support Center and in the stores, and you can see that in Q2 in particular as we really manage
componenttext: Sure. We continuously look at cost savings initiatives. And in actuality, we feel that we've been very successful, one, in managing headcount both at the Store Support Center and in the stores, and you can see that in Q2 in particular as we really manage the payroll expense and the variability relative to the softer sales. And we have some key initiatives looking at all levels of expense structure. So when you look at the increase, we believe that it really is very focused on growth areas and areas that we need to make investment in. And as I alluded to in our prepared remarks, as much as we only ran about a 6% increase year-over-year, net of the incentive compensation, we do expect, as we continue to move forward, to be in -- somewhere in the 9% to 10% range, consistent with our growth in sales, in particular, because some of the investments that we made last year that we're cycling, in particular, the Arizona distribution center and the mixing centers.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, longer-term though, they're never -- at least as you stand right now, it's sort of just perpetuity investment mode. Is that the way to think about it?
componenttext: I guess, longer-term though, they're never -- at least as you stand right now, it's sort of just perpetuity investment mode. Is that the way to think about it?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I wouldn't necessarily say perpetuity, but as we continue to grow the chain at obviously a fairly significant clip of 110 to 120 stores, we're going to continue to invest in the infrastructure, and that's where the majority of the dollars are going.
componenttext: Yes. I wouldn't necessarily say perpetuity, but as we continue to grow the chain at obviously a fairly significant clip of 110 to 120 stores, we're going to continue to invest in the infrastructure, and that's where the majority of the dollars are going.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Eric Bosshard with Cleveland Research.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Eric Bosshard with Cleveland Research.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two things. First of all, from a competitive standpoint, Greg I think you've mentioned localization opportunities there, I'm just curious from a competitive standpoint, if you're seeing anything different, if you're seeing challenges or opportunities in t
componenttext: Two things. First of all, from a competitive standpoint, Greg I think you've mentioned localization opportunities there, I'm just curious from a competitive standpoint, if you're seeing anything different, if you're seeing challenges or opportunities in that regard that you sort of look forward to pursuing.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric, are you talking about -- let me say competitive, you mean other farm store competitors in particular?
componenttext: Eric, are you talking about -- let me say competitive, you mean other farm store competitors in particular?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: You could say farm store or broaden it, basically, where else your customers may acquire the product they get at your store.
componenttext: You could say farm store or broaden it, basically, where else your customers may acquire the product they get at your store.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say to you that from a competitive standpoint, I think the overall farm community or farm business is probably fairly healthy from a retail standpoint. And we're opening stores in markets where the competition is at. Vice versa, they're openi
componenttext: Yes. I would say to you that from a competitive standpoint, I think the overall farm community or farm business is probably fairly healthy from a retail standpoint. And we're opening stores in markets where the competition is at. Vice versa, they're opening a few in our markets. And we have plans, and I'll call it tactics, to challenge that and offset that. So we're not seeing any real competitive intrusion to any great degree, anything different than we've seen in the past. One of the things we don't and will not do is go out and try to buy sales for the short term. Steve mentioned earlier that we're going to look at all the ways that we can be in front of our customer with our mix and the brand itself. But the more stores that we put out there in the landscape, the more often and more chances we have to win customers over. So I think our plans as we go forward are solid. I think our store expansion strategy is solid. And there's not a competitive intrusion that's causing any issues for us at this point.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, just to understand, from a big ticket standpoint, obviously, dilutive to the second quarter comp. Do you expect big ticket to run below the average comp in the third quarter as well?
componenttext: And then secondly, just to understand, from a big ticket standpoint, obviously, dilutive to the second quarter comp. Do you expect big ticket to run below the average comp in the third quarter as well?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's obviously pretty difficult for us to project. Being the optimistic retailers, we want to take each one of our categories and drive a comp increase in each one of those categories. As we look at the back half, it tends to be less sensitive to big ti
componenttext: That's obviously pretty difficult for us to project. Being the optimistic retailers, we want to take each one of our categories and drive a comp increase in each one of those categories. As we look at the back half, it tends to be less sensitive to big ticket. However, as we saw last December, there, we do have some big ticket items. Our focus is going to be to continue to drive value. And as Greg has indicated, our core business has been very strong. So we're going to continue to emphasize in those key categories that will drive footsteps. And hopefully, as we get those customers into the store, we'll be able to get them to create a bigger basket and drive the comp sales in the back half of the year.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just one last point. In terms of core categories being strong, which is great to hear, anything within the core categories that have slowed a little bit relative to where they were previously? Or is that sort of other than big ticket, ever
componenttext: Great. And then just one last point. In terms of core categories being strong, which is great to hear, anything within the core categories that have slowed a little bit relative to where they were previously? Or is that sort of other than big ticket, everything else is running basically where it's been?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Eric, this is Steve. I would tell you that the business continues to be pretty strong in a lot of those basic core businesses. I mean, Tony, I believe, talked about it in his prepared remarks, that we continue to see good growth in the animal side of
componenttext: Yes, Eric, this is Steve. I would tell you that the business continues to be pretty strong in a lot of those basic core businesses. I mean, Tony, I believe, talked about it in his prepared remarks, that we continue to see good growth in the animal side of our business across all species. And so I don't see a slowdown there whatsoever. I think we continue to invest in those businesses and our assortments, our prices and our in-stock, and we're seeing the traction and the benefit of those investments.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we do have a final question for Seth Basham with Wedbush Securities.
componenttext: And we do have a final question for Seth Basham with Wedbush Securities.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: With the business not bouncing back as much as it historically has in June and July with the high moisture levels and the late spring, is that bounce more limited in big ticket or in the core consumables part of the business?
componenttext: With the business not bouncing back as much as it historically has in June and July with the high moisture levels and the late spring, is that bounce more limited in big ticket or in the core consumables part of the business?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It clearly was not in the big ticket categories. And one of the things you need to understand about our business is that there's a cycle and timing to this. And when you get past a certain point -- we know our customer, and they will say to us, "It's too
componenttext: It clearly was not in the big ticket categories. And one of the things you need to understand about our business is that there's a cycle and timing to this. And when you get past a certain point -- we know our customer, and they will say to us, "It's too late in the season now to buy that x product. I'll wait now until next year." And we have heard that in a number of instances as we've been out in the stores ourselves, so that really is the culprit right there.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And as you assess the move into selling more kayaks and more UTVs based on what you experienced this season, is it something that you continue to expect to repeat next year or if you change the merchandising plan around those types of outdoor rec
componenttext: Got it. And as you assess the move into selling more kayaks and more UTVs based on what you experienced this season, is it something that you continue to expect to repeat next year or if you change the merchandising plan around those types of outdoor rec categories?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Steve. While we have a challenging overall top line, I would tell you that there were a lot of gems in the quarter. We talked about a lot of what we did with gardening, in organics, sustainability. We saw a lot of growth there. We saw a lot o
componenttext: Yes, this is Steve. While we have a challenging overall top line, I would tell you that there were a lot of gems in the quarter. We talked about a lot of what we did with gardening, in organics, sustainability. We saw a lot of growth there. We saw a lot of growth in our Chick Days event and a lot of what we're doing there as well. When it comes to what we're doing with our outdoor rec, we saw nice growth. Our kayak business really drove a lot of incremental units and top line sales there. So there's a lot of things in the box that are working incredibly well, and I know that gets overshadowed by the overall top line sales for the quarter. But I would be remiss if I didn't say a lot of that as well as our core business being strong and the foot traffic coming in for those categories. So again, overall, when you look at the quarter, it was a miss. I think we're all disappointed by that, but at the same time, we can build on those things that really work this year for next year. And those categories that suffered this year a little bit, we'll have a plan to reconcile.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Mr. Sandfort, there are no further questions. I'll turn the call over  you for any closing remarks.
componenttext: And Mr. Sandfort, there are no further questions. I'll turn the call over  you for any closing remarks.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, all, for your continued support and your interest in Tractor Supply, and we look forward to speaking to you again in October regarding our third quarter performance.
componenttext: Okay. Thank you, all, for your continued support and your interest in Tractor Supply, and we look forward to speaking to you again in October regarding our third quarter performance.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, this does conclude today's conference. We appreciate your participation.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, this does conclude today's conference. We appreciate your participation.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Tractor Supply Company's conference call to discuss third quarter 2016 results. [Operator Instructions] Please be advised that reproduction of this call, in whole or in part, is not permitted without
componenttext:
Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Tractor Supply Company's conference call to discuss third quarter 2016 results. [Operator Instructions] 
Please be advised that reproduction of this call, in whole or in part, is not permitted without written authorization of Tractor Supply Company. And as a reminder, this call is being recorded. 
I would now like to introduce your host for today's call, Ms. Christine Skold of Tractor Supply Company. Christine, please go ahead.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Camille. Good afternoon. And thank you, for joining us for Tractor Supply Company's quarterly earnings conference call.Before we begin, let me reference the safe harbor provisions under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Th
componenttext:
Thank you, Camille. Good afternoon. And thank you, for joining us for Tractor Supply Company's quarterly earnings conference call.
Before we begin, let me reference the safe harbor provisions under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. This call may contain forward-looking statements that are subject to significant risks and uncertainties, including the future operating and financial performance of the company. Although the company believes the expectations reflected in its forward-looking statements are reasonable, it can give no assurance that such expectations or any of its forward-looking statements will prove to be correct.
Important risk factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those reflected in the forward-looking statements are included in the company's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The information contained in this call is accurate only as of the date discussed. And investors should not assume that statements will remain operative at a later time. Lastly, Tractor Supply Company undertakes no obligation to update any information discussed in this call.
As a reminder, the focus of this call is to discuss third quarter earnings results, and we do not have any additional update on the Petsense [ph] acquisition at this time. We ask that your questions during the call and during follow-up telephone calls focus on Tractor Supply Company's results. 
I'm now pleased to introduce Greg Sandfort, Tractor Supply Company's Chief Executive Officer. Greg, please go ahead.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us. On the call with me today are Tony Crudele, our EVP and Chief Financial Officer; Steve Barbarick, our President and Chief Merchandising and Marketing Officer; and Kurt Barton, our Senior VP and Controlle
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us. On the call with me today are Tony Crudele, our EVP and Chief Financial Officer; Steve Barbarick, our President and Chief Merchandising and Marketing Officer; and Kurt Barton, our Senior VP and Controller. 
As we previously discussed in our business update earlier in September, there were several headwinds affecting our business during the third quarter. We have dedicated a considerable amount of time and effort gathering and analyzing data during the quarter to understand more fully the impact these headwinds have had on our performance, and we do not believe the current sales trends are the result of significant shifts in the competitive landscape, our market share growth or our long-term operating fundamentals. In fact, our core everyday business in categories such as Livestock and Pet [ph] remain strong throughout the third quarter, and our business outside of the energy and agricultural markets in regions like the Southwest and West performed very well for the quarter. We did, however, experienced softer demand in the energy and agricultural markets, and we saw a slow start to the early preseason sales of cold weather and heating-related products that impacted the Northern region.
We have managed successfully through challenging sales environments before, the recession of 2008, 2009. And during those most difficult sales periods, our teams remained focused on managing the factors they could control such as inventory, gross margin and other expenses. We made the necessary adjustments then by taking a long-term balanced approach as we cycle through those periods, and we will do the same for now until these short-term headwinds subside.
At Tractor Supply, we are committed to introduce new products and updating our merchandise categories to keep our stores fresh. And with the current sales environment, we are specifically targeting those categories that have demonstrated strong sales performance year-to-date. Already this fall season, we have had several series of calls with field leadership across several of our more challenged markets to understand the depth of the issues we face. As a result of those calls, we executed a number of timely inventory investments to ensure that we have the appropriate emphasis on categories of high demand in those regions that are performing well: categories such as pet food, agricultural fencing [ph] and grass seeds, to name a few.
Additionally, recognizing [ph] the cold weather and winter preparedness sales were slower to ramp, we adjusted our inventories downward on cold weather products and upward on warm weather regional categories where customer demand stayed high such as fly control, riding lawnmowers, short-sleeve shirts and packaged seeds. [ph] Having this agility to react to current sales trends, we believe it's our [ph] level of sophistication and capability that differentiates us from most of our competition. 
Now with respect to our management of seasonal inventory, we are monitoring sales trends closely and continue to adjust for ongoing customer demand. For example, in the heating category, which I mentioned earlier, we have experienced sluggish early demand and we have kept inventories at a minimum for now. When sales trends accelerate due to cooler weather, our supply chain and our vendor base are ready to react and will push inventory into our DCs then into our stores quickly so that we can meet the increased sales demands.
Also in many of our everyday basic items, C.U.E., [ph] we have elevated in-stock levels to meet the continuing strong demand for animal, pet and land care needs. While we may be a chain of 1,500-plus stores, what is important to understand about our customer is that they perceive Tractor Supply as their unique farm store conveniently located in their small community that offers them locally correct assortments that meet the unique outdoor [ph] lifestyle needs they have.
Now on the marketing front. We adjusted Q3 and forward [ph] programs based on current sales trends by region in an effort to accelerate our comp store sales. We added radio advertising to promote key events during the quarter such as our annual pet appreciation week and lowest prices of the season event. [ph] We enhanced our digital impressions to our web customers and increased our circular distribution to a larger base of our best customers, and we added several targeted sales driving initiatives in key sales weeks to improve our overall sales and marketing effectiveness.
To demonstrate how we are focusing on the growth of our business for the long term, we are continuing to invest in technology to improve our capture of customer insights. This includes the rollout of our Neighbor's Club loyalty program which we believe will give Tractor Supply a unique way to communicate with our customer base by offering a more relevant and personalized message. As well, we completed bringing our customer database in-house so that we could better analyze and segment the customer information that we are collecting from our Neighbor's Club members.
We added an additional 45 stores to the Neighbor's Club program on October 1 in the Western region. And with the initial customer enrollment and customer response being so positive, we now plan to roll the program out to all stores by the middle of 2017.
We continue to invest in the platforms where our customers choose to shop, giving them more options in the way they can interact with the Tractor Supply Company as a brand. This includes the introduction of buy online, pick up in store, [ph] which we started piloting in September and expect to have wide in over half of the chain by the end of this year. We are also continuing to invest in our Tractor Supply website to improved search capabilities and to enhance the know-how section for product content and projects that are important to our customers using videos and online articles. And we continue to invest in store-level resources, including mobile POS and a more intuitive special order process that will assist our team members and our customers to locate hard-to-find products.
As a company, we remain confident in our long-term store target of 2,500 domestic Tractor Supply locations and mid-single-digit annual square footage growth. To help achieve this target, we recently conducted a comprehensive study of our logistics infrastructure to understand what would be required to add capacity and drive more supply chain efficiency as we move toward our long-term store target. One thing to note from the study data, we confirmed that we have a short-term need to add additional distribution capacity in the Northeast region if we plan to continue the store growth there. We have begun the planning process to enable the opening of a new distribution center in that region targeted for mid- to late 2018.
Our recently announced purchase of Petsense, [ph] a leading specialty retailer of pet supplies and services with over 130 stores in 25 states, is another example of our commitment to long-term growth. For some time now, we have discussed the Pet category as a growth opportunity for the company. And based on our research and experience with our own hometown pet concept, we concluded there is a substantial opportunity to grow the pet specialty business in small town America. Their expertise and success in growing a smaller pet specialty store format will allow Petsense to continue at a growth rate of 15% to 20% annually without distraction to the TSC business. Tractor Supply's proven expertise in site selection and store growth should make for a strong partnership with Petsense and allow us to accelerate their growth over time.
Over the longer term, we stay focused on our people and their development, on enhancing our merchandise assortments and adding IT capability to better meet the evolving needs of our customers while always being mindful to return value to our shareholders through sustainable longer-term growth.
Before I wrap up, I want to thank the nearly 23,000 members of the Tractor Supply family for their continued hard work, dedication and the level of service they provide our customers. A big hoorah [ph] to all. 
I would also like to welcome the Petsense team as members of the Tractor Supply family. We are proud to be partnered with you and are excited about the opportunity to develop and grow the Petsense business.
I will now turn the call over to Tony for more detailed commentary on our third quarter financial results and the outlook for the remainder of 2016.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Greg. And good afternoon, everyone. For the quarter ended September 24, 2016, on a year-over-year basis, net sales increased 4.5% to $1.54 billion; net income grew 2.4% to $89.4 million; and EPS increased 4.7% to $0.67 per diluted share.C
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, Greg. And good afternoon, everyone. For the quarter ended September 24, 2016, on a year-over-year basis, net sales increased 4.5% to $1.54 billion; net income grew 2.4% to $89.4 million; and EPS increased 4.7% to $0.67 per diluted share.
Comp store sales decreased 0.6% in the third quarter compared to an increase of 2.9% in last year's third quarter. There are a number of economic headwinds impacting consumer spending throughout many of our markets. However, as noted in our business update on September 7, the energy-producing and agricultural markets were the most impacted. To give you a sense of the magnitude of the macro impact of the energy and farm economies, we estimate that approximately 25% of our stores have a direct correlation to these economies. This does not include any of the stores that may be tangently [ph] affected by the economies.
The strongest regional performance was in the Southeast and West regions where there is less exposure to the energy and agricultural markets. The West region base had a solid mid-single-digit comp, and the Southeast was well above chain average. We continue to experience strong demand for many of our basic everyday items such as Livestock and Pet category which generated mid-single-digit comparable chain wide sales. While the quarter did not shape up the way we expected, we continued to be well positioned for the long term. The solid comp sales in the nonimpacted regions support our position that the business will continue to drive profitable growth. As Greg said, we have been through periods like this before, and we have the leaders and the strategy to continue delivering value to customers, stakeholders and shareholders.
Comp transaction count increased for the 34th consecutive quarter, gaining 0.5%, on top of a 3.8% increase last year as some C.U.E. items, such as pet food and animal feed, continue to drive strong traffic. Average comp ticket decreased by 111 basis points compared to last year's 90 basis points decrease. Big ticket was one of the largest drivers of this year's average ticket decrease. Comparable sales of big ticket items declined approximately 4.7%. The decline was across several categories related principally to the energy and farm markets as well as early season winter sales in the North. More discretionary items, such as UTVs, were down in the oil and farm areas. Oil patch-related products such as compressors and fuel handling were down. Cold weather-related hardlines, such as log splitters and stoves, were down double digits as a result of the lack of urgency cycling a warm winter season last year and low heating oil prices.
On a positive note, we did take advantage of opportunities for some key summer big ticket products, such as riding lawnmowers, by working collaboratively with vendors to develop a late-season sales driving program. Additionally, the average ticket was negatively impacted by the decline in the units per transaction, with preseason sales of wood burning fuel as the principal driver. We estimated of that deflation also decreased the average ticket by approximately 40 basis points. September was the strongest sales month and did register a positive comp. September did have the easiest year-over-year comparison. 
Now turning to gross margin which was flat at 34.7% compared to 60-basis-point decrease in last year's third quarter. Overall, we're very pleased how the team managed margin during a tough selling environment. We continue to improve our initial margin through our key margin initiatives.
Product mix had a negative impact on margin. This resulted from a larger mix of feed and pet food and the strong sales in the riding lawnmower category. 
With respect to margin rate, we were sharper on price and, as Greg mentioned, added few sales-driving initiatives. Freight was essentially flat, lower diesel fuel, lower container cost and a reduction in outbound stem miles were favorable factors. This was offset by higher inbound and outbound costs related to mix and higher lane [ph] costs. We estimate that deflation had a slightly favorable impact on gross margin.
For the quarter, SG&A, including depreciation and amortization as a percent of sales, deleveraged by 20 basis points to 25.5% of sales. The deleverage was primarily due to the decline in comparable sales. SG&A expense grew only 5.4% from the prior year which benefited from a reduction in incentive compensation expense. Excluding incentive compensation, SG&A expense increased only 7.9%, a continuation of the tight cost control management initiated in the second quarter.
Similar to the second quarter, we experienced strong cost control in store level and store support center payroll and medical expense. Occupancy expense was well managed as we continued to benefit from our LED lighting retrofit. The strong expense management was achieved against the headwind from our Arizona DC and mixing centers. We estimate the deleverage from these centers' operations were approximately 15 basis points. Our effective income tax rate decreased to 36.5% in Q3 compared to 36.9% last year due to additional federal and state tax credits.
Turning to the balance sheet. At the end of Q3 this year, we had a cash balance of $55.5 million and $295 million in outstanding debt compared to a cash balance of $51.4 million and $190 million outstanding debt last year. During the third quarter, under our stock repurchase program, we acquired approximately 1.4 million shares for $108.8 million. Average inventory levels per store decreased 1.8% compared to 1.6% increase in last year's third quarter, and inventory turns decreased slightly. We managed our inventory well in the quarter and are comfortable with our seasonal inventory as we move into the fourth quarter.
Capital expenditures for the quarter were $66.2 million compared to $66.5 million last year. We opened up 34 stores, closed 1 Del's store in the third quarter compared to 30 new stores opened and 2 Del's stores and 1 Tractor Supply store closed in the third quarter of 2015. The CapEx this year relates to new store expansion, which includes an emphasis on retrofit locations that generally require renovation capital, and our LED lighting retrofit project. Whereas last year, capital included $12.6 million for the Arizona DC. 
Now looking ahead. Based on the trends and results of the third quarter, we revised our outlook for the full year fiscal year 2016 in our September 7 business update. We are reiterating that outlook today.
We expect full year sales to range from $6.7 billion to $6.75 billion, comparable store sales to increase between 1% and 1.7%, and net income to range from $432 million to $438 million and earnings per diluted share to range between $3.22 to $3.26. Assumed in this full year guidance is an EBIT margin decline of 10 to 15 basis points, a tax rate of 36.7% and capital expenditures of $235 million to $245 million. We will continue to make purchases under our share repurchase program and currently project full year diluted shares outstanding to be approximately 133.8 million to 134.2 million.
As a reminder, we have our 53rd week and an additional comp sales day in the fourth quarter. We now estimate that the additional week will provide $0.04 to $0.05 benefit to EPS which is contained in our guidance. We expect deflation in the fourth quarter of approximately 40 basis points. With respect to gross margin, we expect to continue to be sharper on price which will limit the upside on margin. We also expect to have slight headwinds from product mix and transportation expenses as we cycle the decline in diesel prices. Therefore, we are targeting gross margin to be flat to slightly down for the full year and the fourth quarter.
With respect to SG&A, we will continue to drive cost-saving programs in the fourth quarter and we will react accordingly to the sales trends. We expect to maintain appropriate payroll allocation to drive sales in the fourth quarter, and incur a more normalized incentive compensation expense. We will continue to have the headwind of the Arizona DC until we cycle its opening in late December. Although we benefit from slight leverage from the additional sales week, it has very little impact on the quarter. We estimate that the additional week adds approximately 6% to the year-over-year SG&A growth, including depreciation. We do not expect to leverage SG&A for the quarter. 
With respect to the Petsense acquisition, as we mentioned in our webcast call on September 29, we expect onetime transaction costs, with the majority being recognized in the fourth quarter to be approximately $0.01 to $0.015. There will be some integration costs but we expect these to be immaterial to our overall financial results. Although not originally included in our full year outlook due to the immateriality [ph] of the amount, we did not revise our guidance. Our guidance does that include Petsense sales or operations as we expect the net bottom line impact not to be material.
A few reminders as we look ahead to 2017. We'll be cycling the 53rd week year and, therefore, you need to adjust your models accordingly. With the resulting 1 week shift in 2017, Q2 will have 1 less comp day related to the shift in Easter. Additionally, in 2016, we had a significant decrease in incentive compensation. We would expect a normalized planned incentive compensation for 2017, and that would represent an incremental $0.07 to $0.08 to the SG&A cost structure.
That concludes our prepared remarks. Operator, we will now turn the call over for questions.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we will take our first question from Matt McClintock from Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we will take our first question from Matt McClintock from Barclays.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could maybe update us on the competitive dynamics that you're seeing in some of those challenged energy markets and rural markets. Are you seeing anything different there? And then longer term, if weakness persists, I mean, could we
