componenttext: I was wondering if you could maybe update us on the competitive dynamics that you're seeing in some of those challenged energy markets and rural markets. Are you seeing anything different there? And then longer term, if weakness persists, I mean, could we actually argue an acceleration in market share consolidation for those markets?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matt, this is Greg Sandfort. We are not seeing anything of any substance from a competitive standpoint in even those markets that you mentioned that are challenged right now. The farm store market still has growth, and some of the competition are opening
componenttext: Matt, this is Greg Sandfort. We are not seeing anything of any substance from a competitive standpoint in even those markets that you mentioned that are challenged right now. The farm store market still has growth, and some of the competition are opening some stores but we're outpacing their growth at a very, very high rate. So to think there's a competitive threat, I would say no from another farm store competitor. And that's what -- we watch that very closely and monitor, but I would say no, there's not.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then if I could ask a follow-up on -- you reiterated the 2,500 store goal longer-term. And if I recall, I believe there might have been -- even been, longer-term, some upside there previously in the past. As I think about that goal, does that imply a
componenttext: And then if I could ask a follow-up on -- you reiterated the 2,500 store goal longer-term. And if I recall, I believe there might have been -- even been, longer-term, some upside there previously in the past. As I think about that goal, does that imply a recovery in those energy markets to maybe the highs? Or any recovery at all in those markets? How do we -- how should we think about that?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, the modeling that we use would not today say don't go into those markets because right now they're under some pressure. It would actually tell us that there is a placeholder there for store based upon all the factors that go into that
componenttext: Well, first of all, the modeling that we use would not today say don't go into those markets because right now they're under some pressure. It would actually tell us that there is a placeholder there for store based upon all the factors that go into that model. And there's a number of those until would [ph] tell us that's an ideal location. The one thing I can tell you is that in some of those markets where we're seeing some challenges today, we are being very diligent when those stores come up for presentation at the real estate strategy. We need to look at them very closely to make sure that they are our stores that we believe now, today, we should be looking toward opening. Now there's a number of stores already in the pipeline for 2017. And those stores, we are going to stay with and run with. We're talking about stores now that truly are affecting [ph] '18 and probably into '19.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Peter Benedict with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Peter Benedict with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question on the Neighbor's Club and the decision to kind of roll that out for next year. I mean, what kind of impacts are you seeing from it? If you can [ph] give us a little bit more color on what has encouraged you and given you the confidence to
componenttext: Just a question on the Neighbor's Club and the decision to kind of roll that out for next year. I mean, what kind of impacts are you seeing from it? If you can [ph] give us a little bit more color on what has encouraged you and given you the confidence to push this out by the middle of next year.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Peter, this is Steve Barbarick. We started the program back -- it was about a year ago in October, and we've been very methodical and watching it. The one thing that's really exciting is the enrollment continues to exceed our expectations of -- to lo
componenttext: Yes. Peter, this is Steve Barbarick. We started the program back -- it was about a year ago in October, and we've been very methodical and watching it. The one thing that's really exciting is the enrollment continues to exceed our expectations of -- to look at the fact that -- I'll give you some numbers here. 80% of the e-mails that we're getting through the program are new to our database, and about 50% of the folks that are signing up are also new to our database. So we're getting a real good insight into these individuals. In tracking over the course of the last year, what we're finding is that people that are signing up, and this is of no surprise, tend to be the closest ones to the brand, and they do want to hear from us. They tend to shop us more often, and they're twice as likely to take advantage of our marketing promotions. So as we move forward with this program, we think that this is a real opportunity to talk more to them. They're typically our best customers, and they really want to hear from us. So we think this has a lot of upside in the future.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And related to that, Steve, the response to the marketing changes you guys made in the fourth quarter, just curious, I mean what's the plan for the fourth quarter? Which of those events, or was it radio, or what was the most impactful in your view and how
componenttext: And related to that, Steve, the response to the marketing changes you guys made in the fourth quarter, just curious, I mean what's the plan for the fourth quarter? Which of those events, or was it radio, or what was the most impactful in your view and how you guys plan to kind of evolve the marketing in 4Q and then into '17 based on that?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: A lot of what we're doing is [ph] not just new but it's also enhancements of what we're currently doing. So for example, we're using the digital space today more effectively than we've had in the past. And so you'll see us continue to move down that path
componenttext: A lot of what we're doing is [ph] not just new but it's also enhancements of what we're currently doing. So for example, we're using the digital space today more effectively than we've had in the past. And so you'll see us continue to move down that path as we evolve. We still know that a lot of our customers like the traditional marketing that we do. But we will continue to evolve based on what we see to be most efficient, and that's where right now we're kind of moving toward.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we have Seth Sigman from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Next, we have Seth Sigman from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just follow up on a comment about September improving. I think the comment was that September was positive. Can you elaborate on that? And I know you said there was an easy comp, but did you see any sort of narrowing of the gap between some of
componenttext: I wanted to just follow up on a comment about September improving. I think the comment was that September was positive. Can you elaborate on that? And I know you said there was an easy comp, but did you see any sort of narrowing of the gap between some of those troubled markets versus the healthier markets?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Seth. This is Tony. As I mentioned on the remarks, it was an easier comparison. But as we look at the individual markets, we did see that those markets were still the ones that had the same similar trends that we had in the July and August time fram
componenttext: Sure, Seth. This is Tony. As I mentioned on the remarks, it was an easier comparison. But as we look at the individual markets, we did see that those markets were still the ones that had the same similar trends that we had in the July and August time frame. The one thing in September that did impact September was obviously not getting any type of cold snaps, and some of the preseason heating sales were still down. But again, going up against the easier compare of last year made September a positive comp.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And so just to clarify, when you talk about the 25% of the store base, that's either in energy markets or agricultural markets, you're not referring to those stores necessarily getting better in September?
componenttext: Okay. And so just to clarify, when you talk about the 25% of the store base, that's either in energy markets or agricultural markets, you're not referring to those stores necessarily getting better in September?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. When we look at those stores, those are clearly -- I want to say it's all ships rise with the current tide. So as we moved into September, obviously, we had stronger comps but the difference or the delta between sort of a normalized comp in those sto
componenttext: Yes. When we look at those stores, those are clearly -- I want to say it's all ships rise with the current tide. So as we moved into September, obviously, we had stronger comps but the difference or the delta between sort of a normalized comp in those stores remain similar as it was in July and August.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And then on the expense side, obviously, very well managed this quarter despite the tough environment. How are you thinking about the ability to leverage comps here? I mean, you gave some color on the fourth quarter, but just in general, as
componenttext: Okay, got it. And then on the expense side, obviously, very well managed this quarter despite the tough environment. How are you thinking about the ability to leverage comps here? I mean, you gave some color on the fourth quarter, but just in general, as we look out over the next 12 months, to the extent that comps are maybe below that 3% to 5% long-term target, maybe what are some of the opportunities that the team is focused on to maybe take some expenses out?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We've been very aggressive in looking at the expenses for the back half as we saw sales soften through Q2 and Q3. As we look out, we believe that we can continue to manage those discretionary expenses such as travel, training, looking at some of the
componenttext: Sure. We've been very aggressive in looking at the expenses for the back half as we saw sales soften through Q2 and Q3. As we look out, we believe that we can continue to manage those discretionary expenses such as travel, training, looking at some of the stores, really working with vendors to try to reduce our costs relative to maintenance, supplies, fixtures and things like that. So obviously, we'll continue to do that. The one thing that's very important to us, though, is we look at the long-term. And so we do not want to do anything that would jeopardize the business. So we'll continue to make sure that we fund our stores, fund payroll, we want to make sure that we maintain market share and want to convert those customers and maintain those customers as they come into our stores. The one thing that we do mention when we look out over the next 12 months is the incentive compensation piece. Though, obviously, it's much reduced this year, and we'll be comping up against that as we put in a more normalized incentive compensation, it will make it very difficult to get SG&A leverage.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Christopher Horvers with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question is from Christopher Horvers with JPMorgan.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So sort of a follow-up-on that. I mean, I know you haven't given full guidance for 2017. You have a long-term earnings algorithm out there of 3% to 5% comps and midteens earnings growth. And given the state of the world, it feels like that's not going to
componenttext: So sort of a follow-up-on that. I mean, I know you haven't given full guidance for 2017. You have a long-term earnings algorithm out there of 3% to 5% comps and midteens earnings growth. And given the state of the world, it feels like that's not going to be achievable next year, so any initial thoughts about how you're thinking about the sales outlook for next year and the overall earnings growth would be really helpful.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: [ph] Sure. As we look out, we're still, one, very confident in the long-term store target of 2,500. And we tend -- we still want to look out, and we believe that we're capable of driving that 3% to 5% comp on a long-term basis. Obviously, as we look at th
componenttext: [ph] Sure. As we look out, we're still, one, very confident in the long-term store target of 2,500. And we tend -- we still want to look out, and we believe that we're capable of driving that 3% to 5% comp on a long-term basis. Obviously, as we look at the headwinds that are -- have been presented to us this year as well as -- we cannot determine at what point in time they will subside. We'll take a harder look at the short term and adjust our comps accordingly. At this point in time, though, we're not prepared to give full guidance on 2017. But obviously, given the current sales environment, we would agree with the consensus that it'd be difficult to hit the longer-term target of 3% to 5%.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And just related to that, so then is the message here, guys, like we've got $0.05, $0.06 for the 53rd week, you've got $0.07 to $0.08 from the incentive comp normalizing, so if consensus is like 3.60, [ph] is it essentially the [ph] message to
componenttext: Understood. And just related to that, so then is the message here, guys, like we've got $0.05, $0.06 for the 53rd week, you've got $0.07 to $0.08 from the incentive comp normalizing, so if consensus is like 3.60, [ph] is it essentially the [ph] message to take those onetime items and reduce our numbers by that amount to bring it down to that 3 45 to 3 50-ish level?[ph]

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, obviously, we want you to consider those factors in the model. We are a grower. We're going to continue to grow the store base next year. We anticipate to be above the 100-store range next year, and we -- the merchandising team is aggressive as far
componenttext: Well, obviously, we want you to consider those factors in the model. We are a grower. We're going to continue to grow the store base next year. We anticipate to be above the 100-store range next year, and we -- the merchandising team is aggressive as far as putting in programs and looking at new products and trying to drive the comps. So obviously, we're really working hard to have a very strong 2017 campaign. Having said that, we just understand that those headwinds of the 53rd week and the incentive compensation will have an impact on earnings. But again, our mindset here is we want to be double-digit earnings growth, and we're going to do whatever we can to make sure that happens.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And then just as a follow-up, how much of your mix would you say is heating-related in the fourth quarter? And then bigger picture, how much is cold weather-related sales as a percentage of mix in the fourth quarter as well?
componenttext: Understood. And then just as a follow-up, how much of your mix would you say is heating-related in the fourth quarter? And then bigger picture, how much is cold weather-related sales as a percentage of mix in the fourth quarter as well?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Chris, this is Steve Barbarick. We typically don't get too detailed into the numbers. The big picture, we know that animal products is about 40% or 45% of our business and, seasonally, it changes. So again, we're not going to get that granular here.
componenttext: Yes, Chris, this is Steve Barbarick. We typically don't get too detailed into the numbers. The big picture, we know that animal products is about 40% or 45% of our business and, seasonally, it changes. So again, we're not going to get that granular here.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Lasser with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Lasser with UBS.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's on the 25% of the business that's been underperforming. It seemed to catch you offguard that the ag markets are rolling over. So what are you looking for to give you an indication that it's going to get better? I guess the point is, how long is this
componenttext: It's on the 25% of the business that's been underperforming. It seemed to catch you offguard that the ag markets are rolling over. So what are you looking for to give you an indication that it's going to get better? I guess the point is, how long is this going to be a drag on the overall business?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, obviously, Michael, it's very difficult to project how long that would be. Now what I would tell you, as far as order of magnitude, the oil markets have been a drag. Obviously, just in the recent weeks, you start to see the oil prices coming back. T
componenttext: Well, obviously, Michael, it's very difficult to project how long that would be. Now what I would tell you, as far as order of magnitude, the oil markets have been a drag. Obviously, just in the recent weeks, you start to see the oil prices coming back. They are having a few more rigs put back into place, not that that's going to turn on the light switch but, obviously, it's more of a positive indication. Next, if -- on the higher key [ph] would be really the impact of the cold weather products, and that would be probably the second biggest drag on the comps. And then really, thirdly, it's the farm economies. It's really all 3 combined which is having the impact. So as any one of those start to turn, obviously, it would have a favorable impact on the business. So I wouldn't necessarily say we need all 3 of them to turn around to start to see the comps really improve dramatically. And of the -- of those 3 factors, farm income probably is the least of the 3.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful, Tony. Two points to clarify, you mentioned double-digit earnings growth for next year, are you saying think about double-digit earnings growth and then subtract the incentive comp piece and the extra week piece? Or is that not the ri
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful, Tony. Two points to clarify, you mentioned double-digit earnings growth for next year, are you saying think about double-digit earnings growth and then subtract the incentive comp piece and the extra week piece? Or is that not the right way to think about it?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say that would be the correct way to look at it. I would say you want to adjust for those items and then this team here is -- we are geared towards driving double-digit growth, but we need to adjust those 2 factors.
componenttext: I would say that would be the correct way to look at it. I would say you want to adjust for those items and then this team here is -- we are geared towards driving double-digit growth, but we need to adjust those 2 factors.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then will there be -- what would the -- how should we think about the sales contribution from Petsense in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: And then will there be -- what would the -- how should we think about the sales contribution from Petsense in the fourth quarter?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're not providing guidance at this time, but what we believe is that any bottom line benefit that we would receive would offset the transaction and/or integration cost in that quarter. So net-net, bottom line, there's no impact.[ph]
componenttext: We're not providing guidance at this time, but what we believe is that any bottom line benefit that we would receive would offset the transaction and/or integration cost in that quarter. So net-net, bottom line, there's no impact.[ph]

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Peter Keith with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Peter Keith with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to circle back on the oil markets and maybe a little bit on the ag economies, too, with the economic issues. Which -- when you look at the oil markets that's 25% of the base, is that only South Central Texas? [ph] Or could you maybe frame that for us
componenttext: Just to circle back on the oil markets and maybe a little bit on the ag economies, too, with the economic issues. Which -- when you look at the oil markets that's 25% of the base, is that only South Central Texas? [ph] Or could you maybe frame that for us geographically? And then similarly, on the -- where the ag economies are the worst?[ph]

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Tony. I'll give you just a little bit more color as best as I can. In the prepared remarks, we talked about 25% of the store base, and that would include all energy which would be oil, it could also be coal in the Appalachian [ph] area and, obviou
componenttext: This is Tony. I'll give you just a little bit more color as best as I can. In the prepared remarks, we talked about 25% of the store base, and that would include all energy which would be oil, it could also be coal in the Appalachian [ph] area and, obviously, the farming tends to be mostly in the Midwest and the Great Plains. [ph] So -- but what we're seeing is -- and since it's such a broad area of the country, all the stores are getting thrown in there, so it appears to be a much larger piece of the business. But when we run our models, we see that the correlation, specifically to all 3 of those, being any of the oil, energy, coal or farm, the correlation -- the direct correlation is only for about 25% of the store base. So those are the ones that are being directly impacted. So as much as we have a lot of stores in Texas, there's only x amount that are energy-impacted. So the first thing is I would not extrapolate it to every store in every state. What we're saying is about 25% of the stores are -- correlate directly and have a more significant impact than the rest of the chain.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. I want to pivot over to gross margin. Curious on the sharper pricing, it sounds like you're having some success there. Is that something that, with the ongoing sluggishness, you would anticipate continuing? And is there a possibility
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. I want to pivot over to gross margin. Curious on the sharper pricing, it sounds like you're having some success there. Is that something that, with the ongoing sluggishness, you would anticipate continuing? And is there a possibility to get some vendor support to have the preps [ph] mitigate that gross margin impact?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Steve Barbarick. We have been working with our supplier community. But we use our price optimization tool and systems here, and it's been very effective for us. And we continue to drive share in a lot of the key categories that are more price
componenttext: Yes. This is Steve Barbarick. We have been working with our supplier community. But we use our price optimization tool and systems here, and it's been very effective for us. And we continue to drive share in a lot of the key categories that are more price-sensitive like feed and, in some cases, pet food. I don't want to get too deep into the vendor support but we do work with our vendors to make sure that when we do promote and we do EDLP [ph] pricing that we're competitive and that we are continuing to gain share.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe just a follow-up on that for Tony, is there some risk of gross margin pressure continuing in a sluggish sales environment? Or is it just too tough to tell at this point looking out to next year?
componenttext: Okay. And maybe just a follow-up on that for Tony, is there some risk of gross margin pressure continuing in a sluggish sales environment? Or is it just too tough to tell at this point looking out to next year?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Obviously, it's too early to tell for next year. As we've done our sensitivities for Q4, we believe that if there is margin pressure with some of the pricing programs, we would expect to pick it up on the top line. And vice versa, if we aren't overly aggr
componenttext: Obviously, it's too early to tell for next year. As we've done our sensitivities for Q4, we believe that if there is margin pressure with some of the pricing programs, we would expect to pick it up on the top line. And vice versa, if we aren't overly aggressive on price, we'll pick it up on the margin side relative to the model that we ran for the quarter.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Steven Forbes with Guggenheim Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Steven Forbes with Guggenheim Securities.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: To start with the top line performance and trends within the different sales category thus far, so far this year, I know you mentioned livestock and pet rose mid-single-digits during the quarter. I think that's been relatively consistent. But can you prov
componenttext: To start with the top line performance and trends within the different sales category thus far, so far this year, I know you mentioned livestock and pet rose mid-single-digits during the quarter. I think that's been relatively consistent. But can you provide some color around the other categories, maybe just touching on the categories you lay out within the SEC filings, and how they've trended throughout the year just to give us a better perspective as we look out kind of over the next 6 to 12 months here as it relates to the compares by category?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steven, this is Steve, and I'll try to stay at a fairly high level here because we can break this thing down in a lot of little pieces and parts. But we talked about the impact that the energy markets have had on ticket, and I would go back and say that c
componenttext: Steven, this is Steve, and I'll try to stay at a fairly high level here because we can break this thing down in a lot of little pieces and parts. But we talked about the impact that the energy markets have had on ticket, and I would go back and say that categories such as welders, some compressors, those type of businesses have been a bit of a challenge for us. And you can see that in those individual markets where we are impacted most by energy, things like certain apparel, whether it's some steel footwear -- cold footwear or fire-retardant apparel, that you can actually look into those specific regions and you can pretty much kind of estimate what categories are going to be the most impacted there. In terms of the seasonal businesses, we talked about having a fairly soft spring but didn't drag [ph] into the fall and that benefited us. But we certainly didn't capture any of the preheating sales that we had traditionally gotten. Still, again, if you look at seasonal, it's kind of a tale of 2 stories how we preferred to have spring in spring and winter in winter, but that just hasn't necessarily been the case yet. So we're having to move some of our inventories around to better position ourselves to optimize where we think we can. And then the last thing I would tell you is in the truck tool [ph] and hardware business, it's a little similar to what I talked about earlier with some of the big ticket. Truck boxes, fuel handling, those kind of categories have been really soft for us. And again, we believe a lot of that is more energy-related. So does that help clarify some?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess. And then I guess as a follow-up, maybe if we can expand on it, regarding the trends in those more discretionary categories, right, the nonmaintenance side and not livestock and pets. I mean, I guess, just trying to understand the color aroun
componenttext: Yes, I guess. And then I guess as a follow-up, maybe if we can expand on it, regarding the trends in those more discretionary categories, right, the nonmaintenance side and not livestock and pets. I mean, I guess, just trying to understand the color around behavioral trends, right, as you think about the consumer shopping the store. And I'm not sure if you have visibility via talking to store managers or so forth, are the consumers coming into the box, right, because you're clearly driving traffic in the 34th consecutive quarter? And are they shopping the rest of the store and just not making, right -- exploring the side [ph] of store, exploring the merchandising displays and just not making the purchase? Or are you seeing the consumers come in to the store and really just go right for that -- the back section livestock and pet and not even exploring, right, everything you're doing on the merchandising side? And then how does that relate, right, to the initiatives you have in place and you're working on as it relates to space allocation merchandising and promotional activity, right, as you look to curtail those trends?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steven, this is Greg. Let me -- I'll make it very simple for you. There's evidence, not only in the consumer surveys that we've completed but in our current sales trends, that the customers have become more conservative in their purchasing behaviors. That
componenttext: Steven, this is Greg. Let me -- I'll make it very simple for you. There's evidence, not only in the consumer surveys that we've completed but in our current sales trends, that the customers have become more conservative in their purchasing behaviors. That doesn't mean they're not still buying but they're buying more conservative, which means they're buying absolutely what they need at the time that they need it. They're still shopping the store as evidenced by the transaction increases that we're seeing. They're still supporting the pet, the animal and some land maintenance and in other categories across the stores. So we're not seeing them just cherrypick. They're actually shopping across the store. But they pull back considerably on big ticket spends for now. We think there's a number of factors involved there, not just the energy markets and some of the things happening in the ag economy. But we're going get to -- listen again this evening on a debate about who's going to be the next President of the United States, and those things have some effect on our customer, no question. We have heard from them in these surveys that they feel their budgets are a bit tighter right now. And as we've been monitoring sales trends and looking at this by region, the customer demand for those things that are needed to support the lifestyle continue to exist, continue -- they continue to come in and purchase in our stores. So we have got to keep bringing new products. We got to keep updating the merchandise assortments, keeping those stores fresh. And I can tell you, the consumer count is still there, but they're being very conservative and very thoughtful in their spends.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Simeon Gutman with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Simeon Gutman with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I want to ask about farm income and -- because a couple of years ago, it actually started to nosedive. And we know from history, there was no impact to the business. And actually, the deceleration were sharper 2 or 3 years ago than any time in 2016. So
componenttext: So I want to ask about farm income and -- because a couple of years ago, it actually started to nosedive. And we know from history, there was no impact to the business. And actually, the deceleration were sharper 2 or 3 years ago than any time in 2016. So I'm trying to figure out what's happening now? Why wasn't it evident before if something else was sort of hiding the impact? Because I think what we're all trying to get at is -- it's hard to quantify, we don't know when it's going to end but because you weren't getting hit by it before, how do we understand the downside? And I'm sure you're trying to figure out the same thing, but how are you thinking about it?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Simeon, this is Greg. This -- when we studied that in years past and up till even at this point in time, this is the first time in a number of years that, back to back to back years, the farm community has suffered losses in the crops that they've tried t
componenttext: Simeon, this is Greg. This -- when we studied that in years past and up till even at this point in time, this is the first time in a number of years that, back to back to back years, the farm community has suffered losses in the crops that they've tried to bring in and sell. There's also a factor in cattle, which most people don't think about, but in the state of Texas and in a few states north of that, it's a big impact as well. Cattle prices, $1 less per pound. I mean, we hear these things from our customers, and I would tell you that I think it's more severe now than it was in the past. I'll also tell you that in the model of our business, this is the first time that we've seen energy come into the same kind of play on top of these other aspects. So multiple things working at the same time, it's not -- the farming piece, we just mentioned this time and said it's more of a factor or at least it's a bit of an overhang because it's the first time in a number of years we can actually see [ph] in those communities, we're seeing the softness. We didn't see that before. But it's other factors on top of those factors, we believe, that have caused the drag.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just to follow on -- I guess, clarifying that, not a follow-up yet. But would you say, I guess, there's been a lag? Or are you saying they're somewhat of a coincidence now just because it's just amplifying some of the other pressures?
componenttext: So just to follow on -- I guess, clarifying that, not a follow-up yet. But would you say, I guess, there's been a lag? Or are you saying they're somewhat of a coincidence now just because it's just amplifying some of the other pressures?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you just answered your own question.
componenttext: I think you just answered your own question.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my second question, it sounds like you're stepping up the marketing to help drive the sales. What about any, I guess, temptation to promote during this environment? Greg, is there any -- or Steve, I mean -- doesn't it make sense -- does tha
componenttext: Okay. And then my second question, it sounds like you're stepping up the marketing to help drive the sales. What about any, I guess, temptation to promote during this environment? Greg, is there any -- or Steve, I mean -- doesn't it make sense -- does that not make sense for your business?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Simeon, here's how it works. When there's no demand for certain categories of products, there's not a price that you can sell that product to the consumer for. And I'm talking of things like heating, I'm talking about things like possibly large farm equip
componenttext: Simeon, here's how it works. When there's no demand for certain categories of products, there's not a price that you can sell that product to the consumer for. And I'm talking of things like heating, I'm talking about things like possibly large farm equipment or larger pieces of equipment, big ticket items and so on. You have to have the consumer demand. Now we're going to need to be a little patient here and understand that we can maneuver and control inventories in some of those categories where the demand is not great right now, but we want to make sure, and Steve would tell you this, that we have the ability to react if the category starts to accelerate. We believe there'll still be a heating business this year, but we think it's going to come later. We do believe there'll be some outerwear business and some, call it, seasonal-type businesses this year. But until we see some weather improvement, meaning cooler weather, that's not going to transpire. So instead, inventories have been shifted a bit. And where we put our and place our bets is on the things within C.U.E. and the categories that are retailing right now and doing well. But we have every ability to react when things would move in the right direction, and we believe it will come. We don't know the timing of it, but we do believe some of these seasonal trends will shift.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ben Bienvenu with Stephens Inc.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ben Bienvenu with Stephens Inc.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tony, I think in the past, you had quantified the differential between your energy-exposed markets and the rest of the chain to be around 400 to 500 basis points. Is that still the case today? In light of sort of the broadening of the store base, that's t
componenttext: Tony, I think in the past, you had quantified the differential between your energy-exposed markets and the rest of the chain to be around 400 to 500 basis points. Is that still the case today? In light of sort of the broadening of the store base, that's the same weakness in the broadening of the SKU set, the same weakness?[ph]

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: [ph] Yes. Ben, you're correct. It has -- the difference has continued. It's been very consistent over the last 3 quarters. But where we're disappointed is that, as we have mentioned on a previous conference call, we were hoping that differential would mod
componenttext: [ph] Yes. Ben, you're correct. It has -- the difference has continued. It's been very consistent over the last 3 quarters. But where we're disappointed is that, as we have mentioned on a previous conference call, we were hoping that differential would moderate as we came into the back half of the year, and we have not seen that happen. So there's still is a relatively large delta. And again, until the economies really start to turn a little bit, we expect that we'll have a similar delta throughout the end of the year.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then when you look at the ag-exposed markets, is it a similar magnitude of differential? Or is it less or more? Any quantification you could provide there would be helpful.
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then when you look at the ag-exposed markets, is it a similar magnitude of differential? Or is it less or more? Any quantification you could provide there would be helpful.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. The differential is a little bit less, and it's very, very less number of stores as well.
componenttext: Sure. The differential is a little bit less, and it's very, very less number of stores as well.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Alan Rifkin with BTIG.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Alan Rifkin with BTIG.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to follow up on a couple of earlier questions. So you've cited agricultural impact as well as energy as 2 of the 3 reasons. So can you just try to help us delineate the impact between just those 2 variables on the business?
componenttext: Just to follow up on a couple of earlier questions. So you've cited agricultural impact as well as energy as 2 of the 3 reasons. So can you just try to help us delineate the impact between just those 2 variables on the business?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: [ph] I'm sorry, which 2?
componenttext: [ph] I'm sorry, which 2?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Agriculture and energy. Now I understand the impact from both of them, but are you able to segregate the effect of agriculture alone in the business versus energy alone?
componenttext: Agriculture and energy. Now I understand the impact from both of them, but are you able to segregate the effect of agriculture alone in the business versus energy alone?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: [ph] Well, it's, at times, very difficult to segregate the 2 because you may have some that cross both, but I would try to give you a generalization of the magnitude. It's probably at least 3:1 when it comes to the impact of oil on the comps versus farm o
componenttext: [ph] Well, it's, at times, very difficult to segregate the 2 because you may have some that cross both, but I would try to give you a generalization of the magnitude. It's probably at least 3:1 when it comes to the impact of oil on the comps versus farm on the comps.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And my follow-up, you're now talking about 113 stores for this year whereas, last quarter, you were talking about 115 to 120. When you take that together with your earlier statement, Tony, that, next year, you're going to open up "above 100 store ra
componenttext: Okay. And my follow-up, you're now talking about 113 stores for this year whereas, last quarter, you were talking about 115 to 120. When you take that together with your earlier statement, Tony, that, next year, you're going to open up "above 100 store range," should we think of your square footage in 2017 really being closer to 6% rather than the 7%, 7.5% versus what some people thought? And why the slippage of anywhere from 2 to 7 stores for this year?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're currently trying -- assessing the store target for next year. I would tell you that we have the majority of stores already in place and signed. [ph] As we move towards that north of 100 to 120 range, I would tell you that we will be very discriminat
componenttext: We're currently trying -- assessing the store target for next year. I would tell you that we have the majority of stores already in place and signed. [ph] As we move towards that north of 100 to 120 range, I would tell you that we will be very discriminate in the softer sales environment and making sure that we make the right choices on those stores as we move forward. But we'll give you more guidance on the next conference call in January as to the 2017 store plan.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are you at liberty to say how many of the stores for 2017 are already signed?
componenttext: Are you at liberty to say how many of the stores for 2017 are already signed?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say -- well, we don't usually give out that number but I would say that number is defined, this is Greg. And I want you to think about something that most people don't realize, Alan, back in '08 and '09, we were growing our store base at 10%. We s
componenttext: I would say -- well, we don't usually give out that number but I would say that number is defined, this is Greg. And I want you to think about something that most people don't realize, Alan, back in '08 and '09, we were growing our store base at 10%. We saw a similar type of headwind occur and we said, "You know what, we could've slowed down to about 7% to 8% and hold there for a while until the economies in that time would improve." We're seeing a little bit of the same kind of drag, a little different variable this time than last. So Tony's comment earlier about -- we may not be at the 115, 120, that's always been a target, by the way. In real estate, you can, in a moment's notice, lose 2 or 3 stores because deals can't be completed or there's a problem with a contract or what have you. So for 2016, that's more of the instance. That we wanted to get more stores open, we just could not. But we'll talk more about that in specific as we get to the fourth quarter and we give our guidance for next year.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Scott Mushkin with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Scott Mushkin with Wolfe Research.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: When it comes to the -- those stores comping 3% to 5%, as we mentioned, the Southeast and the West. The Southeast more on the lower end, the West is actually exceeding the upper end. And now again I point out that the West has a less mature store base giv
componenttext: When it comes to the -- those stores comping 3% to 5%, as we mentioned, the Southeast and the West. The Southeast more on the lower end, the West is actually exceeding the upper end. And now again I point out that the West has a less mature store base given the stores that we've opened over the last couple of years so that we would expect the comp a little bit stronger but they've had very strong sales in those areas. Again, those are stores that are highly correlated, obviously, the gap with a normalized comp is much greater and then there's a swap in the stores there range in between those numbers.

componenttext: Perfect. And then one other clarification. I know you guys talked about September, 2 weeks into October, is the momentum continuing?

componenttext: Well, what we see in October are similar trends as in September. And as we moved into this quarter, we did anticipate that October will be the toughest compare. And obviously the, quarter is going to really be driven by November and December and the type of weather that we have in those 2 months.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perfect. Now to my real question. So that's more kind of a secular question. So obviously, you guys have some cyclical issues now. But if we had a longer view, comps have been kind of slowing for a while, return on invested capital turned down about 18 mo
componenttext: Perfect. Now to my real question. So that's more kind of a secular question. So obviously, you guys have some cyclical issues now. But if we had a longer view, comps have been kind of slowing for a while, return on invested capital turned down about 18 months. How do you kind of view this? And then of course you went out and made an acquisition, an adjacent acquisition. How do you view more the what looks to be more of a secular slowing of the business versus what's going on cyclically?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I would tell you initially is that when you look back at the comps, we've had some very nice comps over the last 3 years and in an environment with mostly deflation. And obviously, as we get into some of these periods where we have a downturn in the
componenttext: What I would tell you initially is that when you look back at the comps, we've had some very nice comps over the last 3 years and in an environment with mostly deflation. And obviously, as we get into some of these periods where we have a downturn in the economy, we're going to be impacted but we continue to believe that will make the necessary adjustments with the merchandising. We'll continue to drive strong store performance and as these economies turn, we're going to be very well positioned to continue towards our long-term goal of 3% to 5% comps.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess just a question for Steve, maybe. Is there anything going on in merchandising? Any initiatives that you guys are thinking about? Or new product categories or specific products, if you will? Anything you're excited about that we should be thinking
componenttext: I guess just a question for Steve, maybe. Is there anything going on in merchandising? Any initiatives that you guys are thinking about? Or new product categories or specific products, if you will? Anything you're excited about that we should be thinking about here as we look out quarter, 2 quarters, maybe into next year?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's a lot going on in the merchandising front. I would tell you that the teams all over certain trends right now. We continue to see in the pet and animal side. People stepping up to premium. Natural foods, we've just expanded a number of organic prod
componenttext: There's a lot going on in the merchandising front. I would tell you that the teams all over certain trends right now. We continue to see in the pet and animal side. People stepping up to premium. Natural foods, we've just expanded a number of organic products in the stores. We still see our customers tend to be self-reliant. So the things that we're doing with chicken supplies and beekeeping, we've got reassess that are taking place throughout the stores right now in both sides that we think we can capitalize on things like premium, rubber footwear and things in truck accessories. So there's a variety of things. We always said that we're a test and learning company and we've been testing and learning a lot and we're rolling and expanding a lot of programs out. So from that perspective, there's still a lot in the hopper. Just most recently, we expanded our animal test from 25 stores to 100 stores thinking that this would be a good quarter to learn a little bit more in. In sporting goods, for example, we've got premium coolers and kayaks and other things going on. So if I were to walk a store with you and walk through the entire 4 walls, I would tell you there's something happening in about every area.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's good to hear. And moving on to the loyalty card. I don't know some companies from time to time have actually quantified a lift that you get from sales. I don't know if there's anything like that, that you've seen. Obviously, over time there's more yo
componenttext: It's good to hear. And moving on to the loyalty card. I don't know some companies from time to time have actually quantified a lift that you get from sales. I don't know if there's anything like that, that you've seen. Obviously, over time there's more you can do with the data but I'm curious if there has been a lift than sort of the test markets.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: Steven, this is Steve again. I would tell you that it's still early in the game for us. While we've got about a handful of stores in the comp, the first year we're now just comping over last year's and we're going to be able to give you a much better indication on the next call but I will tell you, we wouldn't be expanding it if we didn't feel like we were getting a benefit.

componenttext: I believe in some prior calls you noted that e-commerce revenues were less than 1% of total. Certainly recognize there is some of these products that are not certainly for online shopping. But nevertheless, would you think that the -- your penetration should be exceeding that level given the investments that have been made?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dan, this is Steve again. I would tell you that we're seeing a nice momentum in this space. We've added a number of new lines, online and content and we're seeing the growth there. As you know that we've invested in a new platform, we've mobile optim
componenttext: Yes, Dan, this is Steve again. I would tell you that we're seeing a nice momentum in this space. We've added a number of new lines, online and content and we're seeing the growth there. As you know that we've invested in a new platform, we've mobile optimized our website to ensure there's a consistent consumer experience across the device. And most recently, the impact of buy online in store is having a very positive impact on our business. I think that alone tied in with the initiatives we have some around the fulfillment side, you'll see that percentage grow over time. And once it becomes more material, we'll be able to share with you exactly where we're at. But I would tell you that there's a lot of work being done and we're very excited about what we're doing right now. And we're seeing the results of it.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Also second question. I know that you're still targeting 3% to 5% secular same-store sales growth. Can that be achieved if energy markets stabilize at current levels? Or do those markets need to rebound to where they were say 2 or 3 years ago to achieve t
componenttext: Also second question. I know that you're still targeting 3% to 5% secular same-store sales growth. Can that be achieved if energy markets stabilize at current levels? Or do those markets need to rebound to where they were say 2 or 3 years ago to achieve that 3% to 5% companywide target?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Dan, this is Greg. Very difficult to predict as you can imagine but those energy markets we're watching closely. And I would say that we can't predict if they're going to do any worse or any better. But my prediction, if I was to give one on this, is
componenttext: Hey, Dan, this is Greg. Very difficult to predict as you can imagine but those energy markets we're watching closely. And I would say that we can't predict if they're going to do any worse or any better. But my prediction, if I was to give one on this, is a slight uptick in that business down there to stabilize would give our customers the confidence to go back and start spending again on some of those categories that we believe right now from the survey work we've done, they're sitting back holding their monies. They're not releasing those funds right now because they are nervous. Once they can settle down, do think we'll start to see some movement back, yes.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just one real quick question. Year ago, this guy think some of the weaker first year sales volumes in Arizona and in Utah. Now we're talking about the strength in the Western markets. Are we seeing those stores that opened up that revenues, are they a
componenttext: And just one real quick question. Year ago, this guy think some of the weaker first year sales volumes in Arizona and in Utah. Now we're talking about the strength in the Western markets. Are we seeing those stores that opened up that revenues, are they achieving that faster same-store sales growth now that they're in their second year?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, Dan, this is Tony. when we look at the comps and sort of the store maturation cycle, we've always said that the newer stores are going to ramp at a higher pace than the chain. And when in good times and the chain is moving at your 3 to 5 comp, we're g
componenttext: Hi, Dan, this is Tony. when we look at the comps and sort of the store maturation cycle, we've always said that the newer stores are going to ramp at a higher pace than the chain. And when in good times and the chain is moving at your 3 to 5 comp, we're going to be in a Delta above that. We're seeing that the stores out West are running above that normalized Delta. But given that obviously the rest of the chain is very flat, obviously, that helps to increase the Delta between the mature stores and the new out there. But what I would tell you is that, yes, some of the stores came out the slow are ramping at a much nicer pace. We're very pleased with of the stores and that's why when we look at the new store productivity and we spend a great deal of time looking at it, we look at it more on a rolling 12. We know that some of the stores last year that we talked about came out a little bit soft. So we know that we probably have this lower new store productivity over the course of the year. But when we look at it and look at it over a 12, rolling 12, it's relatively consistent for the last 4 quarters. It has gone down slightly. Some of the West stores have come out slower, that's probably one of the bigger drivers. And some of the West stores also had a little bit more square footage, as we've had some additional square footage so that we can add more allocation for the product since they tend to be strong feed stores. So that's the stores calculation a little as well. But IRR hurdle has not changed. We're meeting pro forma and so we feel very good about the new stores, especially as we see the stores out West ramp.

componenttext: A quick question on Petsense. I'm more interested about the timing of the announcement. It seems or if I remember correctly, that this sort of thought process was that you have a bunch of stores in front of you to open and that is the main focus, probably no acquisitions during that time frame. Petsense obviously very small but again, it does seem like a different customer base on what you're saying about your learning some HomeTown Pet. So now we are in a difficult microenvironment you sort of have to try and manage 2 related but different businesses. And related to questions about maybe where we are on a broader picture, what should be we think about the timing of this announcement? Why now I guess as sort of a general question.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Adam, this is Greg. Two things to remember on Petsense. One is, it is not going to be a distraction for TSC and it will not really look to take any type of funding and resources from TSC. As a matter of fact, it's a well-run company. It is small in base t
componenttext: Adam, this is Greg. Two things to remember on Petsense. One is, it is not going to be a distraction for TSC and it will not really look to take any type of funding and resources from TSC. As a matter of fact, it's a well-run company. It is small in base today, but has tremendous growth opportunity and it will basically fund itself. So don't worry about trying to run 2 businesses. They're not going to be integrated. It's a separate business, it runs separately, it has its own President and its own staff of people and there will be no integration. This was a strategic buy, not an integration buy. There's the difference.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Christina Fernandez for Joe. We wanted to ask about the incentive compensation you talked about, $0.07 to $0.08 headwind being your normalized compensation for next year but then at the same time, EPS coming in below that midteens range. So how do
componenttext: This is Christina Fernandez for Joe. We wanted to ask about the incentive compensation you talked about, $0.07 to $0.08 headwind being your normalized compensation for next year but then at the same time, EPS coming in below that midteens range. So how do you reconcile the 2?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Christina, this is Tony. What we're saying is that our incentive compensation is based against our plan. So as we move into 2017 and we create a new plan, we have to allocate to the incentive compensation expense line relative to our projected 2017
componenttext: Well, Christina, this is Tony. What we're saying is that our incentive compensation is based against our plan. So as we move into 2017 and we create a new plan, we have to allocate to the incentive compensation expense line relative to our projected 2017 plan. So as we go through this year with very limited incentive compensation in the expense structure, once we recalibrate next year and put a new plan together, we need to put a on-plan incentive compensation. So we estimate that if we move back relative year-over-year that there will be an increase in the expense structure of $0.07 to $0.08 to the bottom line. So having said that, we're just seeing -- we're just giving you notice that you need to adjust your models accordingly as a lot of people have been looking at this years expense run rate and applying it to next year. So you just need to be able to add in some incentive compensation into your model next year if you have not already.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
