componenttext: Yes, Chris, this is Steve Barbarick. We typically don't get too detailed into the numbers. The big picture, we know that animal products is about 40% or 45% of our business and, seasonally, it changes. So again, we're not going to get that granular here.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Lasser with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Lasser with UBS.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's on the 25% of the business that's been underperforming. It seemed to catch you off-guard that the ag markets are rolling over. So what are you looking for to give you an indication that it's going to get better? I guess the point is, how long is this
componenttext: It's on the 25% of the business that's been underperforming. It seemed to catch you off-guard that the ag markets are rolling over. So what are you looking for to give you an indication that it's going to get better? I guess the point is, how long is this going to be a drag on the overall business?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, obviously, Michael, it's very difficult to project how long that would be. Now what I would tell you, as far as order of magnitude, the oil markets have been a drag. Obviously, just in the recent weeks, you start to see the oil prices coming back. T
componenttext: Well, obviously, Michael, it's very difficult to project how long that would be. Now what I would tell you, as far as order of magnitude, the oil markets have been a drag. Obviously, just in the recent weeks, you start to see the oil prices coming back. They are having a few more rigs put back into place, not that that's going to turn on the light switch but, obviously, it's more of a positive indication. Next, if -- on the hierarchy would be really the impact of the cold weather products, and that would be probably the second biggest drag on the comps. And then really, thirdly, it's the farm economies. It's really all 3 combined which is having the impact. So as any one of those start to turn, obviously, it would have a favorable impact on the business. So I wouldn't necessarily say we need all 3 of them to turn around to start to see the comps really improve dramatically. And of the -- of those 3 factors, farm income probably is the least of the 3.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful, Tony. Two points to clarify, you mentioned double-digit earnings growth for next year, are you saying think about double-digit earnings growth and then subtract the incentive comp piece and the extra week piece? Or is that not the ri
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful, Tony. Two points to clarify, you mentioned double-digit earnings growth for next year, are you saying think about double-digit earnings growth and then subtract the incentive comp piece and the extra week piece? Or is that not the right way to think about it?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say that would be the correct way to look at it. I would say you want to adjust for those items and then this team here is -- we are geared towards driving double-digit growth, but we need to adjust those 2 factors.
componenttext: I would say that would be the correct way to look at it. I would say you want to adjust for those items and then this team here is -- we are geared towards driving double-digit growth, but we need to adjust those 2 factors.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then will there be -- what would the -- how should we think about the sales contribution from Petsense in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: And then will there be -- what would the -- how should we think about the sales contribution from Petsense in the fourth quarter?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're not providing guidance at this time, but what we believe is that any bottom line benefit that we would receive would offset the transaction and/or integration cost in that quarter. So net-net, bottom line, there's an impact.
componenttext: We're not providing guidance at this time, but what we believe is that any bottom line benefit that we would receive would offset the transaction and/or integration cost in that quarter. So net-net, bottom line, there's an impact.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Peter Keith with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Peter Keith with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to circle back on the oil markets and maybe a little bit on the ag economies, too, with the economic issues. Which -- when you look at the oil markets that's 25% of the base, is that only South Central? Is that Texas? Or could you maybe frame that fo
componenttext: Just to circle back on the oil markets and maybe a little bit on the ag economies, too, with the economic issues. Which -- when you look at the oil markets that's 25% of the base, is that only South Central? Is that Texas? Or could you maybe frame that for us geographically? And then similarly, on the -- where the ag economies are at the worst?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Tony. I'll give you just a little bit more color as best as I can. In the prepared remarks, we talked about 25% of the store base, and that would include all energy which would be oil, it could also be coal in the Appalachian area and, obviously,
componenttext: This is Tony. I'll give you just a little bit more color as best as I can. In the prepared remarks, we talked about 25% of the store base, and that would include all energy which would be oil, it could also be coal in the Appalachian area and, obviously, the farming tends to be mostly in the Midwest and the Great Plains. So -- but what we're seeing is -- and since it's such a broad area of the country, all the stores are getting thrown in there, so it appears to be a much larger piece of the business. But when we run our models, we see that the correlation, specifically to all 3 of those, being any of the oil, energy, coal or farm, the correlation -- the direct correlation is only for about 25% of the store base. So those are the ones that are being directly impacted. So as much as we have a lot of stores in Texas, there's only x amount that are energy-impacted. So the first thing is I would not extrapolate it to every store in every state. What we're saying is about 25% of the stores are -- correlate directly and have a more significant impact than the rest of the chain.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. I want to pivot over to gross margin. Curious on the sharper pricing, it sounds like you're having some success there. Is that something that, with the ongoing sluggishness, you would anticipate continuing? And is there a possibility
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. I want to pivot over to gross margin. Curious on the sharper pricing, it sounds like you're having some success there. Is that something that, with the ongoing sluggishness, you would anticipate continuing? And is there a possibility to get some vendor support to perhaps mitigate that gross margin impact?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Steve Barbarick. We have been working with our supplier community. But we use our price optimization tool and systems here, and it's been very effective for us. And we continue to drive share in a lot of the key categories that are more price
componenttext: Yes. This is Steve Barbarick. We have been working with our supplier community. But we use our price optimization tool and systems here, and it's been very effective for us. And we continue to drive share in a lot of the key categories that are more price-sensitive like feed and, in some cases, pet food. I don't want to get too deep into the vendor support but we do work with our vendors to make sure that when we do promote and we do EDLP pricing that we're competitive and that we are continuing to gain share.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe just a follow-up on that for Tony, is there some risk of gross margin pressure continuing in a sluggish sales environment? Or is it just too tough to tell at this point looking out to next year?
componenttext: Okay. And maybe just a follow-up on that for Tony, is there some risk of gross margin pressure continuing in a sluggish sales environment? Or is it just too tough to tell at this point looking out to next year?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Obviously, it's too early to tell for next year. As we've done our sensitivities for Q4, we believe that if there is margin pressure with some of the pricing programs, we would expect to pick it up on the top line. And vice versa, if we aren't overly aggr
componenttext: Obviously, it's too early to tell for next year. As we've done our sensitivities for Q4, we believe that if there is margin pressure with some of the pricing programs, we would expect to pick it up on the top line. And vice versa, if we aren't overly aggressive on price, we'll pick it up on the margin side relative to the model that we ran for the quarter.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Steven Forbes with Guggenheim Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Steven Forbes with Guggenheim Securities.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: To start with the top line performance and trends within the different sales category thus far, so far this year, I know you mentioned livestock and pet rose mid-single-digits during the quarter. I think that's been relatively consistent. But can you prov
componenttext: To start with the top line performance and trends within the different sales category thus far, so far this year, I know you mentioned livestock and pet rose mid-single-digits during the quarter. I think that's been relatively consistent. But can you provide some color around the other categories, maybe just touching on the categories you lay out within the SEC filings, and how they've trended throughout the year just to give us a better perspective as we look out kind of over the next 6 to 12 months here as it relates to the compares by category?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steven, this is Steve, and I'll try to stay at a fairly high level here because we can break this thing down in a lot of little pieces and parts. But we talked about the impact that the energy markets have had on ticket, and I would go back and say that c
componenttext: Steven, this is Steve, and I'll try to stay at a fairly high level here because we can break this thing down in a lot of little pieces and parts. But we talked about the impact that the energy markets have had on ticket, and I would go back and say that categories such as welders, some compressors, those type of businesses have been a bit of a challenge for us. And you can see that in those individual markets where we are impacted most by energy, things like certain apparel, whether it's some steel footwear -- cold footwear or fire-retardant apparel, that you can actually look into those specific regions and you can pretty much kind of estimate what categories are going to be the most impacted there. In terms of the seasonal businesses, we talked about having a fairly soft spring but didn't drag into the fall and that benefited us. But we certainly didn't capture any of the preheating sales that we had traditionally gotten. Still, again, if you look at seasonal, it's kind of a tale of 2 stories how we preferred to have spring in spring and winter in winter, but that just hasn't necessarily been the case yet. So we're having to move some of our inventories around to better position ourselves to optimize where we think we can. And then the last thing I would tell you is in the truck tool and hardware business, it's a little similar to what I talked about earlier with some of the big ticket. Truck boxes, fuel handling, those kind of categories have been really soft for us. And again, we believe a lot of that is more energy-related. So does that help clarify some?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess. And then I guess as a follow-up, maybe if we can expand on it, regarding the trends in those more discretionary categories, right, the nonmaintenance side and not livestock and pets. I mean, I guess, just trying to understand the color aroun
componenttext: Yes, I guess. And then I guess as a follow-up, maybe if we can expand on it, regarding the trends in those more discretionary categories, right, the nonmaintenance side and not livestock and pets. I mean, I guess, just trying to understand the color around behavioral trends, right, as you think about the consumer shopping the store. And I'm not sure if you have visibility via talking to store managers or so forth, are the consumers coming into the box, right, because you're clearly driving traffic in the 34th consecutive quarter? And are they shopping the rest of the store and just not making, right -- exploring the side of the store, exploring the merchandising displays and just not making the purchase? Or are you seeing the consumers come in to the store and really just go right for that -- the back section livestock and pet and not even exploring, right, everything you're doing on the merchandising side? And then how does that relate, right, to the initiatives you have in place and you're working on as it relates to space allocation merchandising and promotional activity, right, as you look to curtail those trends?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steven, this is Greg. Let me -- I'll make it very simple for you. There's evidence, not only in the consumer surveys that we've completed but in our current sales trends, that the customers have become more conservative in their purchasing behaviors. That
componenttext: Steven, this is Greg. Let me -- I'll make it very simple for you. There's evidence, not only in the consumer surveys that we've completed but in our current sales trends, that the customers have become more conservative in their purchasing behaviors. That doesn't mean they're not still buying but they're buying more conservative, which means they're buying absolutely what they need at the time that they need it. They're still shopping the store as evidenced by the transaction increases that we're seeing. They're still supporting the pet, the animal and some land maintenance and in other categories across the stores. So we're not seeing them just cherry-pick. They're actually shopping across the store. But they pull back considerably on big ticket spends for now. We think there's a number of factors involved there, not just the energy markets and some of the things happening in the ag economy. But we're going get to -- listen again this evening on a debate about who's going to be the next President of the United States, and those things have some effect on our customer, no question. We have heard from them in these surveys that they feel their budgets are a bit tighter right now. And as we've been monitoring sales trends and looking at this by region, the customer demand for those things that are needed to support the lifestyle continue to exist, continue -- they continue to come in and purchase in our stores. So we have got to keep bringing new products. We got to keep updating the merchandise assortments, keeping those stores fresh. And I can tell you, the consumer count is still there, but they're being very conservative and very thoughtful in their spends.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Simeon Gutman with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Simeon Gutman with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I want to ask about farm income and -- because a couple of years ago, it actually started to nosedive. And we know from history, there was no impact to the business. And actually, the deceleration were sharper 2 or 3 years ago than any time in 2016. So
componenttext: So I want to ask about farm income and -- because a couple of years ago, it actually started to nosedive. And we know from history, there was no impact to the business. And actually, the deceleration were sharper 2 or 3 years ago than any time in 2016. So I'm trying to figure out what's happening now? Why wasn't it evident before if something else was sort of hiding the impact? Because I think what we're all trying to get at is -- it's hard to quantify, we don't know when it's going to end but because you weren't getting hit by it before, how do we understand the downside? And I'm sure you're trying to figure out the same thing, but how are you thinking about it?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Simeon, this is Greg. This -- when we studied that in years past and up till even at this point in time, this is the first time in a number of years that, back to back to back years, the farm community has suffered losses in the crops that they've tried t
componenttext: Simeon, this is Greg. This -- when we studied that in years past and up till even at this point in time, this is the first time in a number of years that, back to back to back years, the farm community has suffered losses in the crops that they've tried to bring in and sell. There's also a factor in cattle, which most people don't think about, but in the state of Texas and in a few states north of that, it's a big impact as well. Cattle prices, $1 less per pound. I mean, we hear these things from our customers, and I would tell you that I think it's more severe now than it was in the past. I'll also tell you that in the model of our business, this is the first time that we've seen energy come into the same kind of play on top of these other aspects. So multiple things working at the same time, it's not -- the farming piece, we just mentioned this time and said it's more of a factor or at least it's a bit of an overhang because it's the first time in a number of years, we can actually say in those communities, we're seeing the softness. We didn't see that before. But it's other factors on top of those factors, we believe, that have caused the drag.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just to follow on -- I guess, clarifying that, not a follow-up yet. But would you say, I guess, there's been a lag? Or are you saying they're somewhat of a coincidence now just because it's just amplifying some of the other pressures?
componenttext: So just to follow on -- I guess, clarifying that, not a follow-up yet. But would you say, I guess, there's been a lag? Or are you saying they're somewhat of a coincidence now just because it's just amplifying some of the other pressures?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you just answered your own question.
componenttext: I think you just answered your own question.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my second question, it sounds like you're stepping up the marketing to help drive the sales. What about any, I guess, temptation to promote during this environment? Greg, is there any -- or Steve, I mean -- doesn't it make sense -- does tha
componenttext: Okay. And then my second question, it sounds like you're stepping up the marketing to help drive the sales. What about any, I guess, temptation to promote during this environment? Greg, is there any -- or Steve, I mean -- doesn't it make sense -- does that not make sense for your business?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Simeon, here's how it works. When there's no demand for certain categories of products, there's not a price that you can sell that product to the consumer for. And I'm talking of things like heating, I'm talking about things like possibly large farm equip
componenttext: Simeon, here's how it works. When there's no demand for certain categories of products, there's not a price that you can sell that product to the consumer for. And I'm talking of things like heating, I'm talking about things like possibly large farm equipment or larger pieces of equipment, big ticket items and so on. You have to have the consumer demand. Now we're going to need to be a little patient here and understand that we can maneuver and control inventories in some of those categories where the demand is not great right now, but we want to make sure, and Steve would tell you this, that we have the ability to react if the category starts to accelerate. We believe there'll still be a heating business this year, but we think it's going to come later. We do believe there'll be some outerwear business and some, call it, seasonal-type businesses this year. But until we see some weather improvement, meaning cooler weather, that's not going to transpire. So instead, inventories have been shifted a bit. And where we put our and place our bets is on the things within C.U.E. and the categories that are retailing right now and doing well. But we have every ability to react when things would move in the right direction, and we believe it will come. We don't know the timing of it, but we do believe some of these seasonal trends will shift.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ben Bienvenu with Stephens Inc.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ben Bienvenu with Stephens Inc.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tony, I think in the past, you had quantified the differential between your energy-exposed markets and the rest of the chain to be around 400 to 500 basis points. Is that still the case today in light of sort of the broadening of the store base that's see
componenttext: Tony, I think in the past, you had quantified the differential between your energy-exposed markets and the rest of the chain to be around 400 to 500 basis points. Is that still the case today in light of sort of the broadening of the store base that's seeing weakness and the broadening of the SKU set that's seeing weakness?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Ben, you're correct. It has -- the difference has continued. It's been very consistent over the last 3 quarters. But where we're disappointed is that, as we have mentioned on a previous conference call, we were hoping that differential would moderate
componenttext: Yes. Ben, you're correct. It has -- the difference has continued. It's been very consistent over the last 3 quarters. But where we're disappointed is that, as we have mentioned on a previous conference call, we were hoping that differential would moderate as we came into the back half of the year, and we have not seen that happen. So there's still is a relatively large delta. And again, until the economies really start to turn a little bit, we expect that we'll have a similar delta throughout the end of the year.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then when you look at the ag-exposed markets, is it a similar magnitude of differential? Or is it less or more? Any quantification you could provide there would be helpful.
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then when you look at the ag-exposed markets, is it a similar magnitude of differential? Or is it less or more? Any quantification you could provide there would be helpful.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. The differential is a little bit less, and it's very, very less number of stores as well.
componenttext: Sure. The differential is a little bit less, and it's very, very less number of stores as well.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Alan Rifkin with BTIG.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Alan Rifkin with BTIG.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to follow up on a couple of earlier questions. So you've cited agricultural impact as well as energy as 2 of the 3 reasons. So can you just try to help us delineate the impact between just those 2 variables on the business?
componenttext: Just to follow up on a couple of earlier questions. So you've cited agricultural impact as well as energy as 2 of the 3 reasons. So can you just try to help us delineate the impact between just those 2 variables on the business?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, which 2?
componenttext: I'm sorry, which 2?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: The ag and energy.
componenttext: The ag and energy.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Agriculture and energy. Now I understand the impact from both of them, but are you able to segregate the effect of agriculture alone in the business versus energy alone?
componenttext: Agriculture and energy. Now I understand the impact from both of them, but are you able to segregate the effect of agriculture alone in the business versus energy alone?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's, at times, very difficult to segregate the 2 because you may have some that cross both, but I would try to give you a generalization of the magnitude. It's probably at least 3:1 when it comes to the impact of oil on the comps versus farm on the
componenttext: Well, it's, at times, very difficult to segregate the 2 because you may have some that cross both, but I would try to give you a generalization of the magnitude. It's probably at least 3:1 when it comes to the impact of oil on the comps versus farm on the comps.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And my follow-up, you're now talking about 113 stores for this year whereas, last quarter, you were talking about 115 to 120. When you take that together with your earlier statement, Tony, that, next year, you're going to open up "above 100 store ra
componenttext: Okay. And my follow-up, you're now talking about 113 stores for this year whereas, last quarter, you were talking about 115 to 120. When you take that together with your earlier statement, Tony, that, next year, you're going to open up "above 100 store range," should we think of your square footage in 2017 really being closer to 6% rather than the 7%, 7.5% versus what some people thought? And why the slippage of anywhere from 2 to 7 stores for this year?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're currently trying -- assessing the store target for next year. I would tell you that we have the majority of stores already in place and signed. As we move towards that north of 100 to 120 range, I would tell you that we will be very discriminate in
componenttext: We're currently trying -- assessing the store target for next year. I would tell you that we have the majority of stores already in place and signed. As we move towards that north of 100 to 120 range, I would tell you that we will be very discriminate in the softer sales environment and making sure that we make the right choices on those stores as we move forward. But we'll give you more guidance on the next conference call in January as to the 2017 store plan.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are you at liberty to say how many of the stores for 2017 are already signed?
componenttext: Are you at liberty to say how many of the stores for 2017 are already signed?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say -- well, we don't usually give out that number but I would say that number is defined, this is Greg. And I want you to think about something that most people don't realize, Alan. Back in '08 and '09, we were growing our store base at 10%. We s
componenttext: I would say -- well, we don't usually give out that number but I would say that number is defined, this is Greg. And I want you to think about something that most people don't realize, Alan. Back in '08 and '09, we were growing our store base at 10%. We saw a similar type of headwind occur and we said, "You know what, we could've slowed down to about 7% to 8% and hold there for a while until the economies in that time would improve." We're seeing a little bit of the same kind of drag, a little different variable this time than last, so Tony's comment earlier about we may not be at the 115, 120, that's always been a target, by the way. In real estate, you can, in a moment's notice, lose 2 or 3 stores because deals can't be completed or there's a problem with a contract or what have you. So for 2016, that's more of the instance. It's not -- we wanted to get more stores open, we just could not. But we'll talk more about that in specific as we get to the fourth quarter and we give our guidance for next year.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Scott Mushkin with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Scott Mushkin with Wolfe Research.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I just want to clarify a couple of things. The stores that are not in the 25% that are feeling the winds of oil and agriculture, are they comping 3% to 5% in your -- just to be very specific?
componenttext: So I just want to clarify a couple of things. The stores that are not in the 25% that are feeling the winds of oil and agriculture, are they comping 3% to 5% in your -- just to be very specific?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: When it comes to the -- those stores comping 3% to 5%, as we mentioned, the Southeast and the West. The Southeast, more on the lower end; the West is actually exceeding the upper end. Now again I pointed out that the West has a less mature store base give
componenttext: When it comes to the -- those stores comping 3% to 5%, as we mentioned, the Southeast and the West. The Southeast, more on the lower end; the West is actually exceeding the upper end. Now again I pointed out that the West has a less mature store base given the stores that we've opened over the last couple of years, so that we would expect them to comp a little bit stronger, but they have had very strong sales in those areas. Again, those stores that are highly correlated, obviously, the gap with a normalized comp is much greater. And then there's a swath of stores that range in between those numbers.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perfect. Then one other clarification. I know you guys talked about September. 2 weeks into October, is the momentum continuing?
componenttext: Perfect. Then one other clarification. I know you guys talked about September. 2 weeks into October, is the momentum continuing?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what we see in October are similar trends as in September. And as we moved into this quarter, we did anticipate that October will be the toughest compare. And obviously, the quarter is going to really be driven by November and December and the type
componenttext: Well, what we see in October are similar trends as in September. And as we moved into this quarter, we did anticipate that October will be the toughest compare. And obviously, the quarter is going to really be driven by November and December and the type of weather that we have in those 2 months.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perfect. Now to my real question, so much more of a kind of a secular question. So obviously, you guys have some cyclical issues now. But if you kind of take a longer view, comps have been kind of slowing for a while, return on invested capital turned dow
componenttext: Perfect. Now to my real question, so much more of a kind of a secular question. So obviously, you guys have some cyclical issues now. But if you kind of take a longer view, comps have been kind of slowing for a while, return on invested capital turned down about 18 months. How do you kind of view this? And then, of course, you went out and made an acquisition, an adjacent acquisition. How do you view more the -- what looks to be more of a secular slowing of the business versus what's going on cyclically?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I would tell you initially is that when you look back at the comps, we've had some very nice comps over the last 3 years in an environment with mostly deflation. And obviously, as we get into some of these periods where we have a downturn in the econ
componenttext: What I would tell you initially is that when you look back at the comps, we've had some very nice comps over the last 3 years in an environment with mostly deflation. And obviously, as we get into some of these periods where we have a downturn in the economy, we're going to be impacted. But we continue to believe that we'll make the necessary adjustments with the merchandising, we'll continue to drive strong store performance. And as these economies turn, we're going to be very well positioned to continue towards our long-term goal of 3% to 5% comps.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our next question comes from Stephen Tanal with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our next question comes from Stephen Tanal with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Obviously, a lot of ground to cover. I guess just a question for Steve maybe, is there anything going on in merchandising? Any initiatives that you guys are thinking about or new product categories or specific products, if you will? Anything you're
componenttext: Okay. Obviously, a lot of ground to cover. I guess just a question for Steve maybe, is there anything going on in merchandising? Any initiatives that you guys are thinking about or new product categories or specific products, if you will? Anything you're excited about that we should be thinking about here as we look out a quarter, 2 quarters, maybe into next year?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's a lot going on in the merchandising front. I would tell you that the team's all over certain trends right now. We continue to see, in the pet and animal side, people stepping up to premium. In natural foods, we've just expanded a number of organic
componenttext: There's a lot going on in the merchandising front. I would tell you that the team's all over certain trends right now. We continue to see, in the pet and animal side, people stepping up to premium. In natural foods, we've just expanded a number of organic products in the stores. We still see our customers tend to be self-reliant, so there are things that we're doing with chicken supplies and beekeeping. We've got resets that are taking place throughout the store right now on both sides that we think we can capitalize on things like premium, rubber footwear and things in truck accessories. So there's a variety of things. We've always said that we're a test-and-learning company. And we've been testing and learning a lot, and we're rolling and expanding a lot of programs out. So from that perspective, there's still a lot in the hopper. Just most recently, we expanded our animal test from 25 stores to 100 stores, thinking that this would be a good quarter to learn a little bit more in. In sporting goods, for example, we've got premium coolers and kayaks and other things going on. So if I were to walk in a store with you and walk through the entire 4 walls, I would tell you there's something happening in about every area.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's good to hear. And moving on to the loyalty card. I don't know -- some companies from time to time have actually quantified a lift that you get from sales. I don't know if there's anything like that, that you've seen. Obviously, over time, the
componenttext: Okay, that's good to hear. And moving on to the loyalty card. I don't know -- some companies from time to time have actually quantified a lift that you get from sales. I don't know if there's anything like that, that you've seen. Obviously, over time, there's more you can do with the data. But I'm curious to know if there has been a lift in sort of the test markets.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Stephen, this is Steve again. I would tell you that it's still early in the game for us. While we've got about a handful of stores sort of comped the first year, we're now just comping over last year's, and we're going to be able to give you much better i
componenttext: Stephen, this is Steve again. I would tell you that it's still early in the game for us. While we've got about a handful of stores sort of comped the first year, we're now just comping over last year's, and we're going to be able to give you much better indication on the next call. But I will tell you, we wouldn't be expanding if we didn't feel like we were getting a benefit.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Dan Wewer with Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question is from Dan Wewer with Raymond James.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I believe in some prior calls you noted that e-commerce revenues were less than 1% of total. I certainly recognize there is some of these products that are not friendly for online shopping but, nevertheless, would you think that the -- your penetration sh
componenttext: I believe in some prior calls you noted that e-commerce revenues were less than 1% of total. I certainly recognize there is some of these products that are not friendly for online shopping but, nevertheless, would you think that the -- your penetration should be exceeding that level given the investments that have been made?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dan, this is Steve again. I would tell you that we're seeing nice momentum in this space. We've added a number of new lines, online and content, and we're seeing the growth there. As you know, we've invested in a new platform, we've mobile-optimized
componenttext: Yes, Dan, this is Steve again. I would tell you that we're seeing nice momentum in this space. We've added a number of new lines, online and content, and we're seeing the growth there. As you know, we've invested in a new platform, we've mobile-optimized our website to ensure there's a consistent consumer experience across the device. And most recently, the impact of Buy Online for the store is having a very positive impact on our business. I think that alone, tied in with the initiatives we have, some around the fulfillment side, you'll see that percentage grow over time. And once it becomes more material, we'll be able to share with you exactly where we're at. But I would tell you that there's a lot of work being done, and we're very excited about what we're doing right now. And we're seeing the results of it.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: A second question, I know that you're still targeting 3% to 5% secular same-store sales growth. Can that be achieved if energy markets stabilize at current levels? Or do those markets need to rebound to where they were, say, 2 or 3 years ago to achieve th
componenttext: A second question, I know that you're still targeting 3% to 5% secular same-store sales growth. Can that be achieved if energy markets stabilize at current levels? Or do those markets need to rebound to where they were, say, 2 or 3 years ago to achieve that 3% to 5% company-wide target?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, this is Greg. Very difficult to predict, as you can imagine. But those energy markets, we're watching closely. And I would say that we can't predict if they're going to be any worse or any better. But my prediction, if I was going to give one on this
componenttext: Dan, this is Greg. Very difficult to predict, as you can imagine. But those energy markets, we're watching closely. And I would say that we can't predict if they're going to be any worse or any better. But my prediction, if I was going to give one on this, is a slight uptick in that business down there to stabilize would give our customers the confidence to go back and start spending again on some of those categories that we believe right now, from the survey work we've done, they're sitting back holding their monies. They're not releasing those funds right now because they're nervous. Once they can settle down, I do think we'll start to see some movement back, yes.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just one real quick question. A year ago, we were discussing some of the weaker first year sales volumes in Arizona and in Utah. Now we're talking about the strength in the Western markets. Are we seeing those stores that opened up have slower revenue
componenttext: And just one real quick question. A year ago, we were discussing some of the weaker first year sales volumes in Arizona and in Utah. Now we're talking about the strength in the Western markets. Are we seeing those stores that opened up have slower revenues? Are they achieving that faster same-store sales growth now that they're in their second year?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, this is Tony. when we look at the comps and sort of the store maturation cycle, we've always said that the newer stores are going to ramp at a higher pace than the chain. When in good times, and the chain is moving at your 3 to 5 comp, we're going to
componenttext: Dan, this is Tony. when we look at the comps and sort of the store maturation cycle, we've always said that the newer stores are going to ramp at a higher pace than the chain. When in good times, and the chain is moving at your 3 to 5 comp, we're going to be at a delta above that. We're seeing that the stores out West are running above that normalized delta. But given that, obviously, the rest of the chain is very flat, obviously, that helps to increase the delta between the mature stores and the new stores out there. But what I would tell you is that, yes, some of the stores that came out slow are ramping at a much nicer pace. We're very pleased with those stores. And that's why when we look at the new store productivity, and we spend a great deal of time looking at it, we look at it more on a rolling 12. We know that some of the stores last year that we talked about came out a little bit soft. So we know that we probably have this lower new store productivity over the course of the year. But when we look at it and look at it over a 12 -- rolling 12, it's relatively consistent for the last 4 quarters. It has gone down slightly. Some of the West stores have come out slower, that's probably one of the bigger drivers. And some of the West stores also had a little bit more square footage as we've had some additional square footage so that we could have more allocation for the products since they tend to be strong feed stores. So that distorts the calculation a little as well. But IRR hurdle has not changed. We're meeting pro forma, and so we feel very good about the new stores, especially as we see the stores out West ramp.

componenttext: Yes, they are connected. I mean we brought the database in-house last month. So all the enrollments, all the customer data we have will be here, and we'll be able to manage it accordingly.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: And tie it -- was there any problem connecting shopper data to the -- individuals to specific market baskets while it was done outside of the company? Or is that all dependent on the loyalty program?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, no. I mean, what the loyalty program will do is give us access to every single one of the purchases they make as they go into our stores. But whether it was outsourced before or whether it's in-house, we're not going to see any material difference i
componenttext: Well, no. I mean, what the loyalty program will do is give us access to every single one of the purchases they make as they go into our stores. But whether it was outsourced before or whether it's in-house, we're not going to see any material difference in the data itself, it's just how we'll mine the data.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: A quick question on Petsense and more just about the timing of the announcement. It seems -- or if I remember correctly, that the sort of thought process was that you have a bunch of stores in front of you to open and that is the main focus, probably no a
componenttext: A quick question on Petsense and more just about the timing of the announcement. It seems -- or if I remember correctly, that the sort of thought process was that you have a bunch of stores in front of you to open and that is the main focus, probably no acquisitions during that time frame. Petsense is, obviously, very small. But again, it does seem like a different customer base on what you're saying about your learnings from HomeTown Pet. So now in a difficult macro environment you sort of have to try and manage 2 related but different businesses. What -- and related to questions about maybe where we are on a broader picture, what should we think about the timing of this announcement? Why now, I guess, is sort of the general question.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Adam, this is Greg. Two things to remember on Petsense. One is, it is not going to be a distraction for TSC, and it will not really look to take any type of funding and resources from TSC. As a matter of fact, it's a well-run little company. It is small i
componenttext: Adam, this is Greg. Two things to remember on Petsense. One is, it is not going to be a distraction for TSC, and it will not really look to take any type of funding and resources from TSC. As a matter of fact, it's a well-run little company. It is small in base today but has tremendous growth opportunity, and it will basically fund itself. So don't worry about trying to run 2 businesses. They're not going to be integrated. It's a separate business. It runs separately. It has its own President and its own staff of people, and there will be no integration. This was a strategic buy, not an integration buy. There's the difference.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: Our final question comes from Joseph Feldman with Telsey Advisory Group.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Cristina Fernández for Joe. We wanted to ask about the incentive compensation. You talked about $0.07 to $0.08 headwind being your normalized compensation for next year but then, at the same time, EPS coming in below that midteens range. So how d
componenttext: This is Cristina Fernández for Joe. We wanted to ask about the incentive compensation. You talked about $0.07 to $0.08 headwind being your normalized compensation for next year but then, at the same time, EPS coming in below that midteens range. So how do you reconcile the two?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Cristina, this is Tony. What we're saying is that our incentive compensation is based against our plan. So as we move into 2017 and we create a new plan, we have to allocate to the incentive compensation expense line relative to our projected 2017 plan. S
componenttext: Cristina, this is Tony. What we're saying is that our incentive compensation is based against our plan. So as we move into 2017 and we create a new plan, we have to allocate to the incentive compensation expense line relative to our projected 2017 plan. So as we go through this year with very limited incentive compensation in the expense structure, once we recalibrate next year and put a new plan together, we need to put an on-plan incentive compensation. So we estimate that if we move back relative year-over-year that there'd be an increase in the expense structure of $0.07 to $0.08 to the bottom line. So having said that, we're just saying -- I'm just giving you notice that you need to adjust your models accordingly as a lot of people have been looking at this year's expense run rate and applying it to next year. So you just need to be able to add in some incentive compensation into your model next year, if you have not already.
