componenttext: I wanted to just follow up on a comment about September improving. I think the comment was that September was positive. Can you elaborate on that? And I know you said there was an easy comp, but did you see any sort of narrowing of the gap between some of those troubled markets versus the healthier markets?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Seth. This is Tony. As I mentioned on the remarks, it was an easier comparison. But as we looked at the individual markets, we did see that those markets were still the ones that had the same similar trends that we had in the July and August time fr
componenttext: Sure, Seth. This is Tony. As I mentioned on the remarks, it was an easier comparison. But as we looked at the individual markets, we did see that those markets were still the ones that had the same similar trends that we had in the July and August time frame. The one thing in September that did impact September was obviously not getting any type of cold snaps, and some of the preseason heating sales were still down. But again, going up against the easier compare of last year made September a positive comp.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And so just to clarify, when you talk about the 25% of the store base, that's either in energy markets or agricultural markets, you're not referring to those stores necessarily getting better in September?
componenttext: Okay. And so just to clarify, when you talk about the 25% of the store base, that's either in energy markets or agricultural markets, you're not referring to those stores necessarily getting better in September?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. When we look at those stores, those are clearly -- I want to say it's all ships rise with the current tide. So as we moved into September, obviously, we had stronger comps, but the difference or the delta between sort of a normalized comp in those st
componenttext: Yes. When we look at those stores, those are clearly -- I want to say it's all ships rise with the current tide. So as we moved into September, obviously, we had stronger comps, but the difference or the delta between sort of a normalized comp in those stores remained similar as it was in July and August.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And then on the expense side, obviously, very well-managed this quarter despite the tough environment. How are you thinking about the ability to leverage comps here? I mean, you gave some color on the fourth quarter, but just in general, as
componenttext: Okay, got it. And then on the expense side, obviously, very well-managed this quarter despite the tough environment. How are you thinking about the ability to leverage comps here? I mean, you gave some color on the fourth quarter, but just in general, as we look out over the next 12 months, to the extent that comps are maybe below that 3% to 5% long-term target, maybe what are some of the opportunities that the team is focused on to maybe take some expenses out?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We've been very aggressive in looking at the expenses for the back half as we saw the sales soften through Q2 and Q3. As we look out, we believe that we can continue to manage those discretionary expenses such as travel, training, looking at some of
componenttext: Sure. We've been very aggressive in looking at the expenses for the back half as we saw the sales soften through Q2 and Q3. As we look out, we believe that we can continue to manage those discretionary expenses such as travel, training, looking at some of the stores, really working with vendors to try to reduce our costs relative to maintenance, supplies, fixtures and things like that. So obviously, we'll continue to do that. The one thing that's very important to us, though, is we look at the long term. And so we do not want to do anything that would jeopardize the business. So we'll continue to make sure that we fund our stores, fund payroll, we want to make sure that we maintain market share and we want to convert those customers and maintain those customers as they come into our stores. The one thing that we do mention when we look out over the next 12 months is the incentive compensation piece. Though, obviously, it's much reduced this year, and we'll be comping up against that as we put in a more normalized incentive compensation, it will make it very difficult to get SG&A leverage.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Christopher Horvers with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question is from Christopher Horvers with JPMorgan.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So sort of a follow-up-on that. I mean, I know you haven't given full guidance for 2017. You have a long-term earnings algorithm out there of 3% to 5% comps and mid-teens earnings growth. And given the state of the world, it feels like that's not going to
componenttext: So sort of a follow-up-on that. I mean, I know you haven't given full guidance for 2017. You have a long-term earnings algorithm out there of 3% to 5% comps and mid-teens earnings growth. And given the state of the world, it feels like that's not going to be achievable next year, so any initial thoughts about how you're thinking about the sales outlook for next year? And the overall earnings growth would be really helpful.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. As we look out, we're still, one, very confident in the long-term store target of the 2,500. And we tend -- we still want to look out, and we believe that we're capable of driving that 3% to 5% comp on a long-term basis. Obviously, as we look at the
componenttext: Sure. As we look out, we're still, one, very confident in the long-term store target of the 2,500. And we tend -- we still want to look out, and we believe that we're capable of driving that 3% to 5% comp on a long-term basis. Obviously, as we look at the headwinds that are -- have been presented to us this year as well as we cannot determine at what point in time they will subside, we'll take a harder look at the short term and adjust our comps accordingly. At this point in time, though, we're not prepared to give full guidance on 2017. But obviously, given the current sales environment, we would agree with the consensus that it'd be difficult to hit the longer-term target of 3% to 5%.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And just related to that, so then is the message here, guys, like we've got $0.05, $0.06 for the 53rd week, you've got $0.07 to $0.08 from the incentive comp normalizing. So if consensus is like 3.60, is it -- essentially the message just to t
componenttext: Understood. And just related to that, so then is the message here, guys, like we've got $0.05, $0.06 for the 53rd week, you've got $0.07 to $0.08 from the incentive comp normalizing. So if consensus is like 3.60, is it -- essentially the message just to take those onetime items and reduce our numbers by that amount to bring it down to that 3.45 to 3.50-ish level?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, obviously, we want you to consider those factors in the model. We are a grower. We're going to continue to grow the store base next year. We anticipate to be above the 100-store range next year, and we -- the merchandising team is aggressive as far
componenttext: Well, obviously, we want you to consider those factors in the model. We are a grower. We're going to continue to grow the store base next year. We anticipate to be above the 100-store range next year, and we -- the merchandising team is aggressive as far as putting in programs and looking at new products and trying to drive the comps. So obviously, we're really working hard to have a very strong 2017 campaign. Having said that, we just understand that those headwinds of the 53rd week and the incentive compensation will have an impact on earnings. But again, our mindset here is we want to be double-digit earnings growth, and we're going to do whatever we can to make sure that happens.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And then just as a follow-up, how much of your mix would you say is heating-related in the fourth quarter? And then bigger picture, how much is cold weather-related sales as a percentage of mix in the fourth quarter as well?
componenttext: Understood. And then just as a follow-up, how much of your mix would you say is heating-related in the fourth quarter? And then bigger picture, how much is cold weather-related sales as a percentage of mix in the fourth quarter as well?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Christopher, this is Steve Barbarick. We typically don't get too detailed into the numbers. The big picture, we know that animal products is about 40% or 45% of our business and, seasonally, it changes. So again, we're not going to get that granular
componenttext: Yes, Christopher, this is Steve Barbarick. We typically don't get too detailed into the numbers. The big picture, we know that animal products is about 40% or 45% of our business and, seasonally, it changes. So again, we're not going to get that granular here.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Lasser with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Lasser with UBS.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's on the 25% of the business that's been underperforming. It seemed to catch you off-guard that the ag markets are rolling over. So what are you looking for to give you an indication that it's going to get better? I guess the point is, how long is this
componenttext: It's on the 25% of the business that's been underperforming. It seemed to catch you off-guard that the ag markets are rolling over. So what are you looking for to give you an indication that it's going to get better? I guess the point is, how long is this going to be a drag on the overall business?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, obviously, Michael, it's very difficult to project how long that would be. Now what I would tell you, as far as order of magnitude, the oil markets have been a drag. Obviously, just in the recent weeks, you start to see the oil prices coming back. T
componenttext: Well, obviously, Michael, it's very difficult to project how long that would be. Now what I would tell you, as far as order of magnitude, the oil markets have been a drag. Obviously, just in the recent weeks, you start to see the oil prices coming back. They are having a few more rigs put back into place, not that that's going to turn on the light switch but, obviously, it's more of a positive indication. Next, if -- on the hierarchy would be really the impact of the cold-weather products, and that would be probably the second biggest drag on the comps. And then really, thirdly, it's the farm economies. And it's really all 3 combined which is having the impact. So as any one of those start to turn, obviously, it would have a favorable impact on the business. So I wouldn't necessarily say we need all 3 of them to turn around to start to see the comps really improve dramatically. And of the -- of those 3 factors, farm income probably is the least of the 3.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful, Tony. Two points to clarify, you mentioned double-digit earnings growth for next year, are you saying think about double-digit earnings growth and then subtract the incentive comp piece and the extra week piece? Or is that not the ri
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful, Tony. Two points to clarify, you mentioned double-digit earnings growth for next year, are you saying think about double-digit earnings growth and then subtract the incentive comp piece and the extra week piece? Or is that not the right way to think about it?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say that would be the correct way to look at it. I would say you want to adjust for those items and then this team here is -- we are geared towards driving double-digit growth, but we need to adjust those 2 factors.
componenttext: I would say that would be the correct way to look at it. I would say you want to adjust for those items and then this team here is -- we are geared towards driving double-digit growth, but we need to adjust those 2 factors.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then will there be -- what will the -- how should we think about the sales contribution from Petsense in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: And then will there be -- what will the -- how should we think about the sales contribution from Petsense in the fourth quarter?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're not providing guidance at this time. What we believe is that any bottom line benefit that we would receive would offset the transaction and/or integration cost in that quarter. So net-net, bottom line, there's not impact.
componenttext: We're not providing guidance at this time. What we believe is that any bottom line benefit that we would receive would offset the transaction and/or integration cost in that quarter. So net-net, bottom line, there's not impact.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Peter Keith with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Peter Keith with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to circle back on the oil markets and maybe a little bit on the ag economies, too, with the economic issues. Which -- when you look at the oil markets that's 25% of the base, is that only South Central? Is that Texas? Or could you maybe frame that fo
componenttext: Just to circle back on the oil markets and maybe a little bit on the ag economies, too, with the economic issues. Which -- when you look at the oil markets that's 25% of the base, is that only South Central? Is that Texas? Or could you maybe frame that for us geographically? And then similarly, on the -- where the ag economies are at the worst?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Tony. I'll give you just a little bit more color as best as I can. In the prepared remarks, we talked about 25% of the store base, and that would include all energy which would be oil, it could also be coal in the Appalachian area and, obviously,
componenttext: This is Tony. I'll give you just a little bit more color as best as I can. In the prepared remarks, we talked about 25% of the store base, and that would include all energy which would be oil, it could also be coal in the Appalachian area and, obviously, the farming tends to be mostly in the Midwest and the Great Plains. So -- but what we're seeing is -- and since this is such a broad area of the country, all the stores are getting thrown in there, so it appears to be a much larger piece of business. But when we run our models, we see that the correlation, specifically to all 3 of those, being any of the oil, energy, coal or farm, the correlation -- the direct correlation is only for about 25% of the store base. So those are the ones that are being directly impacted. So as much as we have a lot of stores in Texas, there's only x amount that are energy-impacted. So the first thing is I would not extrapolate it to every store in every state. What we're saying is about 25% of the stores are -- correlate directly and have a more significant impact than the rest of the chain.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. I want to pivot over to gross margin. Curious on the sharper pricing, it sounds like you're having some success there. Is that something that, with the ongoing sluggishness, you would anticipate continuing? And is there a possibility
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. I want to pivot over to gross margin. Curious on the sharper pricing, it sounds like you're having some success there. Is that something that, with the ongoing sluggishness, you would anticipate continuing? And is there a possibility to get some vendor support to perhaps mitigate that gross margin impact?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Steve Barbarick. We have been working with our supplier community. But we use our price optimization tool and systems here, and it's been very effective for us. And we continue to drive share in a lot of the key categories that are more price
componenttext: Yes. This is Steve Barbarick. We have been working with our supplier community. But we use our price optimization tool and systems here, and it's been very effective for us. And we continue to drive share in a lot of the key categories that are more price-sensitive like feed and, in some cases, pet food. I don't want to get too deep into the vendor support but we do work with our vendors to make sure that when we do promote and we do EDLP pricing that we're competitive and that we are continuing to gain share.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe just a follow-up on that for Tony; is there some risk of gross margin pressure continuing in a sluggish sales environment? Or is it just too tough to tell at this point looking out to next year?
componenttext: Okay. And maybe just a follow-up on that for Tony; is there some risk of gross margin pressure continuing in a sluggish sales environment? Or is it just too tough to tell at this point looking out to next year?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Obviously, it's too early to tell for next year. As we've done our sensitivities for Q4, we believe that if there is margin pressure with some of the pricing programs, we would expect to pick it up on the top line. And vice versa, if we aren't overly aggr
componenttext: Obviously, it's too early to tell for next year. As we've done our sensitivities for Q4, we believe that if there is margin pressure with some of the pricing programs, we would expect to pick it up on the top line. And vice versa, if we aren't overly aggressive on price, we'll pick it up on the margin side relative to the model that we ran for the quarter.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Steven Forbes with Guggenheim Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Steven Forbes with Guggenheim Securities.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: To start with the top line performance and trends within the different sales category thus far, so far this year, I know you mentioned livestock and pet rose mid-single-digits during the quarter. I think that's been relatively consistent. But can you prov
componenttext: To start with the top line performance and trends within the different sales category thus far, so far this year, I know you mentioned livestock and pet rose mid-single-digits during the quarter. I think that's been relatively consistent. But can you provide some color around the other categories, maybe just touching on the categories you lay out within the SEC filings, and how they've trended throughout the year just to give us a better perspective as we look out kind of over the next 6 to 12 months here as it relates to the compares by category?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steven, this is Steve, and I'll try to stay at a fairly high level here because we can break this thing down in a lot of little pieces and parts. But we talked about the impact that the energy markets have had on ticket, and I would go back and say that c
componenttext: Steven, this is Steve, and I'll try to stay at a fairly high level here because we can break this thing down in a lot of little pieces and parts. But we talked about the impact that the energy markets have had on ticket, and I would go back and say that categories such as welders, some compressors, those type of businesses have been a bit of a challenge for us. And you can see that in those individual markets where we are impacted most by energy, things like certain apparel, whether it's some steel footwear -- toe footwear or fire-retardant apparel, that you can actually look into those specific regions and you can pretty much kind of estimate what categories are going to be the most impacted there. In terms of the seasonal businesses, we talked about having a fairly soft spring but then it drag into the fall and that benefited us. But we certainly didn't capture any of the preheating sales that we had traditionally gotten. So again, if you look at seasonal, it's kind of a tale of 2 stories. We prefer to have spring in spring and winter in winter, but that just hasn't necessarily been the case yet. So we're having to move some of our inventories around to better position ourselves to optimize where we think we can. And then the last thing I would tell you is in the truck, tool and hardware business, it's a little similar to what I talked about earlier with some of the big ticket. Truck boxes, fuel handling, those kind of categories have been really soft for us. And again, we believe a lot of that is more energy-related. So does that help clarify some?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess. And then I guess as a follow-up, maybe if we can expand on it, regarding the trends in those more discretionary categories, right, the nonmaintenance side and not livestock and pets. I mean, I guess, just trying to understand the color aroun
componenttext: Yes, I guess. And then I guess as a follow-up, maybe if we can expand on it, regarding the trends in those more discretionary categories, right, the nonmaintenance side and not livestock and pets. I mean, I guess, just trying to understand the color around behavioral trends, right, as you think about the consumer shopping the store. And I'm not sure if you have visibility via talking to the store managers or so forth, are the consumers coming into the box, right, because you're clearly driving traffic in the 34th consecutive quarter? And are they shopping the rest of the store and just not making, right -- exploring the side of the store, exploring the merchandising displays and just not making the purchase? Or are you seeing the consumers come in to the store and really just go right for that -- the back section livestock and pet and not even exploring, right, everything you're doing on the merchandising side? And then how does that relate, right, to the initiatives you have in place and you're working on as it relates to space allocation merchandising and promotional activity, right, as you look to curtail those trends?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steven, this is Greg. Let me -- I'll make it very simple for you. There's evidence not only in the consumer surveys that we've completed, but in our current sales trends, that the customers have become more conservative in their purchasing behaviors. That
componenttext: Steven, this is Greg. Let me -- I'll make it very simple for you. There's evidence not only in the consumer surveys that we've completed, but in our current sales trends, that the customers have become more conservative in their purchasing behaviors. That doesn't mean they're not still buying but they're buying more conservative, which means they're buying absolutely what they need at the time that they need it. They're still shopping the store as evidenced by the transaction increases that we're seeing. They're still supporting the pet, the animal and some land maintenance and in other categories across the stores. So we're not seeing them just cherry-pick. They're actually shopping across the store. But they pull back considerably on big ticket spends for now. We think there's a number of factors involved there, not just the energy markets and some of the things happening in the ag economy. But we're going get to listen again this evening on a debate about who's going to be the next President of the United States, and those things have some effect on our customer, no question. We have heard from them in these surveys that they feel their budgets are a bit tighter right now. And as we've been monitoring sales trends and looking at this by region, the customer demand for those things that are needed to support the lifestyle continue to exist, continue -- they continue to come in and purchase in our stores. So we have got to keep bringing new products. We got to keep updating the merchandise assortments, keeping those stores fresh. And I can tell you, the consumer count is still there, but they're being very conservative and very thoughtful in their spends.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Simeon Gutman with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Simeon Gutman with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I want to ask about farm income and -- because a couple of years ago, it actually started to nosedive. And we know from history, there was no impact to the business. And actually, the deceleration was sharper 2 or 3 years ago than any time in 2016. So
componenttext: So I want to ask about farm income and -- because a couple of years ago, it actually started to nosedive. And we know from history, there was no impact to the business. And actually, the deceleration was sharper 2 or 3 years ago than any time in 2016. So I'm trying to figure out what's happening now. Why wasn't it evident before if something else was sort of hiding the impact? Because I think what we're all trying to get at is -- it's hard to quantify and we don't know when it's going to end but because you weren't getting hit by it before, how do we understand the downside? And I'm sure you're trying to figure out the same thing, but how are you thinking about it?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Simeon, this is Greg. This -- when we studied that in years past and up 'til even at this point in time, this is the first time in a number of years that, back-to-back to back years, the farm community has suffered losses in the crops that they've tried t
componenttext: Simeon, this is Greg. This -- when we studied that in years past and up 'til even at this point in time, this is the first time in a number of years that, back-to-back to back years, the farm community has suffered losses in the crops that they've tried to bring in and sell. There's also a factor in cattle, which most people don't think about, but in the state of Texas and in a few states north of that, it's a big impact as well. Cattle prices, they're $1 less per pound. I mean, we hear these things from our customers, and I would tell you that I think it's more severe now than it was in the past. I'll also tell you that in the model of our business, this is the first time that we've seen energy come into the same kind of a play on top of these other aspects. So multiple things working at the same time, it's not -- the farming piece, we just mentioned this time and said it's more of a factor or at least it's a bit of an overhang because it's the first time in a number of years, we can actually say in those communities, we're seeing a softness. We didn't see that before. But it's other factors on top of those factors, we believe, that have caused the drag.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just to follow on -- I guess, clarifying that, not my follow-up yet. But would you say, I guess, there's been a lag? Or are you saying they're somewhat of a coincidence now just because it's just amplifying some of the other pressures?
componenttext: So just to follow on -- I guess, clarifying that, not my follow-up yet. But would you say, I guess, there's been a lag? Or are you saying they're somewhat of a coincidence now just because it's just amplifying some of the other pressures?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you just answered your own question.
componenttext: I think you just answered your own question.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my second question, it sounds like you're stepping up the marketing to help drive the sales. What about any, I guess, temptation to promote during this environment, Greg? Is there any -- or, Steve, I mean -- doesn't it make sense -- does th
componenttext: Okay. And then my second question, it sounds like you're stepping up the marketing to help drive the sales. What about any, I guess, temptation to promote during this environment, Greg? Is there any -- or, Steve, I mean -- doesn't it make sense -- does that not make sense for your business?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Simeon, here's how it works: When there's no demand for certain categories of products, there's not a price that you can sell that product to the consumer for. And I'm talking about things like heating. I'm talking about things like possibly large farm eq
componenttext: Simeon, here's how it works: When there's no demand for certain categories of products, there's not a price that you can sell that product to the consumer for. And I'm talking about things like heating. I'm talking about things like possibly large farm equipment or larger pieces of equipment, big ticket items and so on. You have to have the consumer demand. Now we're going to need to be a little patient here and understand that we can maneuver and control inventories in some of those categories where the demand's not great right now, but we want to make sure, and Steve will tell you this, that we have the ability to react if the category starts to accelerate. We believe there'll still be a heating business this year, but we think it's going to come later. We do believe there'll be some outerwear business and some, call it, seasonal-type businesses this year. But until we see some weather improvement, meaning cooler weather, that's not going to transpire. So instead, inventories have been shifted a bit. And where we put our -- and placed our bets is on the things within C.U.E. and the categories that are retailing right now and doing well. But we have every ability to react when things would move in the right direction, and we believe it will come. We don't now know the timing of it, but we do believe some of these seasonal trends will shift.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ben Bienvenu with Stephens Inc.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ben Bienvenu with Stephens Inc.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tony, I think in the past, you had quantified the differential between your energy-exposed markets and the rest of the chain to be around 400 to 500 basis points. Is that still the case today in light of sort of the broadening of the store base that's see
componenttext: Tony, I think in the past, you had quantified the differential between your energy-exposed markets and the rest of the chain to be around 400 to 500 basis points. Is that still the case today in light of sort of the broadening of the store base that's seeing weakness and the broadening of the SKU set that's seeing weakness?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Ben, you're correct. It has -- the difference has continued. It's been very consistent over the last 3 quarters. But where we're disappointed is that, as we have mentioned on a previous conference call, we were hoping that that differential would mod
componenttext: Yes. Ben, you're correct. It has -- the difference has continued. It's been very consistent over the last 3 quarters. But where we're disappointed is that, as we have mentioned on a previous conference call, we were hoping that that differential would moderate as we came into the back half of the year, and we have not seen that happen. So there still is a relatively large delta. And again, until the economies really start to turn a little bit, we expect that we'll have a similar delta throughout the end of the year.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then when you look at the ag-exposed markets, is it a similar magnitude of differential? Or is it less or more? Any quantification you could provide there would be helpful.
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then when you look at the ag-exposed markets, is it a similar magnitude of differential? Or is it less or more? Any quantification you could provide there would be helpful.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. The differential is a little bit less, and it's very, very less number of stores as well.
componenttext: Sure. The differential is a little bit less, and it's very, very less number of stores as well.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Alan Rifkin with BTIG.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Alan Rifkin with BTIG.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to follow up on a couple of earlier questions. So you've cited agricultural impact as well as energy as 2 of the 3 reasons. So can you just try to help us delineate the impact between just those 2 variables on the business?
componenttext: Just to follow up on a couple of earlier questions. So you've cited agricultural impact as well as energy as 2 of the 3 reasons. So can you just try to help us delineate the impact between just those 2 variables on the business?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, the -- which 2, the ag and energy?
componenttext: I'm sorry, the -- which 2, the ag and energy?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Agriculture and energy. Now I understand the impact from both of them, but are you able to segregate the effect of agriculture alone in the business versus energy alone?
componenttext: Agriculture and energy. Now I understand the impact from both of them, but are you able to segregate the effect of agriculture alone in the business versus energy alone?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's, at times, very difficult to segregate the 2 because you may have some that cross both, but I would try to give you a generalization of the magnitude. It's probably at least 3:1 when it comes to the impact of oil on the comps versus farm on the
componenttext: Well, it's, at times, very difficult to segregate the 2 because you may have some that cross both, but I would try to give you a generalization of the magnitude. It's probably at least 3:1 when it comes to the impact of oil on the comps versus farm on the comps.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And my follow-up, you're now talking about 113 stores for this year whereas, last quarter, you were talking about 115 to 120. When you take that together with your earlier statement, Tony, that, next year, you're going to open up "above 100 store ra
componenttext: Okay. And my follow-up, you're now talking about 113 stores for this year whereas, last quarter, you were talking about 115 to 120. When you take that together with your earlier statement, Tony, that, next year, you're going to open up "above 100 store range," should we think of your square footage in 2017 really being closer to 6% rather than the 7%, 7.5% versus what some people thought? And why the slippage of anywhere from 2 to 7 stores for this year?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're currently trying -- assessing the store target for next year. I would tell you that we have the majority of stores already in place and signed. As we move towards that north of 100 to 120 range, I would tell you that we will be very discriminate in
componenttext: We're currently trying -- assessing the store target for next year. I would tell you that we have the majority of stores already in place and signed. As we move towards that north of 100 to 120 range, I would tell you that we will be very discriminate in the softer sales environment and making sure that we make the right choices on those stores as we move forward. But we'll give you more guidance on the next conference call in January as to the 2017 store plan.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are you at liberty to say how many of the stores for 2017 are already signed?
componenttext: Are you at liberty to say how many of the stores for 2017 are already signed?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say -- well, we don't usually give out that number but I would say that number is defined. This is Greg. And I want you to think about something that most people don't realize, Alan. Back in '08 and '09, we were growing our store base at 10%. We s
componenttext: I would say -- well, we don't usually give out that number but I would say that number is defined. This is Greg. And I want you to think about something that most people don't realize, Alan. Back in '08 and '09, we were growing our store base at 10%. We saw a similar type of headwind occur and we said, you know what, we’re going to slow down to about 7% to 8% and hold there for a while until the economies, at that time, would improve. We're seeing a little bit of the same kind of drag, a little different variable this time than last, so Tony's comment earlier about we may not be at the 115, 120, that's always been a target, by the way. In real estate, you can, in a moment's notice, lose 2 or 3 stores because deals can't be completed or there's a problem with a contract or what have you. So for 2016, that's more of the instance. It's not -- we wanted to get more stores open, we just could not. But we'll talk more about that in specific as we get to the fourth quarter and we give our guidance for next year.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Scott Mushkin with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Scott Mushkin with Wolfe Research.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I just want to clarify a couple of things. The stores that are not in the 25% that are feeling the winds of oil and agriculture, are they comping 3% to 5% in your -- just to be very specific?
componenttext: So I just want to clarify a couple of things. The stores that are not in the 25% that are feeling the winds of oil and agriculture, are they comping 3% to 5% in your -- just to be very specific?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: When it comes to the -- those stores comping 3% to 5%, as we mentioned, the Southeast and the West. The Southeast, more on the lower end; the West is actually exceeding the upper end. Now, again, I'd pointed out that the West has a less mature store base
componenttext: When it comes to the -- those stores comping 3% to 5%, as we mentioned, the Southeast and the West. The Southeast, more on the lower end; the West is actually exceeding the upper end. Now, again, I'd pointed out that the West has a less mature store base given the stores that we've opened over the last couple of years, so that we would expect them to comp a little bit stronger, but they have had very strong sales in those areas. Again, those stores that are highly correlated, obviously, the gap with a normalized comp is much greater. And then there's a swath of stores that range in between those numbers.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perfect. Then one other clarification. I know you guys talked about September. Two weeks into October, is the momentum continuing?
componenttext: Perfect. Then one other clarification. I know you guys talked about September. Two weeks into October, is the momentum continuing?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what we see in October are similar trends as in September. And as we moved into this quarter, we did anticipate that October will be the toughest compare. And obviously, the quarter is going to really be driven by November and December and the type
componenttext: Well, what we see in October are similar trends as in September. And as we moved into this quarter, we did anticipate that October will be the toughest compare. And obviously, the quarter is going to really be driven by November and December and the type of weather that we have in those 2 months.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perfect. Now to my real question, so much more of a -- kind of a secular question. So obviously, you guys have some cyclical issues now. But if you kind of take a longer view, comps have been kind of slowing for a while, return on invested capital turned
componenttext: Perfect. Now to my real question, so much more of a -- kind of a secular question. So obviously, you guys have some cyclical issues now. But if you kind of take a longer view, comps have been kind of slowing for a while, return on invested capital turned down about 18 months. How do you kind of view this? And then, of course, you went out and made an acquisition, an adjacent acquisition. How do you view more the -- what looks to be more of a secular slowing of the business versus what's going on cyclically?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what I would tell you initially is that when you look back at the comps, we've had some very nice comps over the last 3 years and in an environment with mostly deflation. And obviously, as we get into some of these periods where we have a downturn i
componenttext: Well, what I would tell you initially is that when you look back at the comps, we've had some very nice comps over the last 3 years and in an environment with mostly deflation. And obviously, as we get into some of these periods where we have a downturn in the economy, we're going to be impacted. But we continue to believe that we'll make the necessary adjustments with the merchandising, we'll continue to drive strong store performance. And as these economies turn, we're going to be very well positioned to continue towards our long-term goal of 3% to 5% comps.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our next question comes from Stephen Tanal with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our next question comes from Stephen Tanal with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Obviously, a lot of groundcover. I guess just a question for Steve maybe, is there anything going on in merchandising? Any initiatives that you guys are thinking about or new product categories or specific products, if you will? Anything you're exci
componenttext: Okay. Obviously, a lot of groundcover. I guess just a question for Steve maybe, is there anything going on in merchandising? Any initiatives that you guys are thinking about or new product categories or specific products, if you will? Anything you're excited about that we should be thinking about here as you look out a quarter, 2 quarters, maybe into next year?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's a lot going on in the merchandising front. I would tell you that the team's all over certain trends right now. We continue to see, in the pet and animal side, people stepping up to premium and natural foods. We've just expanded a number of organic
componenttext: There's a lot going on in the merchandising front. I would tell you that the team's all over certain trends right now. We continue to see, in the pet and animal side, people stepping up to premium and natural foods. We've just expanded a number of organic products in the stores. We still see our customers tend to be self-reliant, so there are things that we're doing with chicken supplies and beekeeping. We've got resets that are taking place throughout the store right now on both sides that we think we can capitalize on things like premium, rubber footwear and things in truck accessories. So there's a variety of things. We've always said that we're a test-and-learning company. And we've been testing and learning a lot, and we're rolling and expanding a lot of programs out. So from that perspective, there's still a lot in the hopper. Just most recently, we expanded our ammo tests from 25 stores to 100 stores, thinking that this would be a good quarter to learn a little bit more in. In sporting goods, for example, we've got premium coolers and kayaks and other things going on. So if I were to walk a store with you and walk through the entire 4 walls, I would tell you there's something happening in about every area.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's good to hear. And moving on to the loyalty card. I don't know -- some companies from time to time have actually quantified a lift that you get from sales. I don't know if there's anything like that, that you've seen. Obviously, over time, the
componenttext: Okay, that's good to hear. And moving on to the loyalty card. I don't know -- some companies from time to time have actually quantified a lift that you get from sales. I don't know if there's anything like that, that you've seen. Obviously, over time, there's more you can do with the data. But I'm curious to know if there has been a lift in sort of the test markets.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Stephen, this is Steve again. I would tell you that it's still early in the game for us. While we've got about a handful of stores that have comped the first year, we're now just comping over last year's, and we're going to be able to give you much better
componenttext: Stephen, this is Steve again. I would tell you that it's still early in the game for us. While we've got about a handful of stores that have comped the first year, we're now just comping over last year's, and we're going to be able to give you much better indication on the next call. But I will tell you, we wouldn't be expanding if we didn't feel like we were getting a benefit.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Dan Wewer with Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question is from Dan Wewer with Raymond James.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I believe in some prior calls you noted that e-commerce revenues were less than 1% of total. I certainly recognize there are some of these products that are not friendly for online shopping but, nevertheless, would you think that the -- your penetration s
componenttext: I believe in some prior calls you noted that e-commerce revenues were less than 1% of total. I certainly recognize there are some of these products that are not friendly for online shopping but, nevertheless, would you think that the -- your penetration should be exceeding that level given the investments that have been made?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dan, this is Steve again. I would tell you that we're seeing nice momentum in this space. We've added a number of new lines, online and content, and we're seeing good growth there. As you know, we've invested in a new platform, we've mobile-optimized
componenttext: Yes, Dan, this is Steve again. I would tell you that we're seeing nice momentum in this space. We've added a number of new lines, online and content, and we're seeing good growth there. As you know, we've invested in a new platform, we've mobile-optimized our website to ensure there's a consistent consumer experience across the device. And most recently, the impact of Buy Online for the store is having a very positive impact on our business. I think that alone, tied in with the initiatives we have, some around the fulfillment side, you'll see that percentage grow over time. And once it becomes more material, we'll be able to share with you exactly where we're at. But I would tell you that there's a lot of work being done, and we're very excited about what we're doing right now. And we're seeing the results of it.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: A second question, I know that you're still targeting 3% to 5% secular same-store sales growth. Can that be achieved if energy markets stabilize at current levels? Or do those markets need to rebound to where they were, say, 2 or 3 years ago to achieve th
componenttext: A second question, I know that you're still targeting 3% to 5% secular same-store sales growth. Can that be achieved if energy markets stabilize at current levels? Or do those markets need to rebound to where they were, say, 2 or 3 years ago to achieve that 3% to 5% companywide target?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, this is Greg. Very difficult to predict, as you can imagine. But those energy markets, we're watching closely. And I would say that we can't predict if they're going to be any worse or any better. But my prediction, if I was going to give one on this
componenttext: Dan, this is Greg. Very difficult to predict, as you can imagine. But those energy markets, we're watching closely. And I would say that we can't predict if they're going to be any worse or any better. But my prediction, if I was going to give one on this, is a slight uptick in that business down there to stabilize would give our customers the confidence to go back and start spending again on some of those categories that we believe right now, from the survey work we've done, they're sitting back holding their monies. They're not releasing those funds right now because they're nervous. Once they can settle down, I do think we'll start to see some movement back, yes.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just one real quick question. A year ago, we were discussing some of the weaker first year sales volumes in Arizona and in Utah. Now, we're talking about the strength in the Western markets. Are we seeing those stores that opened up have slower revenu
componenttext: And just one real quick question. A year ago, we were discussing some of the weaker first year sales volumes in Arizona and in Utah. Now, we're talking about the strength in the Western markets. Are we seeing those stores that opened up have slower revenues? Are they achieving that faster same-store sales growth now that they're in their second year?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, this is Tony. When we look at the comps and sort of the store maturation cycle, we've always said that the newer stores are going to ramp at a higher pace than the chain. When in good times, and the chain is moving out at your 3% to 5% comp, we're go
componenttext: Dan, this is Tony. When we look at the comps and sort of the store maturation cycle, we've always said that the newer stores are going to ramp at a higher pace than the chain. When in good times, and the chain is moving out at your 3% to 5% comp, we're going to be at a delta above that, we're seeing that the stores out West are running above that normalized delta. But given that, obviously, the rest of the chain is very flat, obviously, that helps to increase the delta between the mature stores and the new stores out there. But what I would tell you is that, yes, some of the stores that came out slow are ramping at a much nicer pace. We're very pleased with those stores. And that's why when we look at the new store productivity, and we spend a great deal of time looking at it, we look at it more on a rolling 12. We know that some of the stores last year that we talked about came out a little bit soft. So we know that we probably have this lower new store productivity over the course of the year. But when we look at it and look at it over a 12 -- rolling 12, it's relatively consistent for the last 4 quarters. It has gone down slightly. Some of the West stores have come out slower, that's probably one of the bigger drivers. And some of the West stores also had a little bit more square footage as we've had some additional square footage so that we could have more allocation for the products since they tend to be strong feed stores. So that distorts the calculation a little as well. But IRR hurdle has not changed. We're meeting pro forma, and so we feel very good about the new stores, especially as we see the stores out West ramp.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Chuck Cerankosky from Northcoast Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Chuck Cerankosky from Northcoast Research.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to let you know, the Cleveland Indians are up 3 to nothing. Somebody mentioned earlier you're thinking about taking your data warehouse, my words, in-house and starting to manage that. How does that work as you start to roll out the loyalty card? I a
componenttext: Just to let you know, the Cleveland Indians are up 3 to nothing. Somebody mentioned earlier you're thinking about taking your data warehouse, my words, in-house and starting to manage that. How does that work as you start to roll out the loyalty card? I assume they're connected.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, they are connected. I mean we brought the database in-house, it was last month. And what we're going to be able to do now is mine it with our own folks rather than outsourcing it to a third party. So all the enrollments, all the customer data we have
componenttext: Yes, they are connected. I mean we brought the database in-house, it was last month. And what we're going to be able to do now is mine it with our own folks rather than outsourcing it to a third party. So all the enrollments, all the customer data we have will be here, and we'll be able to manage it accordingly.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And tie it -- was there any problem connecting shopper data to the -- individuals to specific market baskets while it was done outside of the company? Or is that all dependent on the loyalty program?
componenttext: And tie it -- was there any problem connecting shopper data to the -- individuals to specific market baskets while it was done outside of the company? Or is that all dependent on the loyalty program?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, no. I mean, what the loyalty program will do is give us access to every single one of the purchases they make as they go into our stores. But whether it was outsourced before or whether it's in-house, we're not going to see any material difference i
componenttext: Well, no. I mean, what the loyalty program will do is give us access to every single one of the purchases they make as they go into our stores. But whether it was outsourced before or whether it's in-house, we're not going to see any material difference in the data itself, it's just how we'll mine the data.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Adam Sindler with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Adam Sindler with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: A quick question on Petsense and more just about the timing of the announcement. It seems, or if I remember correctly, that the sort of thought process was that you have a bunch of stores in front of you to open and that is the main focus, probably no acq
componenttext: A quick question on Petsense and more just about the timing of the announcement. It seems, or if I remember correctly, that the sort of thought process was that you have a bunch of stores in front of you to open and that is the main focus, probably no acquisitions during that time frame. Petsense is, obviously, very small. But again, it does seem like a different customer, based on what you're saying about your learnings from HomeTown Pet. So now, in a different -- difficult macro environment, you sort of have to try and manage 2 related but different businesses. What -- and related to questions about maybe where we are on a broader picture, what should we think about the timing of this announcement? Why now, I guess, is sort of the general question.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Adam, this is Greg. Two things to remember on Petsense. One is, it is not going to be a distraction for TSC, and it will not really look to take any type of funding and resources from TSC. As a matter of fact, it's a well-run little company. It is small i
componenttext: Adam, this is Greg. Two things to remember on Petsense. One is, it is not going to be a distraction for TSC, and it will not really look to take any type of funding and resources from TSC. As a matter of fact, it's a well-run little company. It is small in base today but it has tremendous growth opportunity, and it will basically fund itself. So don't worry about trying to run 2 businesses. They're not going to be integrated. It's a separate business. It runs separately. It has its own President and its own staff of people, and there will be no integration. This was a strategic buy, not an integration buy. There's the difference.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our final question comes from Joseph Feldman with Telsey Advisory Group.
componenttext: Our final question comes from Joseph Feldman with Telsey Advisory Group.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Cristina Fernández for Joe. We wanted to ask about the incentive compensation. You talked about $0.07 to $0.08 headwind being your normalized compensation for next year but then, at the same time, EPS coming in below that mid-teens range. So how
componenttext: This is Cristina Fernández for Joe. We wanted to ask about the incentive compensation. You talked about $0.07 to $0.08 headwind being your normalized compensation for next year but then, at the same time, EPS coming in below that mid-teens range. So how do you reconcile the 2?

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Cristina, this is Tony. What we're saying is that our incentive compensation is based against our plan. So as we move into 2017 and we create a new plan, we have to allocate to the incentive compensation expense line relative to our projected 2017 plan. S
componenttext: Cristina, this is Tony. What we're saying is that our incentive compensation is based against our plan. So as we move into 2017 and we create a new plan, we have to allocate to the incentive compensation expense line relative to our projected 2017 plan. So as we go through this year with very limited incentive compensation in the expense structure, once we recalibrate next year and put a new plan together, we need to put a on-plan incentive compensation. So we estimate that if we move back relative year-over-year that there would be an increase in the expense structure of $0.07 to $0.08 to the bottom line. So having said that, we're just saying -- I'm just giving you notice that you need to adjust your models accordingly as a lot of people have been looking at this year's expense run rate and applying it to next year. So you just need to be able to add in some incentive compensation into your model next year, if you have not already.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: That does conclude our question-and-answer session. I'd like to turn the call back over to Greg Sandfort for closing comments.
componenttext: That does conclude our question-and-answer session. I'd like to turn the call back over to Greg Sandfort for closing comments.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Tractor Supply Company's conference call to discuss third quarter 2016 results. [Operator Instructions] Please be advised that reproduction of this call, in whole or in part, is not permitted without
componenttext:
Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Tractor Supply Company's conference call to discuss third quarter 2016 results. [Operator Instructions] 
Please be advised that reproduction of this call, in whole or in part, is not permitted without written authorization of Tractor Supply Company. And as a reminder, this call is being recorded. 
I would now like to introduce your host for today's call, Ms. Christine Skold of Tractor Supply Company. Christine, please go ahead.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Camille. Good afternoon. And thank you, for joining us for Tractor Supply Company's quarterly earnings conference call.Before we begin, let me reference the safe harbor provisions under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Th
componenttext:
Thank you, Camille. Good afternoon. And thank you, for joining us for Tractor Supply Company's quarterly earnings conference call.
Before we begin, let me reference the safe harbor provisions under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. This call may contain forward-looking statements that are subject to significant risks and uncertainties, including the future operating and financial performance of the company. Although the company believes the expectations reflected in its forward-looking statements are reasonable, it can give no assurance that such expectations or any of its forward-looking statements will prove to be correct.
Important risk factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those reflected in the forward-looking statements are included in the company's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The information contained in this call is accurate only as of the date discussed. And investors should not assume that statements will remain operative at a later time. Lastly, Tractor Supply Company undertakes no obligation to update any information discussed in this call.
As a reminder, the focus of this call is to discuss third quarter earnings results, and we do not have any additional update on the Petsense acquisition at this time. We ask that your questions during the call and during follow-up telephone calls focus on Tractor Supply Company's results. 
I'm now pleased to introduce Greg Sandfort, Tractor Supply Company's Chief Executive Officer. Greg, please go ahead.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us. On the call with me today are Tony Crudele, our EVP and Chief Financial Officer; Steve Barbarick, our President and Chief Merchandising and Marketing Officer; and Kurt Barton, our Senior VP and Controlle
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us. On the call with me today are Tony Crudele, our EVP and Chief Financial Officer; Steve Barbarick, our President and Chief Merchandising and Marketing Officer; and Kurt Barton, our Senior VP and Controller. 
As we previously discussed in our business update earlier in September, there were several headwinds affecting our business during the third quarter. We have dedicated a considerable amount of time and effort gathering and analyzing data during the quarter to understand more fully the impact these headwinds have had on our performance, and we do not believe the current sales trends are the result of significant shifts in the competitive landscape, our market share growth or our long-term operating fundamentals. In fact, our core everyday business in categories such as Livestock and Pet remained strong throughout the third quarter, and our business outside of the energy and agricultural markets in regions like the Southwest and West performed very well for the quarter. We did, however, experience softer demand in the energy and agricultural markets, and we saw a slow start to the early preseason sales of cold weather- and heating-related products that impacted the Northern region.
We have managed successfully through challenging sales environments before, the recession of 2008, 2009. And during those most difficult sales periods, our teams remained focused on managing the factors they could control such as inventory, gross margin and other expenses. We made the necessary adjustments then by taking a long-term balanced approach as we cycled through those periods, and we will do the same for now until these short-term headwinds subside.
At Tractor Supply, we are committed to introduce new products and updating in merchandise categories to keep our stores fresh. And with the current sales environment, we are specifically targeting those categories that have demonstrated strong sales performance year-to-date. Already this fall season, we have had several series of calls with field leadership across several of our more challenged markets to understand the depth of the issues we face. As a result of those calls, we executed a number of timely inventory investments to ensure that we have the appropriate emphasis on categories of high demand in those regions that are performing well: categories such as pet food, agricultural fencing and grass seed, to name a few.
Additionally, recognizing that cold weather and winter preparedness sales were slower to ramp, we adjusted our inventories downward on cold-weather products and upward on warm weather regional categories where customer demand stayed high such as fly control, riding lawnmowers, short-sleeved shirts and packaged seeds. Having this agility to react to current sales trends, we believe, is the level of sophistication and capability that differentiates us from most of our competition. 
Now with respect to our management of seasonal inventory, we are monitoring sales trends closely and continue to adjust for ongoing customer demand. For example, in the heating category, which I mentioned earlier, we have experienced sluggish early demand and we have kept inventories at a minimum for now. When sales trends accelerate due to cooler weather, our supply chain and our vendor base are ready to react and will push inventory into our DCs then into our stores quickly so that we can meet the increased sales demands.
Also in many of our everyday basic items, C.U.E., we have elevated in-stock levels to meet the continuing strong demand for animal, pet and land care needs. While we may be a chain of 1,500-plus stores, what is important to understand about our customer is that they perceive Tractor Supply as their unique farm store, conveniently located in their small community that offers them locally correct assortments that meet the unique outdoor lifestyle needs they have.
Now on the marketing front. We adjusted Q3 and forward programs based on current sales trends by region in an effort to accelerate our comp store sales. We added radio advertising to promote key events during the quarter such as our annual Pet Appreciation Week and Lowest Prices of the Season event. We enhanced our digital impressions to our web customers and increased our circular distribution to a larger base of our best customers, and we added several targeted sales driving initiatives in key sales weeks to improve our overall sales and marketing effectiveness.
To demonstrate how we are focusing on the growth of our business for the long term, we are continuing to invest in technology to improve our capture of customer insights. This includes the rollout of our Neighbor's Club loyalty program which we believe will give Tractor Supply a unique way to communicate with our customer base by offering a more relevant and personalized message. As well, we completed bringing our customer database in-house so that we could better analyze and segment the customer information that we are collecting from our Neighbor's Club members.
We added an additional 45 stores to the Neighbor's Club program on October 1 in the Western region. And with the initial customer enrollment and customer response being so positive, we now plan to roll the program out to all stores by the middle of 2017.
We continue to invest in the platforms where our customers choose to shop, giving them more options in the way they can interact with the Tractor Supply Company as a brand. This includes the introduction of Buy Online Pickup in Store, which we started piloting in September and expect to have wide in over half of the chain by the end of this year. We are also continuing to invest in our Tractor Supply website to improve search capabilities and to enhance the know-how section for product content and projects that are important to our customers using videos and online articles. And we continue to invest in store-level resources, including mobile POS and a more intuitive special order process that will assist our team members and our customers to locate hard-to-find products.
As a company, we remain confident in our long-term store target of 2,500 domestic Tractor Supply locations and mid-single-digit annual square footage growth. To help achieve this target, we recently conducted a comprehensive study of our logistics infrastructure to understand what would be required to add capacity and drive more supply chain efficiency as we move toward our long-term store target. One thing to note from the study data, we confirmed that we have a short-term need to add additional distribution capacity in the Northeast region if we plan to continue the store growth there. We have begun the planning process to enable the opening of a new distribution center in that region targeted for mid- to late 2018.
Our recently announced purchase of Petsense, a leading specialty retailer of pet supplies and services with over 130 stores in 25 states, is another example of our commitment to long-term growth. For some time now, we have discussed the Pet category as a growth opportunity for the company. And based on our research and experience with our own hometown pet concept, we concluded there is a substantial opportunity to grow the pet specialty business in small town America. Their expertise and success in growing a smaller pet specialty store format will allow Petsense to continue at a growth rate of 15% to 20% annually without distraction to the TSC business. Tractor Supply's proven expertise in site selection and store growth should make for a strong partnership with Petsense and allow us to accelerate their growth over time.
Over the longer term, we stay focused on our people and their development, on enhancing our merchandise assortments and adding IT capability to better meet the evolving needs of our customers while always being mindful to return value to our shareholders through sustainable longer-term growth.
Before I wrap up, I want to thank the nearly 23,000 members of the Tractor Supply family for their continued hard work, dedication and the level of service they provide our customers. A big hoorah [ph] to all. 
I would also like to welcome the Petsense team as members of the Tractor Supply family. We are proud to be partnered with you and are excited about the opportunity to develop and grow the Petsense business.
I will now turn the call over to Tony for more detailed commentary on our third quarter financial results and the outlook for the remainder of 2016.

headline: Tractor Supply Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Greg. And good afternoon, everyone. For the quarter ended September 24, 2016, on a year-over-year basis, net sales increased 4.5% to $1.54 billion; net income grew 2.4% to $89.4 million; and EPS increased 4.7% to $0.67 per diluted share.C
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, Greg. And good afternoon, everyone. For the quarter ended September 24, 2016, on a year-over-year basis, net sales increased 4.5% to $1.54 billion; net income grew 2.4% to $89.4 million; and EPS increased 4.7% to $0.67 per diluted share.
Comp store sales decreased 0.6% in the third quarter compared to an increase of 2.9% in last year's third quarter. There are a number of economic headwinds impacting consumer spending throughout many of our markets. However, as noted in our business update on September 7, the energy-producing and agricultural markets were the most impacted. To give you a sense of the magnitude of the macro impact of the energy and farm economies, we estimate that approximately 25% of our stores have a direct correlation to these economies. This does not include any of the stores that may be tangentially affected by the economies.
The strongest regional performance was in the Southeast and West regions where there is less exposure to the energy and agricultural markets. The West region base had a solid mid-single-digit comp, and the Southeast was well above chain average. We continue to experience strong demand for many of our basic everyday items such as Livestock and Pet category which generated mid-single-digit comparable chainwide sales. 
While the quarter did not shape up the way we expected, we continue to be well positioned for the long term. The solid comp sales in the nonimpacted regions support our position that the business will continue to drive profitable growth. As Greg said, we have been through periods like this before, and we have the leaders and the strategy to continue delivering value to customers, stakeholders and shareholders.
Comp transaction count increased for the 34th consecutive quarter, gaining 0.5% on top of a 3.8% increase last year as some C.U.E. items, such as pet food and animal feed, continue to drive strong traffic. Average comp ticket decreased by 111 basis points compared to last year's 90 basis points decrease. Big ticket was one of the largest drivers of this year's average ticket decrease. Comparable sales of big ticket items declined approximately 4.7%. The decline was across several categories related principally to the energy and farm markets as well as early season winter sales in the North. More discretionary items, such as UTVs, were down in the oil and farm areas. Oil patch-related products such as compressors and fuel handling were down. Cold weather-related hardlines, such as log splitters and stoves, were down double digits as a result of the lack of urgency cycling a warm winter season last year and low heating oil prices.
On a positive note, we did take advantage of opportunities for some key summer big ticket products, such as riding lawnmowers, by working collaboratively with vendors to develop a late-season sales driving program. Additionally, the average ticket was negatively impacted by the decline in the units per transaction, with preseason sales of wood-burning fuel as the principal driver. We estimated that deflation also decreased the average ticket by approximately 40 basis points. September was the strongest sales month and did register a positive comp. September did have the easiest year-over-year comparison. 
Now turning to gross margin which was flat at 34.7% compared to 60-basis-point decrease in last year's third quarter. Overall, we're very pleased how the team managed margin during a tough selling environment. We continue to improve our initial margin through our key margin initiatives. Product mix had a negative impact on margin. This resulted from a larger mix of feed and pet food and the strong sales in the riding lawnmower category. 
With respect to margin rate, we were sharper on price and, as Greg mentioned, added few sales-driving initiatives. Freight was essentially flat. Lower diesel fuel, lower container cost and a reduction in outbound stem miles were favorable factors. This was offset by higher inbound and outbound costs related to mix and higher lane costs. We estimate that deflation had a slightly favorable impact on gross margin.
For the quarter, SG&A, including depreciation and amortization as a percent of sales, deleveraged by 20 basis points to 25.5% of sales. The deleverage was primarily due to the decline in comparable sales. SG&A expense grew only 5.4% from the prior year which benefited from a reduction in incentive compensation expense. Excluding incentive compensation, SG&A expense increased only 7.9%, a continuation of the tight cost control management initiated in the second quarter.
Similar to the second quarter, we experienced strong cost control in store level and store support center payroll and medical expense. Occupancy expense was well managed as we continued to benefit from our LED lighting retrofit. The strong expense management was achieved against the headwind from our Arizona DC and mixing centers. We estimate the deleverage from these centers' operations were approximately 15 basis points.
